headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2015 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Drigge
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2015 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing the fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risk associate
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing the fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risk associated with forward-looking statements have been outlined in the earnings release in EOG's SEC filings and we incorporate those by reference to this call. This conference call also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation schedules for these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures can be found on our website at www.eogresources.com. 
The SEC permits oil and gas companies in their filings with the SEC to disclose not only proved reserves, but also probable reserves as well as possible reserves. Some of the reserve estimates on this conference call and webcast may include potential reserves or other estimated reserves not necessarily calculated in accordance with or contemplated by the SEC's reserve reporting guidelines. We incorporate by reference the cautionary note to U.S. investors that appears at the bottom of our press release and Investor Relations page of our website. 
Participating on the call this morning are Bill Thomas, Chairman and CEO; Gary Thomas, President and Chief Operating Officer; Billy Helms, EVP, Exploration and Production; David Trice, EVP, Exploration and Production; Lance Terveen, VP, Marketing Operations; and Cedric Burgher, Senior VP, Investor and Public Relations. An updated IR presentation was posted to our website yesterday evening, and we included guidance for the  first quarter and full year 2016 in yesterday's press release. This morning, we'll discuss topics in the following order: Bill Thomas will review 2015 highlights and our 2016 capital plans; David Trice and Billy Helms will review operational results and year-end reserve replacement data; then I will discuss EOG's financials, capital structure and hedge position and Bill will provide concluding remarks. Here's Bill Thomas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. EOG has committed a return focus capital discipline and we demonstrated that commitment in 2015 with a simple decision. After 4 years of 40% compound annual oil growth, we slammed on the brakes and decided to defer production growth. It was a
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. EOG has committed a return focus capital discipline and we demonstrated that commitment in 2015 with a simple decision. After 4 years of 40% compound annual oil growth, we slammed on the brakes and decided to defer production growth. It was an easy decision. Outspending cash flow to grow oil and through an oversupply market makes no sense. Rather than chasing production growth through the down cycle, we focused on 3 main goals. First, we concentrated more than ever on resetting the company to be successful on a lower commodity price environment by reducing costs and improving well productivity. 
Second, we wanted to add high-quality drilling inventory through organic exploration and tactical acquisitions. And most importantly, our third goal was to protect our balance sheet. As a result, EOG had a record year in reducing cost, improving well productivity and adding new drilling potential to the company. We accomplished all this and ended the year with one of the strongest balance sheets in the industry. Here are a few highlights from the year. 
We reduced capital more than 40% from 2014 and maintained that U.S. oil production. Total cash operating cost per unit decreased 17% compared to 2014. We drilled 2 industry record wells, 1 each in the Bakken and Delaware Basin Wolfcamp. We added a company record 1.6 billion barrels of oil equivalent and net resource potential over -- and over 3,000 net locations. That means we replaced more than 6x the inventory that we drilled in 2015 and we acquired 34,000 net acres in the sweet spot of the Delaware Basin. 
2015 changed how we think about EOG's position in the industry long-term. It's no longer enough to be the low-cost producer in U.S. horizontal shale. EOG's goal is to be competitive, low-cost oil producer in the global market. Now let's talk about our plan in 2016. Our first objective this year is to achieve strong returns on our capital program, the sustainable profitability gains. In order to maximize return on capital invested, we are shifting into what we call premium drilling mode. 
Like last year, we will concentrate our efforts in capital in our top plays: the Eagle Ford, Delaware Basin, Bakken and Rockies. The difference in 2016 is that we had a flexibility to direct capital only towards our large inventory of premium quality wells. Premium inventories is find wells that generate direct after-tax rates of return of at least 30% at $40 oil. We identified over 2 billion barrels of equivalent of net resource potential and 3,200 net drilling locations that meet this hurdle. 
At our 2016 pace, and we expect to complete 270 wells this year, that represents 12 years of drilling potential. In addition, we are confident our premium inventory will continue to grow in size and quality. Our proven track record of organic exploration and sustainable gains through technology and efficiency will continue to add premium inventory for years to come. What that means, and this is the most important point, is that between our existing premium inventory and our confidence that we can replace it, EOG will be in premium drilling mode from now on. 
EOG's shift to premium drilling in 2016 is not just simple high grading. It is a permanent upgrade for all our future drillings. It's important to realize that this is much more than a small incremental shift in our drilling program, it's a major step change in terms of per well productivity. For the average 2016 well, we estimate a 50% increase in the first 120 days of production per foot of treated lateral versus wells we completed in 2015. 
Our shift to premium drilling allows EOG to quickly return to triple digits, and I'll say this again, to quickly return to triple digit capital rates of return as oil prices improve to modest levels. So the next logical question is: what becomes of the remaining inventory? Our nonpremium inventory is still very high-quality. By any industry standard, it is Tier 1 quality with tremendous value. 
Due to the quality, a large percentage of this inventory will be converted to premium through technology and efficiency gains over time, the remaining high-quality inventory will add value to property sales or trades as part of our ongoing upgrading process. Our second objective in 2016 is to protect our balance sheet. Two years in a row, we have cut capital by more than 40%, demonstrating our commitment to capital discipline. In addition, as a result of our ongoing evaluation of our portfolio upgrade our asset base, we are marketing certain valuable but noncore properties. EOG prioritizes profitability and a healthy balance sheet to prepare the company for uncertain commodity cycles, and that strategy has paid off. 
EOG entered 2016 in excellent financial and operational shape. The combination of EOG's high-quality assets, sustainable cost reductions, and well productivity improvements allow the company to lead the industry in returns year after year. EOG is uniquely positioned with a large and growing inventory of high return drilling even in a $40 price environment. Achieving strong returns in the current environment positions EOG to achieve tremendous returns as commodity prices improve. 
Now I'll turn the call over to David Trice who will update you on the Eagle Ford and Rockies place.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Year after year, the Eagle Ford continues to impress with the quality of its resource potential. In 2015, we grew production while complete 38% fewer wells compared to 2014. Six years ago, we estimated Eagle Ford had 900 million barrels of o
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Year after year, the Eagle Ford continues to impress with the quality of its resource potential. In 2015, we grew production while complete 38% fewer wells compared to 2014. Six years ago, we estimated Eagle Ford had 900 million barrels of oil equivalent of net resource potential. We've since updated that net resource potential 3x and the latest estimate from early 2014 was 3.2 billion barrels of oil equivalent. 
In 2015, we've got a number of things that will promise the further upside to the Eagle Ford's resource potential. First, refinements to our high-density completion techniques continue to improve well productivity in 2015 as can be seen in the cumulative production charts in our investor presentation on Page 10. Second, to complement high-density completions, we made tremendous progress on what we have termed precision targeting. This is one of the most promising developments not only for the Eagle Ford but for all of our plays. Precision targeting starts with first, identifying and then mapping the key petrophysical properties that make the difference between a good well and a great well. 
Once all the data has been integrated, we found that the real sweet spot in any given target can be very narrow. Where we previously landed our wells and 150-foot window, we now precisely steer them in a window as narrow as 20 feet. In addition, this work on precision targeting also reveal that in some areas, we may have 2 distinct sweet spot targets in the lower Eagle Ford alone. 
Finally, we conducted power test by drilling adjacent wells in a W pattern that also make between the 2 targets within the lower Eagle Ford. This allows for surface down-spacing closer than 300 feet use in our current development spacing and resource potential estimate. Early results from these tests are encouraging. In 2016, we have more program flexibility as 91% of our Eagle Ford acreage is held by production. We plan to complete 150 Eagle Ford wells while continuing to test the W pattern. Spacing wells 200 to 250 feet apart. 
Our advancements in precision targeting and completions along with cost efficiencies, may have significant implication on our resource potential and will allow us to continue to upgrade additional Eagle Ford locations to premium status. In our Rockies and Bakken plays, we proactively scaled back activity due to commodity prices. With the lower activity level, we're able to sharpen our focus on sustainable operational improvements. We are very pleased with the progress and in fact, the magnitude of operational improvements in these plays were best in the company. Here are the highlights. 
First, we upgraded our Bakken net resource potential to 1 billion barrels of oil equivalent and added almost 1,000 net locations. Second, we reduced Bakken completed well costs 18% and drilling days over 30%. Third, we've built water handling and water pipeline infrastructure that significantly reduced its long-term LOE. Fourth, we drilled several high-quality wells in the Powder River Basin, highlighted by the Flatbow 602 to 1621H that came online in the fourth quarter. This turner well averaged over 1,100 barrels of oil per day and 1.7 million cubic feet per day of rich natural gas in its first 90 days of production. 
Finally, we also drilled a -- an industry record well in the Bakken, the Riverview 102-32H produce an average of 2,700 barrels of oil over the first 30 days and 2,200 barrels of oil per day for the first 90 days production. This well was the first high-density completion on our Antelope Extension acreage and is an industry record even though it is only a 4,300 foot lateral. Going forward, we will continue to develop this area at a moderate pace as we build out infrastructure that will allow us to deliver long-term operating costs. 
We're encouraged by these 2015 accomplishments in the Rockies and Bakken, and while the activity level will remain low in 2016, our focus on operational and well performance improvements will continue. We expect to see additional cost efficiencies, and well productivity advancements through completions and targeting refinement. We plan to complete approximately 35 wells in the Rockies in 2016. As we continue progressing technically and reducing costs, we expect the premium location count to growth significantly. 
Finally, a quick update on our Conway project in the East Irish Sea. All work for startup has been completed by EOG and we are working with the part-time operator to reach final acceptance, which we believe is imminent. We expect first production by the end of the quarter. Here's Billy Helms to review our activity in the Permian Delaware Basin

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Our Permian Delaware Basin team has made tremendous amount of progress last year. Prior to 2015, we developed a successful winter program and had encouraging results with the Wolfcamp and Bone Spring's intervals. As we entered 2015, we laid
componenttext:
Thanks, David. Our Permian Delaware Basin team has made tremendous amount of progress last year. Prior to 2015, we developed a successful winter program and had encouraging results with the Wolfcamp and Bone Spring's intervals. As we entered 2015, we laid out a specific plan to one, increase our technical knowledge to better understand the potential of these complex plays; two, improve our operational execution and cost performance; and three, expand the scope and the impact of the basin to EOG. 
Our efforts paid off. Here's a recap of our progress. First, we made tremendous progress utilizing 2 techniques: precision targeting and high-density completions. Our enhanced understanding of the regional of the basin, helps us to delineate the most productive target intervals within each formation. This technique requires a significant amount of technical data and data analysis expertise. And coupled with our high-density completion technique, generate solid improvements in well productivity as evidenced by our industry record-setting Wolfcamp well for 4 21 #702H, produced an average of 3,490 barrels of oil equivalent per day over its first 30 days of production. 
After 120 days, average production was an impressive 2,100 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Notably, the well was completed with a shorter lateral, yet still exceeded the longer lateral wells and absolute production. In fact, on average, our 2015 the Wolfcamp wells produced 40% more than the next best operator during the first 3 months of production as displayed on Slide 9 of our investor presentation. Second, we made significant progress generating sustainable cost reductions. For example, in the Wolfcamp oil window, we reduced average drilling time 33% and lower completed well cost 35% despite adding incremental cost to each well for high-density completions. In addition, we secured a long-term brackish water supply that as we move into 2016, it's expected to save us $200,000 to $300,000 per well. 
And finally, we increased the net resource potential for the Delaware Basin by 1.0 billion barrels of oil equivalent and added 2,200 net locations potentially adding decades of drilling inventory. This position us as -- this solidifies a position for the Delaware Basin as one of our high return wealth engines. We also executed on another 8,000 net-acre acquisition in the fourth quarter, bringing total 2015 Delaware Basin acquisitions to 34,000 net acres. This adds to our sweet spot acreage with significant upside potential through multiple stack targets. 
Thanks to the well productivity improvements and cost reductions achieved in 2015, the Delaware Basin delivers returns that compete for capital alongside the Eagle Ford. A large portion of the Delaware Basin is already considered premium and with our continued advancements, we expect to dramatically increase our inventory of premium location in the next few years. 
For 2016, we are continuing the momentum. The Delaware Basin will again be EOG's second most active basin next to the Eagle Ford. We plan to complete the same number of wells as we did in 2015, about 75, and we'll focus primarily on the Wolfcamp. Drilling the Wolfcamp generates excellent returns while allowing us to collect data on the shallower targets at the same time. I'll now address reserve replacement and funding costs. 
All in, proved reserves decreased 15% in 2015, driven primarily by price-related revisions. Excluding revision due to commodity price changes, we replaced 192% of our 2015 production, at a low funding costs of $11.91 per BOE. For the 28th consecutive year, the collier performed an independent engineering analysis of our reserves and their estimate is within 5% of our internal estimate. Their analysis covered about 86% of our crude reserves this year. We see the schedules in the company's earnings press release for the calculation of the reserve replacement funding cost. 
I'll now turn it over to Tim Driggers to discuss financials and capital structure.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Billy. I'll begin with a few comments about our capital spending last year and in the fourth quarter. Capital interest for the quarter was $8.9 million. For the fourth quarter 2015, total exploration and development expenditures were $737 million,
componenttext:
Thanks, Billy. I'll begin with a few comments about our capital spending last year and in the fourth quarter. Capital interest for the quarter was $8.9 million. For the fourth quarter 2015, total exploration and development expenditures were $737 million, including facilities of $116 million, and excluding acquisition and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $35 million. 
There were $105 million of acquisitions during the quarter. For the full year 2015, capitalized interest was $41.8 million. Total exploration and development expenditures were $4.4 billion, including facilities of $765 million, and excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditure for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $288 million. 
For the full year, capital expenditures, excluding acquisitions and asset retirement obligations were $4.7 billion, $200 million below the low end of our original 2015 guidance. Total cash flow from operations was $3.6 billion. In addition, proceeds from asset sales were $193 million. Total acquisitions for the year were $481 [ph] million. 
At year-end, total debt outstanding was $6.7 billion with debt-to-total capitalization ratio of 34%. Taking into account $719 million of cash flow at hand at year-end, net debt-to-total capital was 31%. In the fourth quarter of 2015, total impairments were $168 million, $94 million of these impairments were the results of significant declines in commodity prices during the fourth quarter. 
For the full year 2015, total impairments were $6.6 billion [ph], $6.3 billion of these impairments were results of declines in commodity prices and were related to legacy natural gas assets and marginal liquid plays. The remaining impairments for both the fourth quarter and full year 2015 were ongoing lease for producing company impairments. 
The effective tax rate for the fourth quarter was 29% and the deferred tax ratio was 92%. Yesterday, we included a guidance table with the earnings press release for the first quarter and full year 2016. Our 2016 CapEx estimate is $2.4 billion to $2.6 billion, excluding acquisitions. The exploration and development portion, excluding facilities will account for almost 80% of the total CapEx budget. 
Our 2016 CapEx estimate represents a 47% decrease from 2015 and a 70% less in 2014, capital expenditures demonstrating our commitment to capital discipline. The budget for exploration and development facilities and gathering processing and other accounts were approximately 20% of the total CapEx budget for 2016. 
We plan to concentrate our infrastructure spending in the Eagle Ford and Delaware Basin to support our drilling programs in those areas that enhance operating efficiency. In terms of hedges, for natural gas, we have approximately 60,000 MMBtu per day, close [ph] to $2.49 per MMBtu, the March 1 through August 31, 2016. We currently have no hedges in place for oil. 
Now I'll turn it back over to Bill.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Now for a few comments on the macro. During the fourth quarter of 2014, EOG was early to respond to the price signals in the market. We cut CapEx, scaled back activity and focused on returns and instead of growing oil into an oversupply marke
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. Now for a few comments on the macro. During the fourth quarter of 2014, EOG was early to respond to the price signals in the market. We cut CapEx, scaled back activity and focused on returns and instead of growing oil into an oversupply market. As we start 2016, we are encouraged by the disciplined operators are demonstrating around the world. This disciplined capital reduction is rapidly slowing U.S. oil drilling and reducing significant amounts of future supply worldwide. We believe the pace of market correction is increasing in 2016. 
Now in summary, I will leave you with a few important points. First, 2015 was a record year for EOG in terms of improving the company. We had record well and operating cost reductions and a record year in improving well productivity. We also had our best year ever in adding new, high-quality drilling inventory. Second, we are rapidly resetting the company to be successful in a lower commodity price environment. We are focused on improving returns and lowering operating costs instead of growing oil at the bottom of the market. 
Third, our shift to premium drilling this year should yield strong capital returns in a low commodity price environment. Premium wells generate after-tax rates of return of 30% or better at $40 oil. And over 100% after-tax rates of return at $60 oil. Therefore, EOG is uniquely positioned for tremendous performance as oil prices improve. Fourth, we do not view premium drilling mode as a temporary bridge to get to low oil prices. With over 2 billion barrels of oil equivalent, our premium net resource potential and 12 years of premium inventory, this is a permanent shift in the quality of EOG's future wells. 
We believe the company will continue to grow the size and quality of premium inventory for years to come. Fifth, we remain long-term focused. We continue to do the things that will add significant upside to the future of the company like investments in exploration, secondary recovery and other new technologies. Our focus is creating long-term shareholder value through sustainable productivity investments. 
And finally, our goal has always been to be the low-cost U.S. horizontal oil producer. As we look to the future, that's not enough. Our goal is now squarely set on being one of the lowest-cost producers in the competitive global oil market, and we are well on our way to reaching that goal. 
Thanks for listening. Now for the Q&A.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: My first question is your premiums locations appear higher than most peers core or comparable locations. I mean can you discuss what you think differentiates EOG's premium locations? And what's proprietary and represent a barrier for Pearce to achieve similar results? And also if I could, you mentioned upside locations. Any color on what percentage of the average locations have already been reviewed?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evan, this is [indiscernible]. Certainly, we believe that premium drilling mode is a step change in the future of the company. It is a substantial increase as we said. Over the last 2 years, it's about a 95% increase in quality of the wells we're going to
componenttext: Evan, this is [indiscernible]. Certainly, we believe that premium drilling mode is a step change in the future of the company. It is a substantial increase as we said. Over the last 2 years, it's about a 95% increase in quality of the wells we're going to drill and a 50% uplift for this year. So we're moving more rapidly than what maybe we might have even thought a few years ago. What's driving that is the quality of rock. And the quality of the rock is the most important factor in the productivity of the well. So we made extremely strong technical advancements in identifying of the best rock in the best plays over the years. And certainly, we believe we've captured the premium acreage in the premium plays in the U.S. And then also in each one of those plays, we developed petrophysical techniques, seismic techniques. We've used a lot of core data and have combined over 10 years of experience in these well plays to identify the best target zones in each one of the plays. And so that is the main driver, it's a lot of quality, and capturing its first and then being able to take all the technical knowledge and tools that we developed over the years. And to -- and our experience, to be able to pick out the best targets. And then we've developed proprietary techniques to not only identify, but to place the laterals in those targets and to keep the lateral in those targets for a long portion of the well. So our goal is to keep those targets -- those laterals in the best rock, about 95% or better on the well. So that's really the main driver. We think that's a very unique, very proprietary ability of EOG. And will be very difficult to duplicate in the future.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a follow-up, if I might -- if I may, you discussed a 55% jump in the expected performance per foot in '16. But since your DCs or duct are completed on a largely on a FIFO basis. I presume that many of the wells you complete this year are 2015 vintage.
componenttext: And a follow-up, if I might -- if I may, you discussed a 55% jump in the expected performance per foot in '16. But since your DCs or duct are completed on a largely on a FIFO basis. I presume that many of the wells you complete this year are 2015 vintage. And so my question is, is that, right? And would that then mean there's another step change in performance for 2017 as you completed more of those newly identified premium locations, all of the things being equal?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, the -- a large percentage of our wells that we're going to complete in the first half of the year are carryover duct from 2015. The majority of those wells are very beneficial to what we've been learning about targeting and identifying the rock
componenttext: Yes, Evan, the -- a large percentage of our wells that we're going to complete in the first half of the year are carryover duct from 2015. The majority of those wells are very beneficial to what we've been learning about targeting and identifying the rock. So those will be fantastic wells and we'll get extremely strong returns on those. But the learning curve is not over. We continue to refine our knowledge and our ability to execute, and so we see this is really just the beginning of a continuing, we believe sustainable productivity increase in our drilling moving forward. As we said in the opening, we've identified 3,200 locations and over 2 billion barrels of oil equivalent so far as premium, and we expect that to grow over time in numbers and quality. So we're -- this is really a big game changer for the company. We think it's very proprietary. So we think it's going to give us an extremely competitive edge going forward. So we believe as oil prices improve, we will be able to rapidly be able to generate triple digit rates of return going forward. So this is a very meaningful step for the company.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well I guess, I was talking about BOE guidance, which is still quite white. But I'll take it off-line with Cedric. My follow-up is really more balance sheet related. So I think in the past, Bill, in a more robust oil price environment, you talked abo
componenttext: Yes, well I guess, I was talking about BOE guidance, which is still quite white. But I'll take it off-line with Cedric. My follow-up is really more balance sheet related. So I think in the past, Bill, in a more robust oil price environment, you talked about some 30% ceiling on your net debt-to-cap. You're slightly above that right now. I'm just wondering how you're thinking about that. And this is not in any way disparaging to the industry, but a lot of very strong companies with very strong balance sheets have taken advantage of their relatively outperformance by obviously, issuing equity. I'm just curious as to how you feel about the uncertainty of the outlook, and how you might balance the priorities to reinforce the strategy of your balance sheet given how low your stock has been done in the market.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, just first of all, EOG has no current plans to equity -- to issue equity at this time. Certainly, we entered the year, we came into the downturn with a strong balance sheet and we've been disciplined throughout the process. And so we -- when we look
componenttext: Doug, just first of all, EOG has no current plans to equity -- to issue equity at this time. Certainly, we entered the year, we came into the downturn with a strong balance sheet and we've been disciplined throughout the process. And so we -- when we look as we go forward, we have tremendous flexibility to make further adjustments to capital throughout the year. We do anticipated selling noncore properties as we consistently do every year. We have -- we're pretty far along with that process. We have, what we believe are very high-quality strong buyers for properties. And this could be -- this is not a small amount of money. It's very significant, so we're quite confident in that process, and so our goal going forward is to maintain a strong balance sheet. And fortunately, our balance sheet right now is one of the strongest in the peer group. So that's certainly a focus for us. It's been a -- it's certainly been a hallmark. A strong balance sheet has been a strong hallmark for EOG for years and we've not taken our sight of that, and we're going to be committed to maintaining a good balance sheet going forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's net? Okay.
componenttext: That's net? Okay.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's net. So the gross EUR per well would be quite bigger than what you stated. And let me let David Trice comment a little bit more on the details on the Eagle Ford and the kind of what we expect there going forward.
componenttext: Yes, that's net. So the gross EUR per well would be quite bigger than what you stated. And let me let David Trice comment a little bit more on the details on the Eagle Ford and the kind of what we expect there going forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun. On the Eagle Ford, like we stated in our remarks, we've done a lot of work there. Obviously, over the years, we've collected a tremendous amount of data. Even in this last year in 2015, we drilled quite a few potholes where we actually drilled
componenttext:
Yes, Arun. On the Eagle Ford, like we stated in our remarks, we've done a lot of work there. Obviously, over the years, we've collected a tremendous amount of data. Even in this last year in 2015, we drilled quite a few potholes where we actually drilled down through the Eagle Ford and collected a lot of data. So what that allowed us to see was that we have a lot of additional upside there as far as working on the targeting, like I've mentioned, we're drilling 20-foot target intervals and doing multiple targets within the lower Eagle Ford. And we're seeing very good results with that and we're quite encouraged. So I think really going forward, we see a real opportunity to continue to add premium locations. We stated in our slides that we've got approximately 1,500 premium locations in the Eagle Ford. But we certainly see that as a starting point as far as being able to continue to add premium locations.
Let me just add -- just answer your question specifically on the 450 net MBOE per well in the Eagle Ford, that is for an average Eagle Ford well and that is not a premium well. Premium wells would be quite a bit better than that. And then that number is stale. So we haven't updated that 450 net Mboe per well for several years and we've made quite a bit of advancement since then in the high-density frac technology. And now we're making advancements in targeting also. So those numbers, it takes a little bit of time to get confirmation on what the new EUR number is, so when you make these advancements, you want to make sure you get at least a year's of production and then you can adjust them up accordingly.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up, Bill, you -- in some cases, you've now stratified the inventory a little bit between premium and other locations. You mentioned in your prepared remarks about EOG. Potentially being open to upgrading or trading inventory. I was wondering
componenttext: And my follow-up, Bill, you -- in some cases, you've now stratified the inventory a little bit between premium and other locations. You mentioned in your prepared remarks about EOG. Potentially being open to upgrading or trading inventory. I was wondering if you could maybe elaborate on that for the nonpremium inventory.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the nonpremium inventory will kind of have 2 avenues. The first avenue will be that we believe the majority of it will be converted to premium over time as we continue to learn how to target the rock more correctly, and we continue to be able to be b
componenttext: Yes, the nonpremium inventory will kind of have 2 avenues. The first avenue will be that we believe the majority of it will be converted to premium over time as we continue to learn how to target the rock more correctly, and we continue to be able to be better at picking out the high-quality rock in the target zones. So it's an ongoing process in every one of these plays and we expect the continued improvement. If it doesn't make into the premium in the inventory level and it never gets in our CapEx, then certainly it has a lot of value. All this nonpremium inventory that we have, if you compared it to the rest of the industry, it would be Tier 1 inventory. It's very high-quality. So it gives us a chance to market this as we go forward down the road and through property sales as we normally do in our asset upgrading process.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Brian Singer.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Brian Singer.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dylan, you're opening comments, you mentioned a focus, more specific focus of EOG being a competitive low-cost producer in the global market, not just U.S. shale. Before we run with this too far, do you still expect to do this predominantly through U.S. s
componenttext: Dylan, you're opening comments, you mentioned a focus, more specific focus of EOG being a competitive low-cost producer in the global market, not just U.S. shale. Before we run with this too far, do you still expect to do this predominantly through U.S. shale? Or is there any signal you're willing to pursue international shale or global non-shale investing opportunities to a greater degree? And is it still your view that you can do this from the premium focus areas that you've talked to you and then that you have on the Delaware Basin, Eagle Ford and Bakken?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, we have no intention of expanding international efforts. So we are going to be very much U.S.-driven. We see tremendous opportunity in the U.S. And so this whole direction towards being not only a low-cost producer in the U.S. horizontal route, we
componenttext: Brian, we have no intention of expanding international efforts. So we are going to be very much U.S.-driven. We see tremendous opportunity in the U.S. And so this whole direction towards being not only a low-cost producer in the U.S. horizontal route, we are -- we think we're clearly there. And our site now is really set on being one of the lowest cost producers in the world market. And we believe that we can accomplish this with our very high-quality assets that we currently have and continuing to improve them, and continuing to come up with new technology as we go forward. And we also believe very strongly that we can continue to grow that quality asset, much faster than we're drilling it. And that would be through converting existing inventory into premium and also through new plays. So we see tremendous opportunity in the U.S. and we're going to stay focused there, and we're quite confident that we can continue to lower our operating costs, lower our oil costs and improve well productivity to become more than competitive in the world.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the follow-up side is just 2 little questions. One, you highlighted exploration here and I wondered if you could just give an update on whether you expect to bring any meaningful projects to the [indiscernible] line and ultimately -- and annou
componenttext: And then on the follow-up side is just 2 little questions. One, you highlighted exploration here and I wondered if you could just give an update on whether you expect to bring any meaningful projects to the [indiscernible] line and ultimately -- and announce that in 2016 or whether the reduced budget is prohibitive in that regard? And then on the asset sale front, have you worked any of -- any production impact from any potential asset sales into the guidance that you've provided?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, for the latter part of your questions, we've not put any asset sales volumes into the production guidance. And so the first part of it -- what was the first part of the question?
componenttext: Yes, for the latter part of your questions, we've not put any asset sales volumes into the production guidance. And so the first part of it -- what was the first part of the question?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exploration.
componenttext: Exploration.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, exploration. We did not want to take any short-term cuts that might affect the long-term benefit of the company this year. So we left in a considerable amount of money in the current budget for exploration both in the acreage -- buying acreage on eme
componenttext: Yes, exploration. We did not want to take any short-term cuts that might affect the long-term benefit of the company this year. So we left in a considerable amount of money in the current budget for exploration both in the acreage -- buying acreage on emerging plays. And we also have several test of new plays continuing this year. So we'll see how those all go. We're quite hopeful, quite optimistic that we have maybe some plays that will be premium plays. We won't move forward unless there will be premium, of course. But we're quite optimistic on the exploration front.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Pearce Hammond with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And the next question is from Pearce Hammond with Simmons & Company.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is what commodity price assumptions are embedded in your 2016 capital plan?
componenttext: My first question is what commodity price assumptions are embedded in your 2016 capital plan?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pearce, we use the strip and we use the strip that was in the first part of January. And so we haven't got any -- we don't really put in a lot of upside to the current prices. I think it was based on prices in the -- around $40, was the current strip we u
componenttext: Pearce, we use the strip and we use the strip that was in the first part of January. And so we haven't got any -- we don't really put in a lot of upside to the current prices. I think it was based on prices in the -- around $40, was the current strip we used.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then my follow-up is kind of a hard question to ask, so just bear with me, but it follows up on Brian Singer's question. On the exploration front for the past number of years, you guys have worked on various plays. And obviously, you've had t
componenttext: Perfect. And then my follow-up is kind of a hard question to ask, so just bear with me, but it follows up on Brian Singer's question. On the exploration front for the past number of years, you guys have worked on various plays. And obviously, you've had tremendous success on the Eagle Ford as an example. But now, those plays weren't really -- some of those plays weren't economic and didn't really compete with your core plays back when oil was $80 to $100. And now obviously, oil is a lot lower. I know costs have come down. But when you look at those plays and you also look at what you mentioned in the press release about these premium inventory, how much success you're having at improving your existing inventory, would it make sense instead of spending the money on exploration on trying to discover new plays, to actually use that money to buy that existing acreage around the core -- around plays whether it be the Eagle Ford, the Permian, the Bakken, good stack or whatnot, and then take your core competency and expertise, which is clearly in making something better, would it be a better use of the capital and generate a higher return for shareholders?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pearce, let me let Billy Helms comment on that. We're very focused on bolt on tactical acquisitions. So I'll let him give you some color on that.
componenttext: Pearce, let me let Billy Helms comment on that. We're very focused on bolt on tactical acquisitions. So I'll let him give you some color on that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good morning, Pearce. What we were able to accomplish last year is a good example of that. We focused in first -- the first effort is understanding where the premium acreage is that Bill described earlier. It gets down to basically understand the roc
componenttext: Yes. Good morning, Pearce. What we were able to accomplish last year is a good example of that. We focused in first -- the first effort is understanding where the premium acreage is that Bill described earlier. It gets down to basically understand the rock. And we have to understand where the rock exists and those pieces that are additive to our portfolio and they compete for capital in our existing portfolio, certainly will add to that. As exhibited last year in our Delaware Basin acquisitions and we'll continue that effort as we go into the next year. That's just part of our ongoing philosophy of how we continue to grow the company. And we balanced that off with as you know, we also managed to sell off our properties every year. And so we balance those 2 with the overall capital discipline we have in the company. So that's always been part of our strategy and will continue to be.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next call is from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And the next call is from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you're drilling contracts, they're committing you to more drilling than you would otherwise do, all things being equal. It just seems as if you're somewhat dependent now on the oil prices recovering. But more importantly, I was wonderin
componenttext: I was wondering if you're drilling contracts, they're committing you to more drilling than you would otherwise do, all things being equal. It just seems as if you're somewhat dependent now on the oil prices recovering. But more importantly, I was wondering whether if you didn't have those locked in drilling contracts, you would actually be completing more wells and drilling less?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we did ended the year with 13 rigs under contract. I think the average this year will be 11 rigs. We look very hard at trying to buy out those contracts to reduce that, since we do have so many drops in place. But then we ran the numbers, it just di
componenttext: Well, we did ended the year with 13 rigs under contract. I think the average this year will be 11 rigs. We look very hard at trying to buy out those contracts to reduce that, since we do have so many drops in place. But then we ran the numbers, it just didn't make economic sense. Those rigs are the best quality rigs in the business. The efficiency is tremendous and it just didn't make economic sense to buy those out. So we're really focused on going forward, we didn't want to grow oil. Obviously, this year in the low part of the cycle. And so we didn't want to accelerate the ducts. So I'm going to let Gary Thomas give you a little bit more detail on the rig situation and our duct situation.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. This is Gary. If we didn't have these rigs under contract, we would certainly be completing more of our ducts with the evolving premium wells, that we're just honoring those contracts and as Bill said, yes, we're going to average -- we were 27
componenttext: Yes, Paul. This is Gary. If we didn't have these rigs under contract, we would certainly be completing more of our ducts with the evolving premium wells, that we're just honoring those contracts and as Bill said, yes, we're going to average -- we were 27 rigs under contract in '15, so 11 [ph] this year and we average 5.5 next year. But in '17 [ph], we're going to be able to accelerate the completion of our ducts. It will be very beneficial to us.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and the follow-up would just be, I assume that these prices, CapEx would be lower, but for the contracts.
componenttext: Yes, and the follow-up would just be, I assume that these prices, CapEx would be lower, but for the contracts.

componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you're simply not neither completing nor drilling as much if it wasn't for the fact you're committed in it and it would be too expensive to buy the contracts out.
componenttext: And you're simply not neither completing nor drilling as much if it wasn't for the fact you're committed in it and it would be too expensive to buy the contracts out.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I have a question about the high-density completions. It almost sounds like when I look at it, you're sort of taking the unconventional reservoir and transforming it something close to conventional reservoirs near the well bore. And I don't know if tha
componenttext: So I have a question about the high-density completions. It almost sounds like when I look at it, you're sort of taking the unconventional reservoir and transforming it something close to conventional reservoirs near the well bore. And I don't know if that's a fair way to characterize it. But I guess my question is, do you think there's any implications for the longer-term shape of the decline curve of this new completion from thinking several years out? I'd like to hear your take on it.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The high-density completions, what they do and you described it fairly accurately, is that they contact the enormous amounts of surface area of the rock and they're very, very close to the well bore. So obviously, the better the rock and the more that you
componenttext: The high-density completions, what they do and you described it fairly accurately, is that they contact the enormous amounts of surface area of the rock and they're very, very close to the well bore. So obviously, the better the rock and the more that you connect to the wellbore, especially close to the wellbore, has a tremendous effect on the uplift wells. And let me let Billy Helms comment on kind of the long-term effect of this uplift.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bizu, you did characterize it very accurately. I think the one way to think about it is certainly the more rock you contact in the reservoir, basically yes, you're going to increase the initial potential of that well. But by contact more that rock, y
componenttext: Yes, Bizu, you did characterize it very accurately. I think the one way to think about it is certainly the more rock you contact in the reservoir, basically yes, you're going to increase the initial potential of that well. But by contact more that rock, you're also increasing the ultimate recovery from every well. So you will see your initial production rates, but your decline we're seeing, the benefit of declines flattening with more production from these high-density completions. So the overall effect has been quite uplifting.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when we compare the shape of the decline curve in the longer term, it will remain fairly similar? So when we look at the sort of the terminal rates, would you expect a higher decline for the higher density completions or no?
componenttext: So when we compare the shape of the decline curve in the longer term, it will remain fairly similar? So when we look at the sort of the terminal rates, would you expect a higher decline for the higher density completions or no?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Actually we're not seeing that at all. We're seeing longer-term, the wells will produce longer and the initial decline is a little bit less than the older completions are. This is simply because you're connecting a lot more rock to the wellbore.
componenttext: No, no. Actually we're not seeing that at all. We're seeing longer-term, the wells will produce longer and the initial decline is a little bit less than the older completions are. This is simply because you're connecting a lot more rock to the wellbore.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Tameron with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Tameron with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, how do you think about a ramp as you go into -- assuming we get some upward pressure on prices a year from now. Like what -- how quickly can you ramp? I know you talked about prior -- the availability of people and maybe the services industry can't
componenttext: Bill, how do you think about a ramp as you go into -- assuming we get some upward pressure on prices a year from now. Like what -- how quickly can you ramp? I know you talked about prior -- the availability of people and maybe the services industry can't respond as fast. Can you just talk -- walk us through how you see a scenario if oil goes back to $55 tomorrow? Like how does that play out for EOG?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, we're set up tremendously well. Of course, we're going to handle very large, very high-quality duct inventory. We've got rigs in play. And we have a substantial amount of frac bridge running. We delay the work schedule on some of the frac spreads t
componenttext: David, we're set up tremendously well. Of course, we're going to handle very large, very high-quality duct inventory. We've got rigs in play. And we have a substantial amount of frac bridge running. We delay the work schedule on some of the frac spreads to maybe 5 days a week instead of 7 days a week type of scenarios, so that we can keep a number of frac spreads in place that would be easy to accelerate. When oil prices begin to recover, we're going to be disciplined going forward. We don't -- obviously, don't want to be fooled again like the industry was fooled last year by a little bit of an uptick in oil price and is not sustainable. So we're going to be disciplined in cost going forward on ramping up capital until we're very much convinced that this is not a short-term uptick in the price and that the market is more imbalanced and that the is price more sustainable. But we think obviously, EOG is in fantastic shape to generate extremely strong -- we're talking about triple digit rates of return as oil prices improve. And we have the ability to grow oil when the time comes.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I think about it, I'm going to ask a couple of question, but if I think about -- if you make the decision tomorrow to add rigs and obviously, with the ducts, you can cover some of -- this gap. But how long -- if you say tomorrow, let's s
componenttext: Okay. And then if I think about it, I'm going to ask a couple of question, but if I think about -- if you make the decision tomorrow to add rigs and obviously, with the ducts, you can cover some of -- this gap. But how long -- if you say tomorrow, let's say let's add a rig, how long does it take before we see that production given the laterals and pads, and everything else, is that a 6 month before you see that crunching the numbers?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, we're -- I'm going to ask Gary Thomas to give some color on that.
componenttext: David, we're -- I'm going to ask Gary Thomas to give some color on that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, the benefit for EOG is having this -- by the end of the year, we'll have 230 of these ducts to complete. And having those and then having the number of frac fleets that we have currently that we could ramp up as Bill is saying, besides being able t
componenttext: David, the benefit for EOG is having this -- by the end of the year, we'll have 230 of these ducts to complete. And having those and then having the number of frac fleets that we have currently that we could ramp up as Bill is saying, besides being able to add. You just start with the completion and bringing out, you can see a pretty substantial increase in volumes within 3 to 4 months. And we would just be starting drilling rigs that would be almost twice that long like you're mentioning the 6 months. But it's going to be about half that time.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mike Scialla with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mike Scialla with Stifel.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll follow up to David's question. It sounded like you're not inclined to want to go back to growth mode unless you see a significant price increase. But looking at that inventory of 3,200 premium locations that generate a 30% plus IRR with $40 oil
componenttext: Maybe I'll follow up to David's question. It sounded like you're not inclined to want to go back to growth mode unless you see a significant price increase. But looking at that inventory of 3,200 premium locations that generate a 30% plus IRR with $40 oil, if it looks like that's all that we're going to get out of our recovery, would you go back to growth mode if that were the case?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Mike, that would give the $40 oil, would give us obviously, a bit more cash flow. But we would be certainly, wanting to stay balanced especially the cash flow to CapEx. So that's really going to control the amount of growth that we have. And alon
componenttext: I think, Mike, that would give the $40 oil, would give us obviously, a bit more cash flow. But we would be certainly, wanting to stay balanced especially the cash flow to CapEx. So that's really going to control the amount of growth that we have. And along with making sure that the oil prices is really sustainable. So we can generate the returns. But the growth of the company will be regulated by obviously, the number of wells we complete and the continued improvement we have that will be regulated by the cash flow of the company.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And can you talk about in terms of that premium count, you said Bill, that you could grow that over time. You alluded to how you would do that with better targeting. But I wanted to see where you anticipate, if you could say where most of that will
componenttext: Okay. And can you talk about in terms of that premium count, you said Bill, that you could grow that over time. You alluded to how you would do that with better targeting. But I wanted to see where you anticipate, if you could say where most of that will come from? Is it down-spacing in the Eagle Ford? Is it primarily from the Permian? Or somewhere else?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, it will be really from multiple sources. We're learning in every one of the plays that we're in. And it's really just being able to identify those targets windows within those good plays, and then executing on those. So we were still working on down
componenttext: Mike, it will be really from multiple sources. We're learning in every one of the plays that we're in. And it's really just being able to identify those targets windows within those good plays, and then executing on those. So we were still working on down-spacing in a lot of plays. So it will come from multiple plays improving the inventory there, the premium. And then it'll come from new plays too. We have quite a bit of confidence that through our learning process on the existing plays that we can identify very high-quality rock in emerging plays. And so we're actively engaged in buying acreage in testing wells from those 2. So it'll come from a multiple source. Historically, even through the uptick when we have $90, $95 oil and we were growing very quickly and drilling a lot of wells, we were able to add twice as many wells each year than what we actually drilled. And so we're very confident that we can continue that kind of multiple on the premium going forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Subash Chandra with Guggenheim.
componenttext: And the next question is from Subash Chandra with Guggenheim.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are we looking at a permanent shift to better wells but fewer wells? And how exacting your premier process is and how reliant it is on massive data analysis? And then I have a follow-up.
componenttext: Are we looking at a permanent shift to better wells but fewer wells? And how exacting your premier process is and how reliant it is on massive data analysis? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly when you're drilling twice as good wells, you don't have to drill near as many of them. And so that certainly helps keep your CapEx down and you're able to have a lot more efficiency there. So as you go forward, the learning process will b
componenttext: Well, certainly when you're drilling twice as good wells, you don't have to drill near as many of them. And so that certainly helps keep your CapEx down and you're able to have a lot more efficiency there. So as you go forward, the learning process will be incremental at each one of these plays. And it's a distant ongoing thing. We learn this and then we try it, and as we get good positive results, we're able to apply that to additional wells. And then the sustainable technology gains that we have in the company have been very, very continuous and very steady over the whole life of our involvement in horizontal drilling. It's over 10 years of experience, combined knowledge and we have quite a bit of innovative culture in the company. And we expect that to continue to improve the wells as we go forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the follow-up is -- and no question you're lightyears ahead in many ways. When we think about the additional inventory in that, it is dependent on data that where you have more wells is likely where we'll see more inventory over time. And so the other
componenttext: And the follow-up is -- and no question you're lightyears ahead in many ways. When we think about the additional inventory in that, it is dependent on data that where you have more wells is likely where we'll see more inventory over time. And so the other side of that is how applicable is this to new exploration concepts?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, correctly, when we have an ongoing drilling program and we're collecting data all the time in the existing play, that's certainly how you make advances. But we also are able to take that learning experience and apply it to new plays. So the high-dens
componenttext: Yes, correctly, when we have an ongoing drilling program and we're collecting data all the time in the existing play, that's certainly how you make advances. But we also are able to take that learning experience and apply it to new plays. So the high-density frac techniques, the kinds of rocks that would respond to high-density techniques and then the petrophysical properties of rocks in emerging plays and in the core, we're going to do an extensive amount of very detailed core work. And we integrate all this data along with 3D seismic. And so all that goes into bear on to finding newer plays with high-quality rock. And so it's a learning process that spills over, and it really helps us keep the momentum and keep adding premium inventory to go forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: EOG has a strong track record of game changing events that made the company successful over time. Our shift to premium drilling mode this year with an estimated 50% year-over-year increase and well productivity is another step change to the company's perf
componenttext: EOG has a strong track record of game changing events that made the company successful over time. Our shift to premium drilling mode this year with an estimated 50% year-over-year increase and well productivity is another step change to the company's performance. Premium drilling allows EOG to generate solid capital returns at $40 oil and quite frankly, spectacular returns as oil prices recover. With our focus on improving returns instead of production growth during this down cycle, EOG is now positioned for tremendous performances as process improve. We believe the best times for the company are ahead of us. So thank you for listening, and thank you for your support.
