headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2016 First Quarter Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2016 First Quarter Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. I hope everyone has seen the press release announcing first quarter 2016 earnings and operation results. This conference call contains forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-lookin
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. I hope everyone has seen the press release announcing first quarter 2016 earnings and operation results. This conference call contains forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-looking statements have been outlined in the press release and EOG's SEC filings, and we incorporate those by reference for this call. This conference call also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation schedules for these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures can be found on our website at www.eogresources.com. The SEC permits oil and gas companies in their filings with the SEC to disclose not only proved reserves, but also probable reserves, as well as possible reserves. Some of the reserve estimates on this conference call and webcast may include potential reserves or other estimated reserves not necessarily calculated in accordance with or contemplated by the SEC's reserve reporting guidelines. We incorporate by reference the cautionary note to U.S. investors that appears at the bottom of our press release and Investor Relations page of our website. Participating on the call this morning are Bill Thomas, Chairman and CEO; Gary Thomas, President and Chief Operating Officer; Billy Helms, EVP, Exploration and Production; David Trice, EVP, Exploration and Production; Lance Terveen, VP, Marketing Operations; and Cedric Burgher, Senior VP, Investor and Public Relations.
An update of our presentation is posted to our website yesterday evening and it include guidance for the second quarter and full year 2016 in yesterday's press release. This morning, we'll discuss topics in the following order: Bill Thomas will review our 2016 plan and first quarter highlights; Billy Helms and David Trice will review operational results; I will then discuss EOG's financial capital structure and hedge position and Bill will provide concluding remarks. Here's Bill Thomas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. EOG is becoming an even better company than it was just a year ago by lowering development and production costs and increasing returns. In the yesterday's press release, we announced 2 exciting developments that ha
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. EOG is becoming an even better company than it was just a year ago by lowering development and production costs and increasing returns. In the yesterday's press release, we announced 2 exciting developments that have the potential to be significant additional drivers of higher returns of lower costs. I'll briefly highlight those, and Billy and David will provide details in a moment. Finally, I'll review our shift to premium drilling and how this shift is a game-changing event with significant long-term implications for EOG shareholders. 
First, I want to highlight EOG's development on the first successful on enhanced oil recovery technology in U.S. [indiscernible] on sale. We initiated our EOR efforts in the Eagle Ford 3 years ago. Here's what's we've learned since that time. Number one, geology matters. The Eagle Ford is unique. The same geological characteristic that make the Eagle Ford prolific and primary development  also make it unique for enhanced oil recovery. That EOR process we're using to produce incremental oil out of the Eagle Ford is not necessarily applicable to other horizontal basins. 
Number two. How you initially drilled the field matters. Secondary recovery works best on leased units that were developed using the best completions with optimal space. 
Finally, returns matter. We figured out how to execute EOR economically. The process can be implemented at rates of return that rival our premium drilling and significantly lower funding costs over time. 
The second item I will highlight is our discovery in the South Texas Austin Chalk. The turn discovery is loaded as many operators have been drilling the chart for years with varying degrees of success. Perhaps a more accurate characterization is that we discovered a new geologic concept in an existing play. Our team EOG has cracked the code on how to make our particular footprint in the Austin Chalk a top-tier horizontal play earning returns on par with the Eagle Ford, Permian and Bakken. The third item I would like to review its EOG's shift to premium drilling this year. This shift is a game-changer with significant long-term implications. I will cover those implications in a moment. But first, let's review by what we mean by premium. 
Premium inventory is defined as drilling locations that generate at least 30% [ph] direct after-tax rate of return at $40 oil. Here's a few more clarifying points regarding this inventory. First, 30% return is not an average. It's a minimum. Second, 30% was established as the minimum direct return to ensure that when indirect costs are included, the drilling program are in healthy full cycle returns. Third, we fully expect to more than replace our drilling inventory with new premium locations every year. Therefore, this is the most -- and this is the most important point, our shift to premium is permanent and not simply a temporary high-grading process in a low-commodity price environment. So 2016 will mark a point in time when EOG made a significant permanent shifted its drilling program. There are many long-term implications for that shift. The first is superior capital discipline. Premium drilling set a new higher standard for capital allocation within the company. The second is a large capital efficiency gain. We do not need 50 rigs drilling thousands of wells per year. It will take far west capital for growth production at strong double-digit rates. The third implication is we can return the triple-digit direct rates of return with oil as low as $60 per barrel. And if history is any indication, we will continue to post the oil price needed for triple-digit returns even lower. And finally, premium drilling extends our lead as low cost horizontal oil reserve. As I outlined, our premium shift to premium drilling this year is a game-changing event for EOG. Yesterday's announcement regarding our enhanced oil recovery success in the Eagle Ford and are often drilling success are 2 more technical and operational achievements that will help us reach our long-term goal of being one of the lower-cost producers in the global oil market. Now I'll turn it over to Billy Helms to discuss our exciting results from enhanced oil recovery in the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Three years ago, we initiated an effort to test EOR using gas injection and horizontal shale. Results from lab experiments indicated that the process was technically feasible, but the economics and operational execution were going to be chal
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Three years ago, we initiated an effort to test EOR using gas injection and horizontal shale. Results from lab experiments indicated that the process was technically feasible, but the economics and operational execution were going to be challenged without some creative problem-solving. Our EOR team has only saw the problem the demonstrated returns that are competitive with our premium program. That EOR processes developed is highly proprietary and this limits the amount of detail we are able to disclose. However, I will share several reasons why EOG is uniquely positioned to achieve a successful outcome. As Bill mentioned earlier, the geological setting is important. We have long discuss the competent barriers that it takes to Eagle Ford and provide vertical containments for comletions. This unique feature allows plays -- also plays a significant role in keeping the injection in contact with the targeted reservoir. The injected gas is thus able to become admissible, with the oil and the reservoir exceptionally driving incremental oil recovery. EOG's acreage position is situated in the optimal thermal maturity of the play to maximize oil recovery. Being in the oil window has provided many benefits during the primary development, but it's also important for the EOR process acreage that is too far down deep or at dip in the play may not benefit us greatly. That EOR economics are significantly enhanced by the scale out of EOG's footprint in the play. The infrastructure and facilities that are utilized during primary development across the field are keys to be able to operationally execute the EOR process. Thus, providing a significant economic benefit. These reasons are the keys to the process of success and are why -- why we believe EOR will not be a blanket application across the Eagle Ford or necessarily applicable to other horizontal shale plays. We have not yet determined how much the EOG's acreage will benefit from EOR or what the overall resource potential may be. The 4 pilot projects have tested different geographic and geologic settings, each proving the concept successful. But further definition and time will be needed to assess the applicability and overall benefit across EOG's acreage position. 
Here are some of the key takeaways regarding the economics and recovery potential. One, this EOR technique is not capital-intensive. There is no incremental drilling required for capital cost to average approximately $1 million per well. Two, the operating costs are low. The process makes use of produced gas readily available to the field and there are a few other incremental operating costs. Three, EOR may have significant effect on our long-term base profile unlock typical secondary recovery projects, the production response occurs quickly within the first 2 to 3 months and hold steady for longer. Four, the combination of operating costs and steady production delivers a return profile that complements our primary drilling program. Primarily drilling delivers high returns and short paybacks. Our EOR [indiscernible] has a much different profile characterized by modest upfront capital investment that delivers a longer annuity of incremental oil production and strong cash flow. The rate of return is still on par with primary drilling. But for each dollar invested, EOR delivers at least twice the net present value created as primary drilling. Finally, our models indicate that this process will increase recovery by 30% to 70%. I want to emphasize these are incremental potential reserves not accelerated production delivering at -- delivered at potential finite cost of $6 per barrel of oil or less. We will conduct a the pilot in 2016 and we will evaluate the results and review our acreage. We will determine the long-term capital production and earnings effect of EOR. It's important to note that while this is a significant technical and economic breakthrough, drilling out this effort will take time and it is dependent on the pace of primary drilling and field development. Now here is David Trice.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Billy. Another exciting development on our South Texas acreage position concerns the Austin Chalk. In our press release yesterday, we published the results of our 2 tremendous Austin Chalk wells, the Leonard AC Unit 101H, producing an average with
componenttext:
Thanks, Billy. Another exciting development on our South Texas acreage position concerns the Austin Chalk. In our press release yesterday, we published the results of our 2 tremendous Austin Chalk wells, the Leonard AC Unit 101H, producing an average with 2,715 barrels of oil equivalent per day for 30 days. The unit 101H was completed in April and its average production for the first 20 days was 3,130 barrels of oil equivalent per day. While the Austin Chalk is not a new play, historically industry production has been inconsistent from well to well. While good wells are possible, the performance and resulting returns are highly variable across the play. However, use of proprietary metaphysical analysis we discovered how to find new geologic concepts to the Austin Chalk and drill prolific wells consistently. Much like the Eagle Ford, the Chalk responds very well to EOG style completions. Our high-density completions rig great complex fracture systems both to the well bore in significantly improving well performance. Also like the Eagle Ford, the Austin Chalk benefits from the detailed work we conduct to determine the best target. The Chalk can be as thick as 140 feet in some areas, but our targeting efforts keep the drill bit confined to this 20 to 30 feet of rock. Precision targeting combined with EOG stock equations is now generating prolific premium level well performance. It's too early in our exploration efforts to know how much of the Austin Chalk is perspective over our acreage. The self-service data and detailed mapping, the Austin fields are encouraging. We plan to drill additional 7 Austin Chalk wells in 2016 and look forward to updating you with future drilling results as we learn more. In the Permian Delaware Basin, our recent activity has focused on the Wolfcamp oil window. Drilling the Wolfcamp generates excellent returns while allowing us to collect data on the shower targets such as the Second Bone Spring Sand. During the first quarter, we completed a dozen wells with per well average 13 day rates over 2,100 barrels of oil equivalent per day with approximately 17% oil pad. The average lateral of these Wolfcamp wells is approximately 4,500 [ph] feet. Over the last year, we focused on increasing our understanding of the geology and maximizing well performance through better technologies such as precision targeting, completions and better wellbore design. As a result, our wells are industry-leading as illustrated on Slide 8 on our investor presentation. Since January of last year, our wells have been twice as good as industry average in the Midland or Delaware Basin when normalized collaterally. This is approach EOG takes across all of our plays. We seek to first understand the geology; second, optimize the completions; and finally, enhance operational practices that maximize efficiencies and lower costs. 
Our next step for Wolfcamp optimization is to extend the lateral. Breakthroughs we made in wellbore design will allow us to apply EOG style high-density completions to long Wolfcamp laterals. Longer will enhance our highly successful Wolfcamp program and reduce our service footprint across the play. In April, we drilled 2 7,000-foot laterals, the Rattlesnake 21 feet 701H and 702H. These wells are too new to report at 30-day rate. However, the first 20 days of production are averaging more than 3,800 barrels of oil equivalent per day per well with maximum 24-hour rates at 4,200 barrels of oil equivalent per day per well. 
Meanwhile, we continue to further improve operational efficiencies and cost in the Wolfcamp. During the first quarter, drilling days decreased 14% from our 2015 average to 16.1 days. Also, total well cost decreased 8% to $6.9 million, more than offsetting costs associated with continued completion enhancements. In addition, in the second quarter, we'll begin using our brackish water supply for our New Mexico completions with an anticipated savings of $150 million per well. This new water supply, along with many other operational improvements, will allow EOG to continue to lower cost and increase returns. On international front, we are very happy to report that our East Irish Sea Conway project achieved first production in late March. We're currently addressing normal start-up items and running tests to determine the optimal production rate. Our full-year guidance has been adjusted until we complete more testing. Here's Tim Driggers.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Capitalized interest for the first quarter 2016 was $9 million. Total exploration and development expenditures were $568 million, excluding property acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering syst
componenttext: Thanks, David. Capitalized interest for the first quarter 2016 was $9 million. Total exploration and development expenditures were $568 million, excluding property acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $25 million. This compared to the first quarter 2015 total exploration expenditures decreased by 62% while our total production volumes decreased by just 7%. We have maintained our full year capital expenditure guidance of $2.4 million to $2.6 million. At the end of March 2016, total debt outstanding was $7 billion and the debt-to-total-capitalization ratio was 36%. At March 31, we had $700 million of cash on hand giving us non-GAAP net debt of $6.3 billion or net debt to total cap ratio of 34%. The effective tax rate for the first quarter was 34% and the deferred tax rate was 82%. For the period 9 1 [ph] through June 30, 2016, EOG has crude oil financial price swap contracts in place for 128,000 barrels and barrels of oil per day at a weighted average price of $42.60 per barrel. For the period June 1 through August 31, 2016, EOG has natural gas financial price swap contracts in place for 60,000 MMBtu per day and a weighted average price of $2.49 per MMBtu. Now I'll turn it back over to Bill.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. First, a brief word on our macro views and how they relate to EOG's plans. The substantial capital of capital investment by the industry in 2015 and 2016 is causing oil supply to decline in many producing regions around the world. Led by stea
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. First, a brief word on our macro views and how they relate to EOG's plans. The substantial capital of capital investment by the industry in 2015 and 2016 is causing oil supply to decline in many producing regions around the world. Led by steady declines in the U.S. and supported by strong gasoline demand, the market continues to rebalance. We agree with consensus that this process will accelerate in the second half of this year and into 2017. We believe that in the U.S., it will take a sustained $60 to $65 oil price and 12 months of lead time for the industry to deliver a modest level of growth. However, what is true for the industry in general does not hold for EOG. EOG is a low-cost U.S. horizontal oil producer. With our premium drilling inventory, we believe our reinvestment advantage is $15 to $20 per barrel lower than the average industry operator. When the market balances and prices recover to moderate levels, our leading asset quality, best-in-class technology and low-cost structure will become apparent with how quickly we can resume higher return oil growth.
And that may be the #1 question we received the last 2 months. And or more accurately, at what price will we accelerate and return to growth? Our first priority this year is to completely find our capital program with cash flow and reduce net debt with property sales. We're in the late stages of negotiating on a number of deals and are confident we will be successful on many this year. We expect their collective impact will be meaningful. Our second priority will be to complete [indiscernible]. We have managed our operations such that we have the capacity to add 40% more completions without adding any additional equipment from the service industry. We can respond quickly as supply and demand balance and oil process firm. 
In summary, I would like to leave you with the following important takeaways from this call. Number one, our shift to premium drilling this year is a game-changer. We expect well productivity to improve more than 50% in 2016, which is the largest 1 year improvement in the history of the company. More importantly, this shift is permanent. Premium drilling will allow us to maintain a balanced capital program and resume high return oil growth in a moderate oil price environment. Number two, our enhanced oil recovery success is another example of EOG's ability to make significant technology games. EOR has the potential to add meaningful long-term value to our Eagle Ford asset by adding low-decline, low-cost, high-return reserves. Number three. The new Austin Chalk results are encouraging for our South Texas acreage position. Time will tell. But we believe the chalk geology we discovered is substantially better and more repeatable than previous chalk drilling. Number four. Last year, last year we said 2015 was a record year for improving the company. As we start this year, we are beginning to realize that the improvements in 2016 may be even stronger than 2015. Our sustainable gains in technology and efficiencies are running at record-setting pace and we are excited about what we can achieve in cost reduction and productivity improvements in 2016. Number five. Our goal has always been to be the highest return E&P company in the U.S. and we believe that we have achieved that goal. Our sites are now set on becoming one of the lowest-cost producers in the global oil market. We believe it's possible and we are moving toward that target rapid. Thanks for listening. And now, we'll go to Q&A.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan. This is Billy Helms. So as you mentioned, there, the next step obviously, is implementing a the 32-well pilot. We're still learning a great deal about the process and what its overall impact will be. And primarily, the pace of development in th
componenttext: Yes, Evan. This is Billy Helms. So as you mentioned, there, the next step obviously, is implementing a the 32-well pilot. We're still learning a great deal about the process and what its overall impact will be. And primarily, the pace of development in the future will depend on our pace of development primarily for the developing out the remaining leases and then how we roll that out. I would say that our pace of rollout, we expect to continue to announce new wells or bring new wells into that process in the coming years. And it will become a part of our overall capital allocation to the Eagle Ford that we do primarily each year. We rolled out the certainly our 2017 guidance on that probably in February. But we were very encouraged with our initial results so it's probably a little bit too early to talk about how we're going to roll that out. We still have a lot to learn from our 32-well pilot. And then know we still have a lot of leases to do.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, does the existence of EOR potential later in life opportunity, does that change the way we allocate capital on primarily drilling being as it makes Eagle Ford either relatively more attractive? Or the black window versus the condensate window more
componenttext: I mean, does the existence of EOR potential later in life opportunity, does that change the way we allocate capital on primarily drilling being as it makes Eagle Ford either relatively more attractive? Or the black window versus the condensate window more attractive given this new secondary recovery option?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evan. This is Bill. I don't think it changes it dramatically. We're focused on premium drilling in all of our plays and in Eagle Ford, that's what we want to develop first in our leases and that's what we're going to focus on really permanently from now o
componenttext: Evan. This is Bill. I don't think it changes it dramatically. We're focused on premium drilling in all of our plays and in Eagle Ford, that's what we want to develop first in our leases and that's what we're going to focus on really permanently from now on. So we'll develop those at a normal pace. As Billy mentioned, the key is really to get those developed with the drilling and the completions in the most optimal spacing. And to connect as much rock to the primary process. And that really enhances the EOR effectiveness as we go forward. So we'll move along both of them in a nice steady pace. And we'll just continue to learn as we go forward. And I think the EOR process will be much like the drilling program. We'll get more efficient as we move forward and we'll be able to lower cost and it'll just become kind of a normal part of our investment in the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

componenttextpreview: Bill, on the EOR process, you've done 4 pilots and tested that on 15 [ph] producing wells. Was -- were the tests successful in all the wells? Or can you just talk a little bit about the effectiveness that you've seen thus far?
componenttext: Bill, on the EOR process, you've done 4 pilots and tested that on 15 [ph] producing wells. Was -- were the tests successful in all the wells? Or can you just talk a little bit about the effectiveness that you've seen thus far?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun, this Billy Helms. Certainly, the -- each one of our test, we've learned a lot. I would say without a hesitation that all of our pilot tests were successful. Certainly, we continue to learn from each one. We started the project really with some
componenttext: Yes, Arun, this Billy Helms. Certainly, the -- each one of our test, we've learned a lot. I would say without a hesitation that all of our pilot tests were successful. Certainly, we continue to learn from each one. We started the project really with some laboratory experiments just trying to understand what the fluid behaviors will be. And that certainly was very encouraging. They would roll it out to a single well pilot and had positive results from that. And then we started flying into more multi-well pilots. We had 2 full well pilots and 6 well pilot. And each one of those was successful. So the next step, as we've discussed, is to roll it out in more of a field scale model, which was this 32 well pilot and we'll certainly continue to learn from that. But yes, each one was very successful.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

componenttext: And just my follow-up. Bill, on your prepared remarks when you're talking about the premium locations. You expressed confidence that you could either replace this premium location from an inventory perspective on an ongoing basis. Can you just give us a little bit more color around that, what's driving that confidence?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun. As you know, we believe we have very sustainable cost reduction and technology gains. We've done it we've been in the business and we have a lot of confidence and we see a lot of upside going forward to continue that process. So as we increased
componenttext: Yes, Arun. As you know, we believe we have very sustainable cost reduction and technology gains. We've done it we've been in the business and we have a lot of confidence and we see a lot of upside going forward to continue that process. So as we increased productivity through being able to identify better block and this precision targeting and you get even better with our high-density frac techniques, we believe that the well productivity will continue to increase. That would be 1 way to convert. And then we also believe that we have sustainable cost reduction. So 2/3 of our cost reductions during the downturn have been through technology and efficiency gains. And we do not see any end in that. So we're quite confident that efficiency and technology will continue to drive those costs down. And so we believe a large percentage of inventory that we have in the Eagle Ford will be converted to premium. And we also believe that in the Permian, and we believe we'll add continued premium in the Bakken and other plays too. So we're very confident that our premium inventory will grow much faster than our drilling pace.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

componenttext: We'll move forward to our next question from Robert Morris to with the Royal Capital Markets.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on the EOR process. I know a lot of the stuff that you all did was proprietary, but when do you think it's the right time to actually put this application to work? So what I'm getting at is obviously, these wells have a pretty steep decline rate
componenttext: Question on the EOR process. I know a lot of the stuff that you all did was proprietary, but when do you think it's the right time to actually put this application to work? So what I'm getting at is obviously, these wells have a pretty steep decline rate in the first few years. But generally speaking, is that something that happens more typically earlier in the life compared to say what occurs in conventional reservoirs when you apply more application?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. This is Billy Helms. We typically -- the governing part will mainly be a natural field applications will be on how we develop each pattern. So as Bill mentioned earlier that the primarily goal would be go through and do a full-scale developmen
componenttext: Yes, Scott. This is Billy Helms. We typically -- the governing part will mainly be a natural field applications will be on how we develop each pattern. So as Bill mentioned earlier that the primarily goal would be go through and do a full-scale development on each and every lease with the latest high combinations. That's the number one goal and the pace of development from that will dictate us to when we roll out the secondary or the EOR process. But typically, as we -- I think we have a slide on the deck, I think Slide 4 that, that the time frame will be somewhere in the first 2 to 5 years. So I think that would probably be our initial guide. There's really no detriment that we see as to -- if you wait too long to implement it, it's going to be detrimental. We think it's a great tool for just continuing to contact the remaining oil left in the reservoir. Certainly economically, there'll not be an advantage to doing it earlier than later. But more importantly, the advance completions are driving probably incrementally more success to start with. So I don't know if that helps answer your question. But that -- I would say that it'll be somewhere in that first couple of years 2, 3 years of development.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely that does help. And I was just trying to gauge how this compares to say a refrack or something else in the life of the well. But great. And as my follow-up question, and, obviously, you all, I believe, try this up on the Williston basin on
componenttext: Yes, absolutely that does help. And I was just trying to gauge how this compares to say a refrack or something else in the life of the well. But great. And as my follow-up question, and, obviously, you all, I believe, try this up on the Williston basin on some enhanced opportunities several years ago. That may not have been as successful. And I know it may not be applicable everywhere. But can you compare and contrast what the occured then versus now? And versus that what you learned the Eagle Ford that actually should be transferred into the Williston?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The Eagle Ford, as I mentioned in the call, the primary -- one of the primary factors in the Eagle Ford's success is vertical containment. The Eagle Ford is very well encased and has good strong various for upward or downward growth which is key for
componenttext: Yes. The Eagle Ford, as I mentioned in the call, the primary -- one of the primary factors in the Eagle Ford's success is vertical containment. The Eagle Ford is very well encased and has good strong various for upward or downward growth which is key for the process. The Bakken and many other plays are going to be more challenged in that area. That's probably the key primary difference I would say leads to the success more readily to the Eagle Ford than many other plays.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

componenttext: And we'll move forward to our next question from Subash Chandra from Guggenheim.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is as you talk about this 50% efficiencies in 2016 and continued focus on ROI over growth. How does this sort of influence your desire to outspend in a normalized oil price environment.
componenttext: First question is as you talk about this 50% efficiencies in 2016 and continued focus on ROI over growth. How does this sort of influence your desire to outspend in a normalized oil price environment.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have no desire or intention to consistently outstand. So the number one goal this year is to balance our discretionary cash flow with CapEx. And then, of course, we're working on property sales to help us reduce net debt. And if prices continue to
componenttext: Yes. We have no desire or intention to consistently outstand. So the number one goal this year is to balance our discretionary cash flow with CapEx. And then, of course, we're working on property sales to help us reduce net debt. And if prices continue to firm, we have a lot of confidence that we're on the road to accomplishing that. We do believe that because we're seeing significant cost savings in the current drilling, we think that's going to continue. And any extra capital that we have from cost savings, we will apply to complete new wells. And that will be -- we're going to be disciplined. We're certainly watching the market to make sure that we're not in a temporary uptick on prices if the prices are more sustainable. But then we feel good about that, we will apply those cost savings to completing additional later in the year most likely in the fourth quarter. We want to enter 2017 on a growth level in an uptick. So we believe that we'll be -- we'll have the capital to do that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up is any update or guidance, for the lack of a better word, ranked exploration as we saw the last couple of quarters talk about the refinement of the existing portfolio, how your progress on new portfolio of opportunities?
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up is any update or guidance, for the lack of a better word, ranked exploration as we saw the last couple of quarters talk about the refinement of the existing portfolio, how your progress on new portfolio of opportunities?

componenttext: Yes. We have a very robust exploration effort on new plays. And so we have various plays the will be testing this year. And we'll see update you that when we have some meaningful results. And then we're also picking up acreage. It's been a great time to pick up low-cost acreage in places that we couldn't get acreage in the previous year. So we have an active program going on. Of course, we're very selective. We only want premium plays to fit into our capital program. So we're trying -- we're identifying rock that would lead that category and deliver those kinds of returns. So we're not shortchanging that effort at all.

componenttext: Yes, Doug. This is David. On the chalk. We drilled these 2 wells. We've taken a couple of course here and we've got quite a bit of log data to go with that. So we've really kind of mapped out the play and we're feeling pretty confident that we can move this play into kind of the premium category and have a meaningful impact to EOG. So we're going to go ahead and test, like I mentioned in my remarks, we'll test another 7 wells this year and kind of delineate the play. And then like I said, we'll go ahead move that into the premium in for account. So we will be developed along with the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. We'll watch for more details. My follow-up is I got the say as the own reservoir, you guys never cease to amaze us with the things that you're able to do. On this EOR's as an example of that, but it also provided us a bit of a challenge. So I'm wond
componenttext: Okay. We'll watch for more details. My follow-up is I got the say as the own reservoir, you guys never cease to amaze us with the things that you're able to do. On this EOR's as an example of that, but it also provided us a bit of a challenge. So I'm wondering if you could -- to the extent you can help us with some ideas of how you would think about fitting that into the portfolio. What I'm really getting at is is this an individual well situation? Is it cluster of wells? This is a minimum area that we think about? Anything you can help us in terms of flaming what the relative scale of this would look like once you kind of get going. And then maybe as an add-on, what proportion of your Eagle Ford today is kind of ready to go in terms of daily to move this thing forward?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. This is Billy. The second part of your question in the extent of the acreage that might be applicable to this. Honestly, we just don't know that this point. We do know that there are some areas that probably will be challenged to work economica
componenttext: Yes, Doug. This is Billy. The second part of your question in the extent of the acreage that might be applicable to this. Honestly, we just don't know that this point. We do know that there are some areas that probably will be challenged to work economically we -- but we are still early on that process and trying to determine how much of the acreage is applicable. We just don't know yet. Now the 32-well pattern is probably a good indication of may be what we'll look at the future. It may be subsets or leases that will dictate the size of how we develop going forward. So maybe you've got to think about it instead of a single well, it'll be groups of wells that will be implemented at onetime and not single wells. So we're kind of giving you some guidance on what we think the capital cost is and we try to boil that down to a single well to try to think about this and knowing that each lease will have different counts of well, maybe 12 to 20 wells on a given lease, say. And then the production profile we've kind of given a curve out there that maybe give you some insights what the Kim curves might looks like. The production response from this is pretty unique in the sense of secondary recovery projects it's probably only the process that gives you a rapid production response. You get a response in the first 3 months essentially, which is pretty fast. And then it holds pretty steady for a number of years. So that made -- and so that's probably about as much detail on how we see the -- how it would be rolled out. Again, the pace of development, I know it's a model economically. The pace of development is purely just going to be on the things that we learn from this next pilot and then our develop of existing units using our high completions. So we do expect this to increase that I would expect that do with increase the number of wells this year as we roll out the new budgets and ever-increasing part of San Antonio's capital allocation.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really appreciate the -- what you've been offered -- able to offer disclosures here in the EUR it's really a thought-provoking development. I wanted to ask if you could maybe add a little bit on what's driving that range on the 30%, 70% uplift versus th
componenttext: I really appreciate the -- what you've been offered -- able to offer disclosures here in the EUR it's really a thought-provoking development. I wanted to ask if you could maybe add a little bit on what's driving that range on the 30%, 70% uplift versus the original EUR? Because it strikes me as a wide range. And I'm wondering if perhaps part of the explanation is a function of the vintage or the density of the original completions that you're working with.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. This is Billy again. You're exactly right. I think that's a part of it. First of all, we're early in the process. So you have to remember that our forecast started out with trying to model -- trying to use simulation models to max our histor
componenttext: Yes, Charles. This is Billy again. You're exactly right. I think that's a part of it. First of all, we're early in the process. So you have to remember that our forecast started out with trying to model -- trying to use simulation models to max our history from the pilot projects and then forecast what the future production might be for these. So we haven't actually seen long-term production from a pilot over the number of years, it would take to demonstrate what the ultimate recovery is going to be, becoming to model that with some simulation techniques. I would say that our challenge technically -- so we're working on some enhanced models to better understand what the long-term production will actually be. So I think what just needs further clarification and tests from existing pilots that were -- and featured pilots to really not let down. And then you're right, I think the advantage of the completion. So we'll make a big difference. The new high-density completions we expect will respond better than some of the completions done several years ago. Our pilot projects to date have been older sell completions in large parts. So we expect improvements to continue to improve. I think there's upside there.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color, Billy. And then, if I could ask my follow-up on the Austin Chalk. I know that historically the way that's the play works a lot of the successful wells have a function of intersecting natural lectures I wonder if perhaps for your new
componenttext: That's helpful color, Billy. And then, if I could ask my follow-up on the Austin Chalk. I know that historically the way that's the play works a lot of the successful wells have a function of intersecting natural lectures I wonder if perhaps for your new concept it's the inverse of that. And if you're not avoiding natural fractures in the wellbore perhaps if you're trying to provide them in the simulation of the zone and in fact, if that's what you're trying to figure out here.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, I think you're on the right path there. What we've learned is here, where we're playing the chalk, as the oil is stored a bit different. That has been kind of the previous history of the play. And what that does is it all
componenttext: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, I think you're on the right path there. What we've learned is here, where we're playing the chalk, as the oil is stored a bit different. That has been kind of the previous history of the play. And what that does is it allows it to be a bit more predictable and also allows us to employ our completion techniques. So I think going forward, it's just going to give us a little more certainty on drilling repeatable high-quality wells.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, I might -- I'd like to add to that to -- to the kind of extent of what David said. I think the same kind of techniques that we're finding very successful in these other plays identifying the very sweet spot this a very light quality proprietary t
componenttext: Charles, I might -- I'd like to add to that to -- to the kind of extent of what David said. I think the same kind of techniques that we're finding very successful in these other plays identifying the very sweet spot this a very light quality proprietary techniques. And then they being able to keep that bit in a very small zone in conjunction with the high-density frac. That's really the key to all these plays and it's no different from the chop. And so we're just finding that we can identify a quality pay in the chalk. And we're very encouraged about that.

componenttext: Yes, again we're not going to give a lot of details on how much gas we're injecting. But the important thing there is that 2 things, I guess. One, is that we have gas readily available in the field and then two, with our large footprint there and the facility and infrastructure that we've been able to put in place for our field, really enhances our ability to move the gas around and get to this leases to take advantage of this the EOR process. It really helps position EOG uniquely to be able to take advantage of something like this.

componenttext: Well, it will be -- we're reporting production on a lease basis as we're required to do under the rail commission rules. And certainly over time, there are some things you can glean from that data. And we'll see. Honestly, I have not checked a lot of that data to see what it looks like versus what we see internally. But I think over time, you'll be able to discern what the actual results are. And I would expect you that they would become apparent in the future.

componenttext: A couple of questions. One, on the Austin Chalk. I guess, one, how perspective do you think this is? Like how big is that a sweet spot as a subset of your total Eagle Ford position? componenttextpreview: David, this is Bill Thomas. As far as our potential on our acreage. We're encouraged because we see data, lot data and test data on various parts of our acreage, they're encouraging. And so we have 7 wells -- additional well -- additional to the 2 we've a
componenttext: David, this is Bill Thomas. As far as our potential on our acreage. We're encouraged because we see data, lot data and test data on various parts of our acreage, they're encouraging. And so we have 7 wells -- additional well -- additional to the 2 we've already drilled. We have planned this year that we'll be testing some of these concepts. And so once we get those done and we get some results that confirm the production like we've seen, then we will be able to I think give people an update that'll be more meaningful on the -- what the scope could be. And then on the technical side of it. Let me let David kind of update you on that part of the question.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, like I've mentioned before, we have collected substantial amount of data. I mean, pretty much all the Eagle Ford wells that we've drilled have drilled down to the chalk. So we have a very good set of log data -- and seismic data. And like I men
componenttext: Yes. Look, like I've mentioned before, we have collected substantial amount of data. I mean, pretty much all the Eagle Ford wells that we've drilled have drilled down to the chalk. So we have a very good set of log data -- and seismic data. And like I mentioned before, core data to delineate this. So that's what gives us confidence. And as well, there's been other industry wells drilled. Some of the larger operators have not necessarily drilled very good wells. But some of the smaller operators have drilled some really good wells along this trend. But some of them have 300,000 to 400,000 barrels of oil in the first year. So these are substantial wells. And as I mentioned before Basin the data we have, we think they're very repeatable.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

componenttext: David, the technical advantage from a competitive standpoint is -- are -- I think our ability to recognize fees the pay zones and then target those pay zones. That is before we've learned on the other play there's a flight at Austin Chalk. So we're just taking this targeting -- precision targeting a step further in the chalk. And we think that's very proprietary knowledge at this point.

componenttext: A very quickly. This enhanced oil recovery process how sensitive it is to gas prices I mean, right now we're at all-time low. But what if one of these days, gas shoot up to 4 5 per MCF, how would the process work then?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I read, we certainly taken a look of at a lot of different pricing scenarios. But we've looked at it in the sense of what we're currently modeling and also incrementally, up to $5 gas prices and we see incremental benefits and good economics even up
componenttext: Yes, I read, we certainly taken a look of at a lot of different pricing scenarios. But we've looked at it in the sense of what we're currently modeling and also incrementally, up to $5 gas prices and we see incremental benefits and good economics even up to those levels. So our economic sensitivity is not really a factor of what we think gas prices could be anywhere in the near future. So I think it's going to be continue to be -- it'll continue to be economic even if what we see it can be a for seeable gas prices the future.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2016 First Quarter Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2016 First Quarter Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing first quarter 2016 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-loo
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing first quarter 2016 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risks associated with forward-looking statements have been outlined in the press release and EOG's SEC filings, and we incorporate those by reference for this call. This conference call also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation schedules for these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures can be found on our website at www.eogresources.com. The SEC permits oil and gas companies in their filings with the SEC to disclose not only proved reserves, but also probable reserves as well as possible reserves. Some of the reserve estimates on this conference call and webcast may include potential reserves or other estimated reserves not necessarily calculated in accordance with or contemplated by the SEC's reserve reporting guidelines. We incorporate by reference the cautionary note to U.S. investors that appears at the bottom of our press release and Investor Relations page of our website. Participating on the call this morning are Bill Thomas, Chairman and CEO; Gary Thomas, President and Chief Operating Officer; Billy Helms, EVP, Exploration and Production; David Trice, EVP, Exploration and Production; Lance Terveen, VP, Marketing Operations; and Cedric Burgher, Senior VP, Investor and Public Relations.
An updated IR presentation was posted to our website yesterday evening, and we included guidance for the second quarter and full year 2016 in yesterday's press release. This morning, we'll discuss topics in the following order: Bill Thomas will review our 2016 plan and first quarter highlights; Billy Helms and David Trice will review operational results; I will then discuss EOG's financials, capital structure and hedge position; and Bill will provide concluding remarks. Here's Bill Thomas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. EOG is becoming an even better company than it was just a year ago by lowering development and production costs and increasing returns. In the yesterday's press release, we announced 2 exciting developments that ha
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, and good morning, everyone. EOG is becoming an even better company than it was just a year ago by lowering development and production costs and increasing returns. In the yesterday's press release, we announced 2 exciting developments that have the potential to be significant additional drivers of higher returns and lower costs. I'll briefly highlight those, and Billy and David will provide details in a moment. Finally, I'll review our shift to premium drilling and how this shift is a game-changing event with significant long-term implications for EOG shareholders. 
First, I want to highlight EOG's development on the first successful enhanced oil recovery technology in U.S. horizontal shale. We initiated our EOR efforts in the Eagle Ford 3 years ago. Here's what we've learned since that time. Number one, geology matters. The Eagle Ford is unique. The same geologic characteristic that make the Eagle Ford prolific and primary development also make it unique for enhanced oil recovery. That EOR process we are using to produce incremental oil out of the Eagle Ford is not necessarily applicable to other horizontal basins. 
Number two, how you initially drill would be all matters. Secondary recovery works best on lease units that were developed using the best completions with optimal spacing. 
Finally, returns matter. We figured out how to execute EOR economically. The process can be implemented at rates of return that rival our premium drilling and significantly low refining cost over time. 
The second item I will highlight is our discovery in the South Texas Austin Chalk. The turn discovery is loaded as many operators have been drilling the chalk for years with varying degrees of success. Perhaps a more accurate characterization is that we discovered a new geologic concept in an existing play. Our team at EOG has cracked the code on how to make our particular footprint in the Austin Chalk a top-tier horizontal play earning returns on par with the Eagle Ford, Permian and Bakken. The third item I would like to review is EOG's shift to premium drilling this year. This shift is a game-changer with significant long-term implications. I will cover those implications in a moment. But first, let's review what we mean by premium. 
Premium inventory is defined as drilling locations that generate at least 30% direct after-tax rate of return at $40 oil. Here's a few more clarifying points regarding this inventory. First, 30% return is not an average. It's a minimum. Second, 30% was established as the minimum direct return to ensure that when indirect costs are included, the drilling program are in healthy full cycle returns. Third, we fully expect to more than replace our drilling inventory with new premium locations every year. Therefore, this is the most -- and this is the most important point, our shift to premium is permanent and not simply a temporary high-grading process in a low-commodity price environment. So 2016 will mark the point of time when EOG made a significant permanent shift in its drilling program. There are many long-term implications for that shift. The first is superior capital discipline. Premium drilling sets a new higher standard for capital allocation within the company. The second is a large capital efficiency gain. We do not need 50 rigs drilling thousands of wells per year. It will take far less capital for growth production at strong double-digit rates. The third implication is we can return the triple-digit direct rates of return with oil as low as $60 per barrel. And if history is any indication, we will continue to post the oil price needed for triple-digit returns even low. And finally, premium drilling extends our lead as the low cost horizontal oil reserve. As I outlined, our permanent shift to premium drilling this year is a game-changing event for EOG. Yesterday's announcement regarding our enhanced oil recovery success in the Eagle Ford and our Austin Chalk drilling success are 2 more technical and operational achievements that will help us reach our long-term goal of being one of the lower-cost producers in the global oil market. Now I'll turn it over to Billy Helms to discuss our exciting results from enhanced oil recovery in the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Three years ago, we initiated an effort to test EOR using gas injection in horizontal shale. Results from lab experiments indicated that the process was technically feasible, but the economics and operational execution were going to be chall
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Three years ago, we initiated an effort to test EOR using gas injection in horizontal shale. Results from lab experiments indicated that the process was technically feasible, but the economics and operational execution were going to be challenged without some creative problem-solving. Our EOR team has only saw the problem. They demonstrated returns that are competitive with our premium drilling program. The EOR process we developed is highly proprietary and this limits the amount of detail we are able to disclose. However, I will share several reasons why EOG is uniquely positioned to achieve a successful outcome. As Bill mentioned earlier, the geological setting is important. We have long discussed the competent barriers that intakes at Eagle Ford and provide vertical containment for completions. This unique feature allows plays -- also plays a significant role in keeping the injection in contact with the targeted reservoir. The injected gas is thus able to become miscible, with the oil in the reservoir and subsequently drive incremental oil recovery. EOG's acreage position is situated in the optimal thermal maturity of the play to maximize oil recovery. Being in the oil window has provided many benefits during the primary development, but it's also important for the EOR process acreage that is too far downdip or updip in the play may not benefit us greatly. The EOR economics are significantly enhanced by the scale out of EOG's footprint in the play. The infrastructure and facilities that are utilized during primary development across the field are key to being able to operationally execute the EOR process thus providing a significant economic benefit. These reasons are the keys to the process of success and are why EOG -- why that we believe EOR will not be a blanket application across the Eagle Ford or necessarily applicable to other horizontal shale plays. We have not yet determined how much the EOG's acreage will benefit from EOR or what the overall resource potential may be. The 4 pilot projects have tested different geographic and geologic settings, each proving the concept successful. But further definition and time will be needed to assess the applicability and overall benefit across EOG's acreage position. 
Here are some of the key takeaways regarding the economics and recovery potential. One, this EOR technique is not capital-intensive. There is no incremental drilling required for capital cost to average approximately $1 million per well. Two, the operating costs are low. The process makes use of produced gas readily available to the field, and there are few other incremental operating costs. Three, EOR may have significant effect on our long-term Eagle Ford base production profile, unlock typical secondary recovery projects, the production response occurs quickly within the first 2 to 3 months and hold steady for longer. Four, the combination of lower operating costs and steady production delivers a return profile that complements our primary drilling program. Primarily drilling delivers high returns and short paybacks. Our EOR pilots have a much different profile characterized by modest upfront capital investment that delivers a longer annuity of incremental oil production and strong cash flow. The rate of return is still on par with primary drilling. But for each dollar invested, EOR delivers at least twice the net present value created as primary drilling. Finally, our models indicate that this process will increase recovery by 30% to 70%. I want to emphasize these are incremental potential reserves, not accelerated production, delivering at -- delivered at potential finite cost of $6 per barrel of oil or less. We will conduct a pit pilot in 2016, and we will evaluate the results and review our acreage. We will determine the long-term capital production and earnings effect of EOR. It's important to note that while this is a significant technical and economic breakthrough, drilling out this effort will take time, and it is dependent on the pace of primary drilling and field development. Now here is David Trice.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Billy. Another exciting development on our South Texas acreage position concerns the Austin Chalk. In our press release yesterday, we published the results of 2 tremendous Austin Chalk wells, the Leonard AC Unit 101H, producing average of 2,715 ba
componenttext:
Thanks, Billy. Another exciting development on our South Texas acreage position concerns the Austin Chalk. In our press release yesterday, we published the results of 2 tremendous Austin Chalk wells, the Leonard AC Unit 101H, producing average of 2,715 barrels of oil equivalent per day for 30 days. The Denali Unit 101H was completed in April and its average production for the first 20 days was 3,130 barrels of oil equivalent per day. While the Austin Chalk is not a new play, historically industry production has been inconsistent from well to well. While good wells are possible, the performance and resulting returns are highly variable across the play. However, using proprietary petrophysical analysis, we discovered how to apply new geologic concepts to the Austin Chalk and drill prolific wells consistently. Much like the Eagle Ford, the chalk responds very well to EOG-style completions. Our high-density completions create complex fracture systems close to the wellbore significantly improving the well performance. Also like the Eagle Ford, the Austin Chalk benefits from the detailed work we conduct to determine the best target. The chalk can be as thick as 140 feet in some areas, but our targeting efforts keep the drill bit confined to the best 20 to 30 feet of rock. Precision targeting combined with EOG-style completions is now generating prolific premium level well performance. It's too early in our exploration efforts to know how much of the Austin Chalk is perspective of our acreage. The subsurface data and detailed mapping of the output field are encouraging. We plan to drill 7 additional Austin Chalk wells in 2016 and look forward to updating you with future drilling results as we learn more. In the Permian Delaware Basin, our recent activity has focused on the Wolfcamp oil window. Drilling the Wolfcamp generates excellent returns while allowing us to collect data on the shallower targets such as the Second Bone Spring Sand. During the first quarter, we completed a dozen wells with per well average 30-day rates over 2,100 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with approximately 70% well pad. The average lateral of these Wolfcamp wells is approximately 4,500 feet. Over the last year, we focused on increasing our understanding of the geology and maximizing well performance through better technologies such as precision targeting, high-density completions and better wellbore design. As a result, our wells are industry-leading as illustrated on Slide 8 on our investor presentation. Since January of last year, our wells have been twice as good as industry average in the Midland or Delaware Basin when normalized for lateral length. This is approach EOG takes across all our plays. We seek to first understand the geology; second, optimize the completions; and finally, enhance operational practices that maximize efficiencies and lower costs. 
Our next step for Wolfcamp optimization is to extend the lateral. Breakthroughs we made in wellbore design will allow us to apply EOG-style high-density completions to long Wolfcamp laterals. Longer laterals will enhance our highly successful Wolfcamp program and reduce our surface footprint across the play. In April, we drilled 2 7,000-foot laterals, the Rattlesnake 21 Fed Com 701H and 702H. These wells are too new to report at 30-day rate. However, the first 20 days of production are averaging more than 3,800 barrels of oil equivalent per day per well with maximum 24-hour rates at 4,200 barrels of oil equivalent per day per well. 
Meanwhile, we continue to further improve operational efficiencies and costs in the Wolfcamp. During the first quarter, drilling days decreased 14% from our 2015 average to 16.1 days. Also, total well cost decreased 8% to $6.9 million, more than offsetting costs associated with continued completion enhancements. In addition, in the second quarter, we'll begin using our brackish water supply for our New Mexico completions, with an anticipated saving of $150,000 per well. This new water supply, along with many other operational improvements, will allow EOG to continue lower cost and increased returns. On international front, we're very happy to report that our East Irish Sea Conwy project achieved first production in late March. We are currently addressing normal start-up items and running tests to determine the optimal production rate. Our full year guidance has been adjusted until we complete more testing. Here's Tim Driggers.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Capitalized interest for the first quarter 2016 was $9 million. Total exploration and development expenditures were $568 million, excluding property acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering syst
componenttext: Thanks, David. Capitalized interest for the first quarter 2016 was $9 million. Total exploration and development expenditures were $568 million, excluding property acquisitions and asset retirement obligations. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property, plant and equipment were $25 million. This compared to the first quarter 2015 total exploration expenditures decreased by 62%, while our total production volumes decreased by just 7%. We have maintained our full year capital expenditure guidance of $2.4 million to $2.6 million. At the end of March 2016, total debt outstanding was $7 billion and the debt-to-total-capitalization ratio was 36%. At March 31, we had $700 million of cash on hand, giving us non-GAAP net debt of $6.3 billion or net debt to total cap ratio of 34%. The effective tax rate for the first quarter was 34%, and the deferred tax ratio was 82%. For the period May 1 through June 30, 2016, EOG has crude oil financial price swap contracts in place for 128,000 barrels of oil per day at a weighted average price of $42.56 per barrel. For the period June 1 through August 31, 2016, EOG has natural gas financial price swap contracts in place for 60,000 MMBtu per day and a weighted average price of $2.49 per MMBtu. Now I'll turn it back over to Bill.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. First, a brief word on our macro views and how they relate to EOG's plans. The substantial reduction in capital investment by the industry in 2015 and 2016 is causing oil supply to decline in many producing regions around the world. Led by st
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. First, a brief word on our macro views and how they relate to EOG's plans. The substantial reduction in capital investment by the industry in 2015 and 2016 is causing oil supply to decline in many producing regions around the world. Led by steady declines in the U.S. and supported by strong gasoline demand, the market continues to rebalance. We agree with consensus that this process will accelerate in the second half of this year and into 2017. We believe that in the U.S., it will take a sustained $60 to $65 oil price and 12 months of lead time for the industry to deliver a modest level of growth. However, what is true for the industry in general does not hold for EOG. EOG is a low-cost U.S. horizontal oil producer. With our premium drilling inventory, we believe our reinvestment advantage is $15 to $20 per barrel lower than the average industry operator. When the market balances and prices recover to moderate levels, our leading asset quality, best-in-class technology and low-cost structure will become apparent with how quickly we can resume higher return oil growth.
And that may be the #1 question we received in the last 2 months. And or more accurately, at what price will you accelerate the -- and return to growth? Our first priority this year is to completely fund our capital program with cash flow and reduce net debt with property sales. We are in the late stages of negotiating on a number of deals and are confident we will be successful on many this year. We expect their collective impact will be meaningful. Our second priority will be to complete DUCs. We have managed our operations such that we have the capacity to add 40% more completions without adding any additional equipment from the service industry. We can respond quickly as supply and demand balance in oil prices firm. 
In summary, I would like to leave you with the following important takeaways from this call. Number one, our shift to premium drilling this year is a game-changer. We expect well productivity to improve more than 50% in 2016, which is the largest 1 year improvement in the history of the company. More importantly, this shift is permanent. Premium drilling will allow us to maintain a balanced capital program and resume high return oil growth in a moderate oil price environment. Number two, our enhanced oil recovery success is another example of EOG's ability to make significant technology gains. EOR has the potential to add meaningful long-term value to our Eagle Ford asset by adding low-decline, low-cost, high-return reserves. Number three, the new Austin Chalk results are encouraging for our South Texas acreage position. Time will tell, but we believe the chalk geology we discovered is substantially better and more repeatable than previous chalk drilling. Number four, last year, we said 2015 was a record year for improving the company. As we start this year, we are beginning to realize that improvements in 2016 may be even stronger than 2015. Our sustainable gains in technology and efficiencies are running at record-setting pace, and we are excited about what we can achieve in cost reduction and productivity improvements in 2016. Number five, our goal has always been to be the highest return E&P company in the U.S., and we believe we have achieved that goal. Our sites are now set on becoming one of the lowest-cost producers in the global oil market. We believe it's possible, and we are moving toward that target rapidly. Thanks for listening. And now, we'll go to Q&A.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan. This is Billy Helms. So as you mentioned there, the next step obviously is implementing the 32-well pilot. We're still learning a great deal about the process and what its overall impact will be. And primarily, the pace of development in the fu
componenttext: Yes, Evan. This is Billy Helms. So as you mentioned there, the next step obviously is implementing the 32-well pilot. We're still learning a great deal about the process and what its overall impact will be. And primarily, the pace of development in the future will depend on our pace of development primarily for the developing out the remaining leases and then how we roll that out. I would say that our pace of roll out, we expect to continue to announce new wells or bring new wells into that process in the coming years. And it will become a part of our overall capital allocation to the Eagle Ford that we do primarily each year. We roll out certainly our 2017 guidance on that probably in February. But we are very encouraged with our initial results. So it is probably a little bit too early to talk about how we're going to roll that out. We still have a lot to learn from our 32-well pilot. And then we still have a lot of leases to develop too.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, does the existence of the EOR potential later in life opportunity, does it change the way you allocate capital on primarily drilling, mean does it make the Eagle Ford either relatively more attractive or the black window versus the condensate wind
componenttext: I mean, does the existence of the EOR potential later in life opportunity, does it change the way you allocate capital on primarily drilling, mean does it make the Eagle Ford either relatively more attractive or the black window versus the condensate window more attractive given this new secondary recovery option?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evan, this is Bill. I don't think it changes it dramatically. We're focused on premium drilling in all of our plays and in Eagle Ford. That's what we want to develop first in our leases and that's where we're going to focus on really permanently from now
componenttext: Evan, this is Bill. I don't think it changes it dramatically. We're focused on premium drilling in all of our plays and in Eagle Ford. That's what we want to develop first in our leases and that's where we're going to focus on really permanently from now on. So we'll develop those at a normal pace. As Billy mentioned, the key is really to get those developed with the drilling and the completions in the most optimal spacing and to connect as much rock to the primary process. And that really enhances the EOR effectiveness as we go forward. So we'll move along both of them at a nice steady pace. And we'll just continue to learn as we go forward. And I think the EOR process will be much like the drilling program. We'll get more efficient as we move forward and we'll be able to lower cost, and it'll just become kind of a normal part of our investment in the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
