headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, on the EOR process, you've done 4 pilots and tested that on 15 producing wells. Was -- were the tests successful on all the wells? Or can you just talk a little bit about the effectiveness that you've seen thus far?
componenttext: Bill, on the EOR process, you've done 4 pilots and tested that on 15 producing wells. Was -- were the tests successful on all the wells? Or can you just talk a little bit about the effectiveness that you've seen thus far?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun, this is Billy Helms. Certainly, the -- in each one of our tests, we've learned a lot. I would say that without a hesitation, that all of our pilot tests were successful. Certainly, we continue to learn from each one. We started the project, rea
componenttext: Yes, Arun, this is Billy Helms. Certainly, the -- in each one of our tests, we've learned a lot. I would say that without a hesitation, that all of our pilot tests were successful. Certainly, we continue to learn from each one. We started the project, really, with some laboratory experiments on just trying to understand what the fluid behaviors would be. And that certainly was very encouraging. Then we rolled it out to a single well pilot and had positive results from that. And then we started applying it to more multi-well pilots. We had 2 4-well pilots and a 6-well pilot. And each one of those was successful. So the next step, as we've discussed, is to roll it out on more of a field scale model, which was this 32-well pilot, and we'll certainly continue to learn from that. But yes, each one was very successful.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just my follow-up. Bill, in your prepared remarks, when you're talking about the premium locations, you expressed confidence that you could either replace these premium locations from an inventory perspective on an ongoing basis. Can you just give us
componenttext: And just my follow-up. Bill, in your prepared remarks, when you're talking about the premium locations, you expressed confidence that you could either replace these premium locations from an inventory perspective on an ongoing basis. Can you just give us a little bit more color around that, what's driving that confidence?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun. As you know, we believe we have very sustainable cost reductions and technology gains. We've done it every year we've been in the business. And we have a lot of confidence, and we see a lot of upside going forward to continue that process. So a
componenttext: Yes, Arun. As you know, we believe we have very sustainable cost reductions and technology gains. We've done it every year we've been in the business. And we have a lot of confidence, and we see a lot of upside going forward to continue that process. So as we increase productivity through being able to identify better rock and use precision targeting and get even better with our high-density frac techniques, we believe that the well productivity will continue to increase. That would be one way to convert. And then we also believe that we have sustainable cost reductions. So 2/3 of our cost reductions during the downturn have been through technology and efficiency gains. And we do not see any end in that. So we're quite confident that efficiency and technology will continue to drive those costs down. And so we believe a large percentage of the inventory that we have in the Eagle Ford will be converted to premium. And we also believe that in the Permian and we believe we'll add continued premium in the Bakken and other plays, too. So we're very confident that our premium inventory will grow much faster than our drilling pace.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll move forward to our next question from Scott Hanold with Royal Bank of Canada Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll move forward to our next question from Scott Hanold with Royal Bank of Canada Capital Markets.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another question on the EOR process. And I know a lot of the stuff that you all did was proprietary, but when do you think it's the right time to actually put this application to work? So what I'm getting at is obviously, these wells have a pretty steep d
componenttext: Another question on the EOR process. And I know a lot of the stuff that you all did was proprietary, but when do you think it's the right time to actually put this application to work? So what I'm getting at is obviously, these wells have a pretty steep decline rate in the first few years. But generally speaking, is it something that happens more typically earlier in the life, compared to say what occurs in conventional reservoirs, when you apply a similar application?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Scott, this is Billy Helms. We typically -- the governing part will mainly be, in actual field applications, will be around how we develop each pattern. So as Bill mentioned earlier, the primary goal would be to go through and do a full-scale develop
componenttext: Yes. Scott, this is Billy Helms. We typically -- the governing part will mainly be, in actual field applications, will be around how we develop each pattern. So as Bill mentioned earlier, the primary goal would be to go through and do a full-scale development on each and every lease with the latest high-density completions. That's the number one goal. And the pace of development from that will dictate as to when we roll out the secondary or the EOR process. But typically, as we -- I think we have a slide in the deck, I think Slide 4, that shows that time frame will be somewhere in the first 2 to 5 years. So I think that would probably be our initial guide. There's really no detriment that we see as to -- if you wait too long to implement it, it's going to be detrimental. We think it's a great tool for just continuing to contact the remaining oil left in the reservoir. Certainly, economically, there might be an advantage to doing it earlier than later. But more importantly, the advance completions are driving probably incrementally more success to start with. So I don't know if that helps answer your question, but that -- I would say that it'll be somewhere in that first couple of years, 2, 3 years of development.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely that does help. And I was just trying to gauge how this compares to say a refrac or something else due to the life of the well, but great. And as my follow-up question, and obviously, you all had, I believe, tried this up in the Williston
componenttext: Yes, absolutely that does help. And I was just trying to gauge how this compares to say a refrac or something else due to the life of the well, but great. And as my follow-up question, and obviously, you all had, I believe, tried this up in the Williston Basin, some enhanced opportunities several years ago that may not have been as successful. And I know it may not be applicable everywhere, but can you compare and contrast what occurred then versus now? And if that -- what you learned at the Eagle Ford could actually be transferred up into the Williston?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the Eagle Ford, as I mentioned in the call, the primary -- one of the primary factors in the Eagle Ford's success is the vertical containment. The Eagle Ford is very well encased and has good strong barriers for both upward and downward growth, which
componenttext: Yes, the Eagle Ford, as I mentioned in the call, the primary -- one of the primary factors in the Eagle Ford's success is the vertical containment. The Eagle Ford is very well encased and has good strong barriers for both upward and downward growth, which is key for the process. The Bakken and many other plays are going to be more challenged in that area. That's probably the key primary difference that I would say lends the success more readily to the Eagle Ford than maybe other plays.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move forward to our next question from Subash Chandra from Guggenheim.
componenttext: And we'll move forward to our next question from Subash Chandra from Guggenheim.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is, as you talk about these 50% efficiencies in 2016 and continued focus on ROI over growth, how does this sort of influence your desire to outspend in a normalized oil price environment?
componenttext: First question is, as you talk about these 50% efficiencies in 2016 and continued focus on ROI over growth, how does this sort of influence your desire to outspend in a normalized oil price environment?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have no desire or intention to consistently outspend. So the #1 goal this year is to balance our discretionary cash flow with CapEx. And then, of course, we're working on property sales to help us reduce net debt. And if prices continue to firm, w
componenttext: Yes, we have no desire or intention to consistently outspend. So the #1 goal this year is to balance our discretionary cash flow with CapEx. And then, of course, we're working on property sales to help us reduce net debt. And if prices continue to firm, we have a lot of confidence that we're on the road to accomplishing that. We do believe that because we're seeing significant cost savings in the current drilling, we think that's going to continue. And any extra capital that we have from cost savings, we will apply to completing new wells. And that will be -- but we're going to be disciplined. We're certainly watching the market to make sure that we're not in a temporary uptick on prices, if the prices are more sustainable. But when we feel good about that, we'll apply those cost savings to completing additional DUCs later in the year, most likely in the fourth quarter. We want to enter 2017 on a growth mode, in an uptick. So we believe that we'll be -- we'll have the capital to do that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up is, any update or guidance on, for lack of a better word, rank exploration, as we've sort of last couple of quarters talked about the refinement of the existing portfolio, how your progress on new portfolio of opportunities?
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up is, any update or guidance on, for lack of a better word, rank exploration, as we've sort of last couple of quarters talked about the refinement of the existing portfolio, how your progress on new portfolio of opportunities?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have a very robust exploration effort on new plays. And so we have various plays of -- actually, we will be testing this year. And we'll see, update you that when we have some meaningful results. And then we're also picking up acreage. It's been a
componenttext: Yes, we have a very robust exploration effort on new plays. And so we have various plays of -- actually, we will be testing this year. And we'll see, update you that when we have some meaningful results. And then we're also picking up acreage. It's been a great time to pick up low-cost acreage in places that we couldn't get acreage in the previous years. So we have an active program going on. Of course, we're very selective. We only want premium plays to fit into our capital program. So we're trying -- we're identifying rock that will meet that category and deliver those kinds of returns. So we're not shortchanging that effort at all.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll move forward to our next question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll move forward to our next question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, the Austin Chalk inventory, I realize it's early days, but you haven't added to your inventory, at least not in the slide deck so far. What do you need to see there? When do you expect that you'll be able to give us some updates on that? And I'm jus
componenttext: Bill, the Austin Chalk inventory, I realize it's early days, but you haven't added to your inventory, at least not in the slide deck so far. What do you need to see there? When do you expect that you'll be able to give us some updates on that? And I'm just thinking about the development, again, realizing it's early days, but would you develop this concurrently, [indiscernible] these same pipes off the Eagle Ford? Or how are you thinking about that in terms of relative economics?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. This is David. On the Chalk, we drilled these 2 wells. We've taken a couple of cores here and we've got quite a bit of log data to go with that. So we've really kind of mapped out the play, and we're feeling pretty confident that we can move th
componenttext: Yes, Doug. This is David. On the Chalk, we drilled these 2 wells. We've taken a couple of cores here and we've got quite a bit of log data to go with that. So we've really kind of mapped out the play, and we're feeling pretty confident that we can move this play into kind of the premium category and have a meaningful impact to EOG. So we're going to go ahead and test -- like I mentioned in my remarks, we'll test another 7 wells this year to kind of delineate the play. And then like I said, we'll go ahead and move that into the premium [indiscernible] count. So it will be developed along with the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. We'll watch for more details. My follow-up is, I've got to say, as own reservoir, you guys never cease to amaze us with the things you've been able to do, and this EOR is another example of that, but it also provides us with a bit of a modeling chal
componenttext: Okay. We'll watch for more details. My follow-up is, I've got to say, as own reservoir, you guys never cease to amaze us with the things you've been able to do, and this EOR is another example of that, but it also provides us with a bit of a modeling challenge. So I'm wondering if you could -- to the extent you can, help us with some idea as to how you would think about fitting that into the portfolio. What I'm really getting at is, is this an individual well situation? Is it a cluster of wells? Is it a minimum area that we think about? Anything you can help us in terms of framing what the relative scale of this would look like once you kind of get going. And maybe as an add-on, what proportion of your Eagle Ford today is kind of ready to go in terms of being able to move this thing forward?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. This is Billy. Yes, the second part of your question there, the extent of the acreage that might be applicable to this, honestly, we just don't know at this point. We do know that there are some areas that probably will be challenged to work ec
componenttext: Yes, Doug. This is Billy. Yes, the second part of your question there, the extent of the acreage that might be applicable to this, honestly, we just don't know at this point. We do know that there are some areas that probably will be challenged to work economically. We -- but we are still early on in that process and trying to determine how much of the acreage is applicable, we just don't know yet. Now the 32-well pattern is probably a good indication of maybe what we'll look at in the future will be subsets or leases that will dictate the size of how we develop it going forward. So maybe you've got to think about it instead of a single well, it'll be groups of wells that will be implemented at one time and not single wells. So we've kind of given you some guidelines on what we think the capital cost is, and we try to boil that down to a single well, just so you kind of think about it and knowing that each lease will have different counts of well, maybe 12 to 20 wells on a given lease, say. And then the production profile, we've kind of given a cume curve out there that maybe give you some insights on what the cume curves might looks like. The production response from this is pretty unique in the sense of secondary recovery projects, in that it's probably the only process that gives you such a rapid production response. You get a response in the first 3 months, essentially, which is pretty fast. And then it holds pretty steady for a number of years. So that may be -- and so that's probably about as much detail on how we see the -- how it would be rolled out. Again, the pace of development, I know it's tough to model economically. The pace of development is purely just going to be on the things we learn from this next pilot and then our development of existing units we've used in our high-density completions. So we do expect this to increase. I would say we expect to increase the number of wells each year as we roll out the new budgets and it'll become an ever-increasing part of San Antonio's capital allocation.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move forward to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: And we'll move forward to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really appreciate the -- what you can offer or are able to offer as disclosures here on this EOR, it's really a thought-provoking development. I wanted to ask if you could maybe add a little bit on what's driving that range on the 30% to 70% uplift vers
componenttext: I really appreciate the -- what you can offer or are able to offer as disclosures here on this EOR, it's really a thought-provoking development. I wanted to ask if you could maybe add a little bit on what's driving that range on the 30% to 70% uplift versus the original EOR? Because it strikes me as a wide range. And I'm wondering if perhaps part of the explanation is a function of the vintage or density of the original completions that you're working with.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. This is Billy again. You're exactly right. I think that's a part of it. First of all, we're early in the process. So you have to remember that our forecast started out with trying to model -- trying to use simulation models to match our hist
componenttext: Yes, Charles. This is Billy again. You're exactly right. I think that's a part of it. First of all, we're early in the process. So you have to remember that our forecast started out with trying to model -- trying to use simulation models to match our history from the pilot projects and then forecast what the future production might be from these. So we haven't actually seen long-term production from a pilot. Over the number of years it would take to demonstrate what the ultimate recovery is going to be, we're trying to model that with some simulation techniques. I would say that our challenge technically -- so we're working on some enhanced models to better understand what the long-term production will actually be. So I think we just need further clarification and tests from existing pilots that were -- and feature pilots to really nail that down. And then you're right. I think the vintage of the completion, so will make a big difference. The new high-density completions we expect will respond better than some of the completions done several years ago. Our pilot projects to-date have been older-style completions in large part, so we expect improvements to continue to improve. I think there's upside there.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color, Billy. And then, if I could ask my follow-up on the Austin Chalk. I know that the -- historically, the way that play has worked is, a lot of the successful wells have been a function of intersecting natural fracture. But I'm wonderin
componenttext: That's helpful color, Billy. And then, if I could ask my follow-up on the Austin Chalk. I know that the -- historically, the way that play has worked is, a lot of the successful wells have been a function of intersecting natural fracture. But I'm wondering if perhaps for your new concept, it's maybe the inverse of that, and if you're not avoiding natural fractures in the wellbore, perhaps if you're trying to avoid them in the stimulation of the zone and if that's part of what you're trying to figure out here.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, I think you're on the right path there. What we've learned is, here where we play in the Chalk, is the oil is stored a bit different than it has been in kind of the previous history of the play. And what that does is it a
componenttext: Yes, Charles. This is David. Yes, I think you're on the right path there. What we've learned is, here where we play in the Chalk, is the oil is stored a bit different than it has been in kind of the previous history of the play. And what that does is it allows it to be a bit more predictable and also allows us to employ our completion techniques. So I think going forward, it's just going to give us a little more certainty on drilling repeatable high-quality wells.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, I might -- I'd like to add to that, too, to kind of expand on what David said. I think the same kind of techniques that we're finding very successful in these other plays, by identifying the very sweet spots, very best rock quality, with our prop
componenttext: Charles, I might -- I'd like to add to that, too, to kind of expand on what David said. I think the same kind of techniques that we're finding very successful in these other plays, by identifying the very sweet spots, very best rock quality, with our proprietary techniques and then being able to keep that bit in a very small zone in conjunction with the high-density frac, that's really the key to all these plays. And it's no different from the Chalk, so we're just finding that we can identify and have quality pay in the Chalk. And we're very encouraged about that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move forward to our next question from Bob Brackett with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: And we'll move forward to our next question from Bob Brackett with Bernstein Research.

componenttext: Bob, right now at this point, we're not going to give you a lot of details around the process itself or how we're implementing it. But we will say that it is miscible process. So you can read into that what you might. But we're not really giving a lot of specific details about how we're doing that or interaction between wells or those kind of things.

componenttext: And you guys were issued a patent for a thermal process for shale a couple of years ago. This isn't that process?

componenttextpreview: No, it's definitely not that process.
componenttext: No, it's definitely not that process.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And could you give an idea of sort of barrels per Scf in terms of how much gas injected and how much incremental oil you get out?
componenttext: And could you give an idea of sort of barrels per Scf in terms of how much gas injected and how much incremental oil you get out?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, we're not going to give a lot of details on how much gas we're injecting. But the important thing there is that, 2 things, I guess. One is that we have gas readily available in the field. And then two, with our large footprint there and the fa
componenttext: Yes, again, we're not going to give a lot of details on how much gas we're injecting. But the important thing there is that, 2 things, I guess. One is that we have gas readily available in the field. And then two, with our large footprint there and the facilities and infrastructure that we've been able to put in place for our field, really enhances our ability to move the gas around and get it to these leases to take advantage of this EOR process. It really helps position EOG uniquely to be able to take advantage of something like this.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: A final one. Should we trust sort of railroad commission lease level production? Will that be able to help us figure out volume, incremental volumes? Or is it just all wrapped up at the pad level so we can't -- or lease level, so we won't be able to see i
componenttext: A final one. Should we trust sort of railroad commission lease level production? Will that be able to help us figure out volume, incremental volumes? Or is it just all wrapped up at the pad level so we can't -- or lease level, so we won't be able to see it?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it will be -- we're reporting production on a lease basis, as we're required to do under the railroad commission rules. And certainly, over time, there may be some things you can glean from that data. We'll see. Honestly, I have not checked a lot of
componenttext: Well, it will be -- we're reporting production on a lease basis, as we're required to do under the railroad commission rules. And certainly, over time, there may be some things you can glean from that data. We'll see. Honestly, I have not checked a lot of that data to see what it looks like versus what we see internally. But I think over time, you'll be able to discern what the actual results are. And I would expect you that data will become apparent in the future.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll move forward to our next question from Pearce Hammond with Simmons Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: We'll move forward to our next question from Pearce Hammond with Simmons Piper Jaffray.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Austin Chalk, is your acreage already held by virtue of your completions in the Eagle Ford, since you would hold all depths above the Eagle Ford? And then are you leasing any additional acreage?
componenttext: On the Austin Chalk, is your acreage already held by virtue of your completions in the Eagle Ford, since you would hold all depths above the Eagle Ford? And then are you leasing any additional acreage?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pearce, yes, we would -- we hold Austin Chalk with our Eagle Ford production. So I guess it sits right above the Eagle Ford. And the second part of your question was?
componenttext: Yes, Pearce, yes, we would -- we hold Austin Chalk with our Eagle Ford production. So I guess it sits right above the Eagle Ford. And the second part of your question was?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

componenttext: Are you leasing any additional acreage?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016

componenttext: Well, as you know, there in the Eagle Ford, acreage is held pretty tight. So at this point, we're not leasing anything new on the Austin.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up with the EOR technology. What do you think this does to your base decline? It seems like it will cause your Eagle Ford base declines to moderate significantly over time once you apply this technology in full force.
componenttext: And then my follow-up with the EOR technology. What do you think this does to your base decline? It seems like it will cause your Eagle Ford base declines to moderate significantly over time once you apply this technology in full force.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pearce. I think that's right. I think the overall benefit in the long term is it'll help flatten the decline, the long-life decline from the field. We still haven't been able to quantify that yet. But we're certainly very optimistic that it'll certai
componenttext: Yes, Pearce. I think that's right. I think the overall benefit in the long term is it'll help flatten the decline, the long-life decline from the field. We still haven't been able to quantify that yet. But we're certainly very optimistic that it'll certainly be very meaningful to not only the individual leases, but over the field in general.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move forward to our next question from David Tameron with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll move forward to our next question from David Tameron with Wells Fargo.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One, on the Austin Chalk. I guess, one, how prospective do you think this is, like how big is that sweet spot as a subset of your total Eagle Ford position? And then as I start thinking about what -- and I don't know if you guys wil
componenttext: A couple of questions. One, on the Austin Chalk. I guess, one, how prospective do you think this is, like how big is that sweet spot as a subset of your total Eagle Ford position? And then as I start thinking about what -- and I don't know if you guys will talk about it, but what are you doing differently? What can you give us as far as or give the Street as far as confidence that this isn't the same Austin Chalk that's in everybody's head?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Bill Thomas. As far as the potential on our acreage, we're encouraged because we see data, log data and test data on various parts of our acreage that are encouraging. And so we have 7 wells -- additional wells -- additional to the 2 we've
componenttext: David, this is Bill Thomas. As far as the potential on our acreage, we're encouraged because we see data, log data and test data on various parts of our acreage that are encouraging. And so we have 7 wells -- additional wells -- additional to the 2 we've already drilled we have planned this year that we'll be testing some of these concepts. And so once we get those done that will give some results that confirm the production like we've seen. Then we will be able to, I think, give people an update that will be more meaningful on the -- what the scope could be. And then on the technical side of it, let me let David kind of update you on that part of the question.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, like I've mentioned before, we have collected substantial amount of data. I mean, pretty much all the Eagle Ford wells that we've drilled have drilled down through the Chalk. So we have a very good set of log data, seismic data. And like I mentioned
componenttext: Yes, like I've mentioned before, we have collected substantial amount of data. I mean, pretty much all the Eagle Ford wells that we've drilled have drilled down through the Chalk. So we have a very good set of log data, seismic data. And like I mentioned before, core data to delineate this. So that's what gives us confidence. And as well, there's been other industry wells drilled. Some of the larger operators have not necessarily drilled very good wells. But some of the smaller operators have drilled some really good wells along this trend. But some of them have cumed 300,000 to 400,000 barrels of oil in the first year. So these are substantial wells. And like I mentioned before, based on the data we have, we think they're very repeatable.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, the technical advantages from a competitive standpoint are, I think our ability to recognize these pay zones and then target those pay zones. That is, if what we've learned on the other plays, is applying it at Austin Chalk. So we're just taking th
componenttext: David, the technical advantages from a competitive standpoint are, I think our ability to recognize these pay zones and then target those pay zones. That is, if what we've learned on the other plays, is applying it at Austin Chalk. So we're just taking this targeting, precision targeting, a step further to the Chalk. And we think that's very proprietary knowledge at this point.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that color. Just one more follow-up. If I think about -- and if you covered this, I apologize, I don't think I heard anybody talk about it. But as far as the DUC balance and going into 2017 and I know some of the rigs are coming off contract,
componenttext: I appreciate that color. Just one more follow-up. If I think about -- and if you covered this, I apologize, I don't think I heard anybody talk about it. But as far as the DUC balance and going into 2017 and I know some of the rigs are coming off contract, how should we think about the way you want to manage that going forward?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Gary Thomas, David. And what we've shared before is we're just going to be completing roughly 270 wells this year, drilling about 200. So we'll be completing roughly 70 of our DUCs. You heard, as Bill said, we've got these kind of in inventor
componenttext: Yes, this is Gary Thomas, David. And what we've shared before is we're just going to be completing roughly 270 wells this year, drilling about 200. So we'll be completing roughly 70 of our DUCs. You heard, as Bill said, we've got these kind of in inventory, when we see prices in Peru, we have additional capital, this will be just a source of assets that we can develop rapidly to bring on production when it's justified.

componenttextpreview: Yes, very quickly. This enhanced oil recovery process, how sensitive it is to gas prices. Right now, we're at all-time low. But what if -- one of these days, gas shoots up to $4, $5 per Mcf, how would the process work then?
componenttext: Yes, very quickly. This enhanced oil recovery process, how sensitive it is to gas prices. Right now, we're at all-time low. But what if -- one of these days, gas shoots up to $4, $5 per Mcf, how would the process work then?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Irene. We've certainly taken a look at a lot of different pricing scenarios. But we've looked at it in the sense of what we're currently modeling and also incrementally up to $5 gas prices, and we still see incremental benefit and good economics, eve
componenttext: Yes, Irene. We've certainly taken a look at a lot of different pricing scenarios. But we've looked at it in the sense of what we're currently modeling and also incrementally up to $5 gas prices, and we still see incremental benefit and good economics, even up to those levels. So our economic sensitivity is not really a factor of what we think gas prices could be anywhere in the near future. So I think it's going to be, continue to be -- it'll continue to be economic, even at what we see could be a foreseeable gas price in the future.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to see if you can give us an update on your rig contracts. How many are rolling off at the end of the year? And more importantly, what is your minimum? Or what are your commitments for 2017? And to tie that in a little with the discussion here on
componenttext: I wanted to see if you can give us an update on your rig contracts. How many are rolling off at the end of the year? And more importantly, what is your minimum? Or what are your commitments for 2017? And to tie that in a little with the discussion here on EOR and DUCs, whether you can get to a point or whether it can be meaningful enough from your investment in EOR and reducing DUCs, where you can essentially have rigless growth in 2017?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Gary. We have 11 rigs under contract currently and that will decline to 9 at the end of the year. So it will really average to about 9, because we started with 15 rigs there in January. And then next year, we'll start with 8. And that will de
componenttext: Yes, this is Gary. We have 11 rigs under contract currently and that will decline to 9 at the end of the year. So it will really average to about 9, because we started with 15 rigs there in January. And then next year, we'll start with 8. And that will decline to 4. So we'll average about 5.5 rigs 2017. So yes, we will have some DUCs, but we'll have quite a number of wells that we'll be able to drill, and we've got quite a few of these patterns we would like to further develop, but we'll maintain certainly more than 5.5 rigs 2017.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then to follow up on both the DUCs and the EOR locations. On the DUCs, could you characterize how many of your DUCs would be locations you would regard as premium locations if you were drilling these wells now? And then on the EOR locations, c
componenttext: Got it. And then to follow up on both the DUCs and the EOR locations. On the DUCs, could you characterize how many of your DUCs would be locations you would regard as premium locations if you were drilling these wells now? And then on the EOR locations, can you characterize how many locations in the Eagle Ford over the last 2 to 5 years have been drilled in the area with the completion techniques where you could apply EOR right away if you wanted to?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first is a long question there. As far as the premium DUCs, roughly 100 of the DUCs are in the Eagle Ford. Most all those are going to be premium. We've got some there in the Permian Basin. They'll also be premium. The main thing here is when you loo
componenttext: Yes, first is a long question there. As far as the premium DUCs, roughly 100 of the DUCs are in the Eagle Ford. Most all those are going to be premium. We've got some there in the Permian Basin. They'll also be premium. The main thing here is when you look at it on a finding cost basis, our new drilling is roughly $10 a barrel oil equivalent. And when you look at the DUCs, having already spent the dollars to drill, it's probably in the $7 range. So those all look pretty darn good. As far as on our Eagle Ford and what wells have the modern completion to fit with EOR, by the time we get these patterns developed, a large portion, a majority of our wells, will have the more modern completion. So that's what Bill and Billy are talking about now and just mention, yes, we want to go ahead and further develop these, because we're still working on our spacing, and we need to get our spacing down there in the Eagle Ford. So with that, a vast majority of the wells will have modern completion, very fitting for EOR.

componenttext: Yes, in closing, the first thing I'd like to say is that we're extremely proud of all the EOG employees. They're doing an incredible job this year on resetting the EOG to be successful in lower price environment. The second thought I'll leave you with is that EOG continues to focus on long-term value creation by making sure that every dollar we invest today is making a strong return and growth should be a product of making great returns. So because of the tremendous technology and efficiency gains, the company has the ability to make strong returns in $40 oil environment. And this uniquely positions EOG to continue its leadership in high-return U.S. oil growth as prices improve. Thanks for listening and thanks for your support.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2016 Second Quarter Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Pl
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2016 Second Quarter Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing second quarter 2016 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risk associated with forward-looking
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing second quarter 2016 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risk associated with forward-looking statements have been outlined in the press release and EOG's SEC filings, and we incorporate those by reference for this call. This conference call also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation schedules for these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures can be found in our website at www.eogresources.com. The SEC permits oil and gas companies in their filings with the SEC to disclose not only proved reserves, but also probable reserves as well as possible reserves. Some of the reserve estimates on this conference call and webcast may include potential reserves or other estimated reserves not necessarily calculated in accordance with or contemplated by the SEC's reserve reporting guidelines. We incorporate by reference the cautionary note to U.S. investors that appears at the bottom of our press release and Investor Relations page of our website. 
Participating on the call this morning are Bill Thomas, Chairman and CEO; Gary Thomas, President and Chief Operating Officer; Billy Helms, EVP, exploration and production; David Trice, EVP, exploration and production; Lance Terveen, VP, marketing operations; and Cedric Burgher, senior VP, investor and public relations. 
An updated IR presentation was posted to our website yesterday evening, and we included guidance for the first quarter and full year 2016 in yesterday's press release. This morning, we'll discuss topics in the following order: Bill Thomas will review our shift to premium drilling and the long-term outlook we introduced in yesterday's press release; Billy Helms and David Trice will give notable achievements in select plays; I will then discuss EOG's financials and capital structure; and Bill will provide concluding remarks. 
Here's Bill Thomas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Good morning, everyone. EOG goal during this downturn has been squarely focused on resetting the company to be successful at our low commodity price environment. We are focused on lower operational cost and achieving a strong return on capita
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Good morning, everyone. EOG goal during this downturn has been squarely focused on resetting the company to be successful at our low commodity price environment. We are focused on lower operational cost and achieving a strong return on capital invested in a $40 [ph] oil environment. Our goal is to continue to be the leader -- U.S. leader in investment returns and be competitive with the lowest-cost producers in the global oil market. 
On this call this morning, we have important updates that highlight significant progress towards reaching our goals. 
First, per unit lease operating costs decreased by 27% in the first half of 2016 versus 2015, and per unit cash operating cost in the first half are down 15% compared to full year 2015 and 30% below 2014 levels. Second, with outstanding capital efficiency gains, we exceeded the high end of our second quarter U.S. oil production target and worked on increasing our full year U.S. oil forecast by 2% without increasing CapEx guidance. Third, we have increased our premium inventory by 34% and increased our premium reserve potential by a whopping 75%. And fourth, we closed on $425 million of noncore property sales this year. Along with maintaining our strong balance sheet, we are upgrading our portfolio by investing in high return premium assets.  
As a reminder, our premium well as defined by an after-tax direct order return of at least 30% at $40 oil. We believe this metric makes EOG unique in the U.S. when it comes to quality of inventory and investment returns. There are a few additional points regarding this definition of premium that I want to be sure are very clear. Number one, 30% is a minimum return. This means the average return for premium drilling inventory is clearly higher; number two, 30% was selected as a minimum so that the fully-loaded investment, including all indirect cost, generates a healthy all-in corporate rate of return; number three, 30% at $40 oil is the premium benchmark regardless of what the prevailing market price for oil is. Meaning, if oil goes to $50 or $60, the returns quickly move into the triple digit range; finally, premium inventory is a return based metric. It can be achieved by cost reductions or productivity increases or a combination of both. Because our technical and efficiency gains are sustainable, we are confident that a large majority of our remaining inventory will be converted to premium over time. 
EOG shift to premium is a new chapter for the company. Premium drilling establishes a higher permanent standard for capital allocation and, therefore, will significantly increase capital productivity over time. This shift enables EOG to deliver high return, robust growth using far less capital at a far lower oil price, which leads me to another highlight from yesterday's press release; the 2020 growth outlook we provided. Due to the sustainable gains in well productivity and cost, we can grow oil production at a 10% compound annual growth rate at $50 oil. 
At $60 oil, our compound annual growth rate jumped to 20%. And most importantly, we can deliver that oil production growth [indiscernible] covering our capital expenditures and our dividend with cash flow, enabling us to meet our goal of maintaining strong balance sheet. As prices improve, we expect to incrementally reduce the net debt-to-capital ratio to our historical [indiscernible] of 30% or less by generating free cash flow and, to a lesser extent, through noncore property sales. While the shift to premium drilling has tremendous impact on EOG's returns, growth and capital productivity, the question remains, is this shift really permanent? In other words, can EOG continue to replace its premium inventory? And the answer is yes. The 3 ways we add premium inventory are conversion, exploration and acquisition. The first and most immediate way is through conversion. Conversion locations that were in the edge of a 30% [ph] total rate is the source of the 1,100 new premium locations we announced yesterday. Furthermore, we have much more inventory on the merger conversion. I am [indiscernible] lowering cost in most cases, both, we expect most of our current nonpremium inventory at the top basins to be converted to premium overtime. Improvements to well productivity and cost savings are ongoing and never-ending. In a moment, Billy Helms and David Trice will talk more about how productivity improvements, cost reductions and longer laterals will add to premium inventory
The second way we add premium inventory is through exploration. EOG is a leader in organic exploration growth because in our core, we are an exploration-driven company. In this lower commodity price environment, we have not stopped looking. With EOG's decentralized structure, we have 6 [ph] experienced exploration team for the U.S., generating new ideas with our client leases and developing new plays. EOG is a prospect-generating machine and our shift to premium has not slowed that effort down. In fact, it has enhanced the return hurdle by which new plays are evaluating. 
The third way we expect to add premium inventory is through targeted bolt-on acquisitions. Due to the current low commodity price environment, we are actively pursuing opportunities to capture top-tier acreage. We were successful in for such transactions in the Delaware Basin last year and are optimistic we can execute on more through this down cycle. And I'm confident we can return to premium level drilling in the year [ph] through conversion, exploration and acquisition. And as I said last quarter, this shift to premium drilling is a permanent and it's a game-changing event for EOG. 
Now I'll turn it over to Billy Helms to discuss Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As highlighted in the press release yesterday, we added 390 net locations to our Eagle Ford premium inventory. That's a 25% increase to our original estimate 6 [ph] months ago and takes the total premium well count in the Eagle Ford to almost 2,000 [ph] l
componenttext:
As highlighted in the press release yesterday, we added 390 net locations to our Eagle Ford premium inventory. That's a 25% increase to our original estimate 6 [ph] months ago and takes the total premium well count in the Eagle Ford to almost 2,000 [ph] locations. 10,000 [ph] locations represents 10 years of premium, high-returned drilling. What's more, there are at least 2,000 [ph] more Eagle Ford locations that are on the verge of premium designation. 
To convert these locations, we only need to reduce current well cost by 10% or improve EURs by 10%.  Slide 11 of our investor presentation illustrates this. By making small, very attainable improvements, we can add another 10 years of premium high return Eagle Ford inventory from our existing acreage. I'm confident we will make this conversion over time. 
One of the ways we convert locations to premium is by drilling longer laterals. Our success in the Western Eagle Ford, as illustrated on Slide 9, is a good example. The trick with longer laterals is to maintain or preferably enhance productivity per foot of lateral. Due to the engineering breakthroughs and EOG's completion design, we have gone out as far as 2 miles with no degradation in productivity per foot. 
While longer laterals are one source of future premium inventory, 2 more significant sources will be EOG focus on performance improvement through advancing our technical understanding and lowering cost. On the technical side, geological and geophysical advancements enable us to refine our precision targeting efforts. For example, we are determining where there may be multiple Eagle Ford targets to support drilling and W pattern. We are also working to understand where the upper Eagle Ford is perspective. While the perspective area for the upper Eagle Ford is geographically limited, there are some sweet spots that may contribute premium well locations.  
Finally, as we discussed last quarter, we will be completing 7 additional Austin Chalk wells and continue to delineate the play and understand its full potential. 
On the cost side, we are finding creative ways to drive cost down further. We are drilling more wells per pad with  more efficient rigs designed for bad drilling. The rig design allows for simultaneous operations such as conducting drilling and cementing operations on multiple wells at the same time, reducing both time and cost. On the completion side, we continue to optimize propane schedules and stage links, reduce cost for items like sand and chemicals, while maintaining the EOG high-density completion process. Our continuing focus on every facet of our operations has allowed us to drop Eagle Ford total well cost another 11% year-to-date to $5.1 million. Also, we continue to be encouraged with our enhanced oil recovery for EOR projects. As a reminder, the process is highly economic and provides another way to create premium inventory. It not only increases the recovery, but also provides a means to flatten the field production decline. 
Finally, I'll draw your attention to Slide 23. We added another line to the chart representing 2016 [ph] year-to-date cumulative production. Year after year, we improve our well productivity in the Eagle Ford. Much of this year's increase can be attributed to our shift to premium drilling. However, as Slide 5 illustrates, just 60% of our 2016 drilling program is premium, so we expect to see this chart show improvement for many years to come. 
And here's David Trice.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Billy. Like the Eagle Ford, the Delaware Basin also added its premium drilling inventory. 520 net locations were added across all 3 plays, the Wolfcamp, Second Bone Spring and Leonard. The new premium total now stands at more than 1,700 locations.
componenttext:
Thanks, Billy. Like the Eagle Ford, the Delaware Basin also added its premium drilling inventory. 520 net locations were added across all 3 plays, the Wolfcamp, Second Bone Spring and Leonard. The new premium total now stands at more than 1,700 locations. That's almost 20 years of premium high return drilling. In the Delaware Basin, the main driver of premium additions was improvement in well productivity through better targeting and completions. For example, Slide 7 of the investor presentation shows EOG's 2016 Wolfcamp oil wells produced more than 200,000 barrels equivalent on average on the first 180 days. That's a 17% increase in 180-day cumulative oil production over wells in our 2015 [ph] program. More importantly, it shows a 45% uplift over a typical 750 MBoe well, which is the gross per well EUR given our last Wolfcamp update. 
Finally, it's worth noting that the data in this chart is normalized for 4,500-foot laterals, meaning EOG's 4,500-foot laterals in the Delaware Basin are as good or better than 10,000-foot laterals in the Midland Basin. In addition to productivity gains, longer laterals in the Delaware Basin are another way we've added premium locations to the Wolfcamp as well as in the other 2 plays. Innovations made to wellbore design in the last 6 months allow us to grow longer [indiscernible] high-density completions so that we do not sacrifice long-term reserves. The new design will allow us to maintain higher recovery rates on the longer laterals while lowering costs and increasing returns. 16 gross Wolfcamp oil and combo wells were brought online in the second quarter with an average 30-day rate of more than 2,400 barrels of oil equivalent per day and an average lateral length of 6,500 feet. These are industry-leading Wolfcamp results regardless of operator or basin as shown on Slide 8 of our investor presentation. EOG's expecting to complete 70 [ph] Wolfcamp wells in 2016. 
While the effort in the last couple of years had clearly been focused on the Wolfcamp, we have been able to collect a tremendous amount of data on all of the shallower targets such as the Second Bone Spring and the Leonard Shale. Despite limited drilling this year, results in the Second Bone Spring have also been impressive. 90-day cumulative production has increased 27% over 2015 wells and 60% better than a typical 500 MBoe well. The Second Bone Spring tends to be more stratigraphically  complex, so additional data we collect from drilling Wolfcamp wells has aided in  much better targeting, longer laterals and more premium wells. We expect similar or better uplift to our Leonard shale result in a go-forward basis. 
In the Rockies, we've had great success in the Powder River Basin and Wyoming DJ Basin. As announced in our press release yesterday, we drilled 3 Turner wells last quarter that averaged almost 2,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with [indiscernible] well cost which include drilling, completion and unleashed facilities averaged $5.4 million for a 6,500-foot laterals down from $6.5 million in 2015. These Turner wells are incredibly economic at $40 oil. We plan to drill a total of 20 net wells in the Turner this year. When we conducted our first count of premium inventory in December of last year, the DJ Basin Codell and Wyoming was slightly below the premium threshold. Due to sustainable cost reductions and better targeting, we added 200 premium locations in this play. Currently, Codell wells cost $5.9 million for a 9,400-foot lateral. As noted in our press release of today, our latest Codell well produced approximately 1,400 barrels of oil equivalent in the first 30 days. We expect cost and well improvements to continue and are working to expand gas take away options in Wyoming. The DJ Basin Codell will become a larger part of our premium drilling program in the near future. 
In East Irish Sea, I'm happy to report that Conway is currently producing approximately 10,000 barrels of oil per day. During the second quarter, Conway was down to the issues of the Douglas production platform. While Conway wells were initially tested at daily rates over more than 20,000 barrels of oil, results from recent production testing indicate the optimal level production is 10,000 barrels of oil per day. For the remainder of the year, we expect to average about 4,000 to 8,000 barrels of oil per day to accommodate further tests and potential downtime. 
Here's Tim Driggers.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Capitalized interest in the second quarter of 2016 was $9 million. Exploration and development expenditures were $624 million, excluding property acquisitions, which is 49% less as compared to second quarter 2015, while our total production
componenttext:
Thanks, David. Capitalized interest in the second quarter of 2016 was $9 million. Exploration and development expenditures were $624 million, excluding property acquisitions, which is 49% less as compared to second quarter 2015, while our total production volumes decreased by just 2%. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $20 million. We have maintained our full year capital expenditure guidance of $2.4 billion to $2.6 billion. 
At the end of June 2016, total debt outstanding was $7 billion and the debt to total capitalization ratio was 37%. At June 30, we had $780 [ph] million of cash on hand, giving us non-GAAP net debt of $6.2 billion for a net debt to total cap ratio of 34%. Year-to-date, we have sold 425 million of assets with associated production of 45 million cubic feet per day of natural gas, 3,300 barrels of oil per day and 3,700 barrels per day of NGLs. Assets sold include Midland Basin and Colorado DJ Basin properties. The effective tax rate for the second quarter is 23%, and the deferred tax ratio was 214%. 
Now I'll turn it back over to Bill.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Now, I'll report on our macro views and how it relates to our 2016 plans. Even though oil prices have been volatile, our yields supply demand fundamentals have not changed. We believe $40 oil will not provide enough cash flow or investment re
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. Now, I'll report on our macro views and how it relates to our 2016 plans. Even though oil prices have been volatile, our yields supply demand fundamentals have not changed. We believe $40 oil will not provide enough cash flow or investment return to overcome the combined effect of production decline and demand growth worldwide. While EOG can deliver healthy  growth within cash flow in $50 oil, we continue to believe the U.S. horizontal oil industry as a whole needs a sustained $60 oil price and extended lead time to deliver a moderate level of growth. As we discussed last quarter, the sustainable reduction in capital -- the substantial reduction in capital investments by the industry since 2014 is causing oil supply to decline in many producing regions worldwide. As production continues to decline, the inventory overhang will slowly work off. The consensus view is the market will balance during 2017. 
For 2016, given the uncertainty of the covered commodity environment, we are maintaining our CapEx guidance at $2.4 billion to $2.6 billion. However, as a result of cost savings, we are increasing our well count to 250 drilled wells and 350 completed well. This is an additional 50 wells drilled and 80 completions above our original plan for the same CapEx. 
In summary, I would like to leave you with the following important takeaways on this call. Number one, we continue to reduce operating cost. We believe these reductions are sustainable and we have additional efforts underway for this future operational cost; number two, our shift to premium is achieving what we believe are the strongest investment returns at $40 oil in the U.S.; number three, our shift to premium is permanent. We are confident we can grow premium quality inventory much faster than we drilled; number four, we continue to exceed our U.S. production targets by increasing capital efficiency. We believe these efficiency gains are sustainable and give EOG a significant advantage as we enter the next recovery; and number five, we are maintaining our strong balance sheet through disciplined spending. 
I'll close this call with our view of EOG's future through 2020. There are 4 goals we plan to achieve. The first goal is to be the U.S. leader in the rate of return on capital investments; the second goal is to be the low-cost U.S. producer and, therefore, competitive in the global oil market; our third goal is to be the leader in Lower 48 absolute oil growth through 2020; and our fourth gold is to maintain a strong balance sheet through disciplined spending. BY achieving these 4 goals, we will accomplish our ultimate goal of creating long-term shareholder value, producing growth by consistently outstanding and drilling uneconomic wells is not an EOG's vocabulary. We firmly believe that growth should be the result of strong returns and disciplined spending. EOG's unwavering commitment to our long-term shareholders is the focus on returns first. The company is uniquely positioned to produce strong returns and higher return growth as commodity prices improve. Thanks for listening. And now we go to Q&A.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

[ph] It looks a little bit back end-loaded on Slide 14 and, I guess, my question is did that allow for faster turns? And what signals do you need to [indiscernible] to move towards these targets?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of course, Evan. The driver is oil price, and if oil prices improve above the $50 level, oil capital will happen and the faster we'll ramp up our activity. We're not limited on beginning out very significantly. We have ongoing operations and enough rigs a
componenttext: Of course, Evan. The driver is oil price, and if oil prices improve above the $50 level, oil capital will happen and the faster we'll ramp up our activity. We're not limited on beginning out very significantly. We have ongoing operations and enough rigs and equipment going now and the DUCs really help us off to a good start. But it is, as you can tell from the chart on 14, [ph] it's not 10% every year. So 2017, we'll start of incrementally at a lower rate and then we'll build from there as we go forward. And of course, as volumes grow, cash flow grows, too, so the process kind of multiplies itself going forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What drives the higher growth in the back end of the decade? Is that reflected the EOR-based decline management? Or is that an effect from premium locations?
componenttext: What drives the higher growth in the back end of the decade? Is that reflected the EOR-based decline management? Or is that an effect from premium locations?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The whole driver for being able to grow at these kinds of rates at these low oil prices is really the switch to premium and the lowering of the well cost at the same time. The productivity of the wells is just a tremendous uptick from where we were in '14
componenttext: The whole driver for being able to grow at these kinds of rates at these low oil prices is really the switch to premium and the lowering of the well cost at the same time. The productivity of the wells is just a tremendous uptick from where we were in '14. And so the capital efficiency, I believe, is more than doubled since that time. We did not put it in the outlook, we did not put any EOR investments in their or production response. So that's really not a part of the outlook that we've given you. Of course, the EOR is great capital efficiency is just as good as premium and we're working at it over time as is appropriate.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go through Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And we'll go through Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, it's pretty shaky, obviously, the formal change, I guess. I guess, the question I have is you could pretty much, assuming you write on the macro, you could pretty much see growth on  whatever pace you want, at least in the inventory. I'm guessing th
componenttext: Bill, it's pretty shaky, obviously, the formal change, I guess. I guess, the question I have is you could pretty much, assuming you write on the macro, you could pretty much see growth on  whatever pace you want, at least in the inventory. I'm guessing the 10% hurdle is not for your site record that's difficult to achieve. So what are the constraints that you see to EOG's growth aspirations? I know the people and infrastructure and maybe capital towards EOR or back to shareholders?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. The constraint with the -- I think the biggest one would be we don't want to lose the capital efficiency gains that we have built in right now, and so we don't want to go so fast that we're bringing in equipment in people are spending money and
componenttext: Yes, Doug. The constraint with the -- I think the biggest one would be we don't want to lose the capital efficiency gains that we have built in right now, and so we don't want to go so fast that we're bringing in equipment in people are spending money and drilling wells and really lose these efficiency gains that we've got right now. So if oil, say, with a $60 [ph] or $70 [ph] really quick, we could ramp up appropriately, but we wouldn't do it wait overnight. We couldn't do it overnight. We would have to build up the service quality and we would certainly want to maintain our efficiency that we've already built in. That's the one thing we don't want to do. Of course, we want to focus on our balance sheet and to get that net debt to cap back down to that, below to 30% also. So I will let Gary Thomas kind of chime in on that. He can give some color on that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As Bill said, with premium drilling, it's what helps us with the growth forward because it just requires fewer wells and would not be having to ramp up to the number of rigs that we have, for instance, in 2014. And another reason is because of the product
componenttext: As Bill said, with premium drilling, it's what helps us with the growth forward because it just requires fewer wells and would not be having to ramp up to the number of rigs that we have, for instance, in 2014. And another reason is because of the productivity by rig, you could look at exhibit 20 showing that. So we've got kind of a plan in place to be able to ramp up, to maintain our efficiencies and more than likely continue to reduce our cost.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: To answer your question on when we buy back shares, that's really not in our plans at this time. We're not opportunity limited. I mean, that's an important part of the process. Geologically, we don't have an opportunity and limit there. So we would ramp u
componenttext: To answer your question on when we buy back shares, that's really not in our plans at this time. We're not opportunity limited. I mean, that's an important part of the process. Geologically, we don't have an opportunity and limit there. So we would ramp up appropriately to maintain a discipline and to reduce debt at the same time.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, I appreciate the detailed my answer. Hopefully, my quick follow-up is just on the balance sheet. Clearly, there's going to be some assets that don't -- maybe don't make it into premium inventory. So as you now made this permanent shift, rather than
componenttext: Bill, I appreciate the detailed my answer. Hopefully, my quick follow-up is just on the balance sheet. Clearly, there's going to be some assets that don't -- maybe don't make it into premium inventory. So as you now made this permanent shift, rather than get specific, can you kind of quantify for us what impact from your base production do you think disposals could ultimately present? [ph] Because obviously, that will go down the implied rate there going forward?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, on the oil growth rate, I don't believe it's going to impact it significantly at all. The thing that we targeted this year are mostly gas and properties for sale. And as we go forward, they would either be kind of combo-ish, our gas properties going
componenttext: Doug, on the oil growth rate, I don't believe it's going to impact it significantly at all. The thing that we targeted this year are mostly gas and properties for sale. And as we go forward, they would either be kind of combo-ish, our gas properties going forward. So on oil growth, property sales shouldn't be a factor much at all.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is Pearce Hammond with Simmons.
componenttext: Next is Pearce Hammond with Simmons.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the helpful long-term plan. My first question is given the rise to completion activity, do you believe you have enough access to enough Texas-based finer sands? Or will you need to use more the white sands potentially requiring you to reactivat
componenttext: Thanks for the helpful long-term plan. My first question is given the rise to completion activity, do you believe you have enough access to enough Texas-based finer sands? Or will you need to use more the white sands potentially requiring you to reactivate our Wisconsin mines?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pearce, we have both available to us. We've been working on our own Texas mine and plant and expanding there as far as our capability as well as working on our Wisconsin plant being able to reduce cost and put in place improved transportation. So we belie
componenttext: Pearce, we have both available to us. We've been working on our own Texas mine and plant and expanding there as far as our capability as well as working on our Wisconsin plant being able to reduce cost and put in place improved transportation. So we believe that we have adequate sand and we believe we've been able to lower our sand cost as well. And we're seeing that helping our cost year in 2016. So we've got plenty of sand available. We feel like we've got most all of our resources available to us as well. The thing that's really helped us during this downturn is really been able to just continue increasing our efficiencies. And before, I probably mentioned that we felt that as far as our cost reductions maybe 2/3 for sustainable, but what we've seen here from 2015 going to 2016, we've lowered our well costs in all of our areas from 11% to 13%, and that's just through increased efficiencies. So those will go forward with this.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And then my follow-up, Bill, as you look at the nonpremium inventory, kind of big picture thought, is it -- does it make sense to divest more of it? Or do you need to hold on to some of it and let technology catch up to that so you can move
componenttext: Very helpful. And then my follow-up, Bill, as you look at the nonpremium inventory, kind of big picture thought, is it -- does it make sense to divest more of it? Or do you need to hold on to some of it and let technology catch up to that so you can move that acreage into the premium category? So just want to get your big picture thoughts on how you view with that nonpremium inventory.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pearce. I will let Billy address that. Billy Helms.
componenttext: Yes, Pearce. I will let Billy address that. Billy Helms.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pearce. So in our inventory, as we continue to demonstrate, we can add more and more to our premium inventory. There are some of the inventory that may never make it to that, so we're looking at what options are best to bring that value forward, whet
componenttext: Yes, Pearce. So in our inventory, as we continue to demonstrate, we can add more and more to our premium inventory. There are some of the inventory that may never make it to that, so we're looking at what options are best to bring that value forward, whether it's monetize that property or produce of that for a period of time for whatever the optionality is. We have a tremendous amount of flexibility. We have estimated some properties yet to be put on the market, so we'll just be opportunistic in that approach and evaluate each 1 independently. We have and we've considered any of those volumes, as Bill said, in our 4-year or 5-year plan. And so as you mentioned, there'll be mostly gas or gas combo type place, so it really won't affect oil production guidance if any.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now go to Subash Chandra with Guggenheim.
componenttext: And we'll now go to Subash Chandra with Guggenheim.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the question was in creating these premium locations, do you find the best rock gets better? Or are you equally successful in converting Tier 1, Tier 2 rock to premium?
componenttext: So the question was in creating these premium locations, do you find the best rock gets better? Or are you equally successful in converting Tier 1, Tier 2 rock to premium?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, the rock quality is a very big driver on the premium. And the higher the quality of the rock, the better it responds to the technical advances we make in the completions, there's no question about that. So I think, one of the things that's not cl
componenttext: I think, the rock quality is a very big driver on the premium. And the higher the quality of the rock, the better it responds to the technical advances we make in the completions, there's no question about that. So I think, one of the things that's not clearly understood in the horizontal shale industry is that these sweet spots in these plays, especially in oil plays, are not very large. So capturing the very highest quality rock is extremely important and certainly something that EOG has excelled in and focus on over the years, and it really is the biggest driver of productivity.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up is how many completion crews you have active in your basins? And is there sort of a rig count to completion crews ratio that we should think about?
componenttext: My follow-up is how many completion crews you have active in your basins? And is there sort of a rig count to completion crews ratio that we should think about?

componenttext: This is Gary Thomas. We have now 8 completion units running. And we've got anywhere, 11 to 12 rigs and that's a pretty good ratio before as an average.

componenttext: Could you scale up the rig count without adding completion units materially?

componenttext: We could, yes, it depends on where you add the rigs. If we add it in the Eagle Ford, we would have to add fewer completion units, for instance, there. They're just so efficient after having operated there for the last 7 or 8 years.

componenttext: Maybe a couple of points of clarity. Can you talk about incremental 50 wells drilled in '16 and 80 completions, does that involve any rig additions? Or are you completing that with the existing rigs and crews that you have on hand?
