componenttext: This is Gary Thomas. What we've been able to do is just the tremendous efficiency improvements has allowed us to go ahead and do this with the same number of drilling rigs. We will be adding 1 or 2 completion units here through the second half to go ahead and take care of the 350 completions this round. That's all being done within existing capital, planned capital.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then maybe as we look at over the next couple of years, can you talk about the allocation of capital between the Eagle Ford and the Permian? Is there -- as you look into 2017 and 2018, what's the expected split between capital going to e
componenttext: That's great. And then maybe as we look at over the next couple of years, can you talk about the allocation of capital between the Eagle Ford and the Permian? Is there -- as you look into 2017 and 2018, what's the expected split between capital going to each basin? How long is that change as you look forward over the next 2 or 3 years? And is that reflective of the relative rates of return between the 2 assets?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we look into 2017 and forward, the capital will be about, about 45% will be in the Eagle Ford; about 45% in the Delaware; and then about 10% in the Rockies. That's kind of the rough balance between each one of those areas. And of course, the one w
componenttext: Yes. As we look into 2017 and forward, the capital will be about, about 45% will be in the Eagle Ford; about 45% in the Delaware; and then about 10% in the Rockies. That's kind of the rough balance between each one of those areas. And of course, the one we've increased capital most this year is the Delaware Basin, and that will be increased again kind of going forward. The rates of return that we're getting on the Delaware are just outstanding as the well results we've talked about today.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So today, is it purely a rate of return-driven exercise? Does the Delaware wells [indiscernible] the top or is it also a reflection of depth of inventory, infrastructure, things like that? Or is it just returns-driven?
componenttext: So today, is it purely a rate of return-driven exercise? Does the Delaware wells [indiscernible] the top or is it also a reflection of depth of inventory, infrastructure, things like that? Or is it just returns-driven?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's slightly returns driven. But I would say of those 3 areas, if we look at our current score card, the returns on all 3 of those areas are about [ph] equal. So it has to do with inventory and returns and, of course, operational efficiency.
componenttext: It's slightly returns driven. But I would say of those 3 areas, if we look at our current score card, the returns on all 3 of those areas are about [ph] equal. So it has to do with inventory and returns and, of course, operational efficiency.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: We'll go to Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I could pick up on the theme that you've mentioned a couple of times in your remarks about improved capital efficiency. And certainly, we're seeing that in space today with you increasing your completed well count or your completions by 30% and your wells
componenttext: I could pick up on the theme that you've mentioned a couple of times in your remarks about improved capital efficiency. And certainly, we're seeing that in space today with you increasing your completed well count or your completions by 30% and your wells drilled by 25% with the same CapEx. But I think, I get the theme that this is really driven by your shift to premium drilling, and I'm looking at that left half of the Slide 5 you have, where you laid out your plans for the next years. Is that ongoing shift to premium have kind of fair sort of weather to look at or how capital efficiency will continue to improve in '17 and '18? Or is it the kind of thing that you think you've seen the big gains and we shouldn't expect a whole lot more from this point forward?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that chart is very indicative of the way the capital efficiency goes. And I believe this year, it's about 60% [ph] premium. Next year, it's 81% premium, and I think from 2018 forward, it's 98%. So as we complete more premium wells each year, the capi
componenttext: Yes, that chart is very indicative of the way the capital efficiency goes. And I believe this year, it's about 60% [ph] premium. Next year, it's 81% premium, and I think from 2018 forward, it's 98%. So as we complete more premium wells each year, the capital efficiency will increase.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then if I could pick up on 1 of the big things from last quarter, your Austin Chalk activity, I think, I heard you mentioned that you're still excited about that play. Can you give us a sense, are any of those locations in your
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then if I could pick up on 1 of the big things from last quarter, your Austin Chalk activity, I think, I heard you mentioned that you're still excited about that play. Can you give us a sense, are any of those locations in your premium count right now, perhaps under the overall Eagle Ford heading? Or is this still kind of in the exploration bucket waiting to be promoted somewhere down the road?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, this is David. As far as Austin Chalk goes, like we mentioned last quarter, we're still delineating that play. We're still intending to drill 9 [ph] well spread out throughout our whole acreage position. And currently, we don't have any Austin Ch
componenttext: Charles, this is David. As far as Austin Chalk goes, like we mentioned last quarter, we're still delineating that play. We're still intending to drill 9 [ph] well spread out throughout our whole acreage position. And currently, we don't have any Austin Chalk within our premium count. So -- but that's clearly a potential for some upside there. Just like Bill has mentioned, one of the ways that we're going to add premium in the future is through exploration. So the well that we brought on and we talked about last quarter are clearly bringing them. So we're still excited about that play, but we need a little more data on it.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go to Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Billy, recently, [indiscernible] a bit less on the topic on the recovery rate. But given you are increasing our premium inventory in part because of productivity gains and longer laterals, I wonder if you can provide an update on where you see your recove
componenttext: Billy, recently, [indiscernible] a bit less on the topic on the recovery rate. But given you are increasing our premium inventory in part because of productivity gains and longer laterals, I wonder if you can provide an update on where you see your recovery  rates, particularly in  the Delaware and the Eagle Ford? And any opportunity from here for further technology and productivity gains to increase resource and premium inventory and overall recovery?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brian, this Billy Helms. On the recovery rate, yes, we've kind of got away from quoting what we think overall recovery rate is by zone, but needless to say, it's improvement. I think, a large part of that, a very significant part of that is what Bill
componenttext: Yes. Brian, this Billy Helms. On the recovery rate, yes, we've kind of got away from quoting what we think overall recovery rate is by zone, but needless to say, it's improvement. I think, a large part of that, a very significant part of that is what Bill talked about earlier is understanding the rock, our shift to better define what targeting is and then deploying our high-density completion process. it's really made a huge difference on the recovery rates. We really don't focus on what that recovery rate percentage it. It really doesn't help us understand our go forward models on how these wells will perform. So it's really hasn't been a focus for us. That's the color I would give to you is that they're definitely improving with time.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll ask innocently in a different way, then, since you talked about the targeting and enhance completions specifically. What inning do you think we're in, in terms of the impact that those technological improvements are having on  your productivity
componenttext: Maybe I'll ask innocently in a different way, then, since you talked about the targeting and enhance completions specifically. What inning do you think we're in, in terms of the impact that those technological improvements are having on  your productivity? Is there still a big gap even if they're not specific on the recovery rates? Is there still a big gap, where there's the opportunity for further use of the technologies to increase the company and are the benefits from target and enhance completions fully baked into your premium resource in premium acreage?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Bill. The targeting, we started that, I believe, in the latter part of 2014. And it's really in different stages and different basins. In the Eagle Ford, it's more mature there. We're probably still in the sixth [ph] inning, and I've been s
componenttext: Brian, this is Bill. The targeting, we started that, I believe, in the latter part of 2014. And it's really in different stages and different basins. In the Eagle Ford, it's more mature there. We're probably still in the sixth [ph] inning, and I've been saying this for years, but we're probably still on the sixth [ph] inning there, understanding what is the best target and working into our W pattern and our spacing patterns. So as we get more data, even in a very mature area like the Eagle Ford, we get more data, we continue to find out more about the rock and the section and we're able to discriminate and pit better rock all the time. So it's an ongoing process even there. In the Delaware Basin, we're probably in the second and third innings there. There is so much potential pay there and we're still learning and we've got a lot of data to gather. As we drill the Delaware wells, we're focused on the Wolfcamp for 2 reasons. They're fantastic wells, but another, too, you'll get to see all the Bone Springs, Sands and all the place above you, and so you're gathering data as you drill these wells and that helps with delineating targets and working in the [indiscernible] out in mapping. So each one of the plays have a different stamp, a different position on improvements. But we think there's really a long way to go. We're not anywhere close to the end of being able to make additional improvements and even that side of the business or the cost side, too. So it's an ongoing process and it's a very sustainable process.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go to a Irene Haas with Wunderlich.
componenttext: We'll go to a Irene Haas with Wunderlich.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following up on Delaware Basin, your inventory count of about 21 30, I'm curious as to -- for the Wolfcamp, are they mostly in Wolfcamp A and you're doing work on the deeper horizons? And are there more room to add flat locations without really adding mor
componenttext: Following up on Delaware Basin, your inventory count of about 21 30, I'm curious as to -- for the Wolfcamp, are they mostly in Wolfcamp A and you're doing work on the deeper horizons? And are there more room to add flat locations without really adding more acreage?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And yes, Irene. This is David. On the Wolfcamp, really, what we've targeted mostly there is we've got several targets in the upper Wolfcamp, so there's quite a few premium targets. And kind of like Bill mentioned earlier, we're still early in the Wolfcamp
componenttext: And yes, Irene. This is David. On the Wolfcamp, really, what we've targeted mostly there is we've got several targets in the upper Wolfcamp, so there's quite a few premium targets. And kind of like Bill mentioned earlier, we're still early in the Wolfcamp, so we still see quite a bit of upside there. But clearly, from the data that we show like on the Chart 7 in our investor book, we've made some big progress there. And I mean, these are clearly premium wells. As we go forward we're going to have to drill these drill more and more of them with longer laterals. So we could go...

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up question. I was kind of wondering how far are you along with your database? How many wells you have been putting in your sort of position targeting model? Do you use existing vertical wells, horizontal wells and core samples? Just trying to ge
componenttext: A follow-up question. I was kind of wondering how far are you along with your database? How many wells you have been putting in your sort of position targeting model? Do you use existing vertical wells, horizontal wells and core samples? Just trying to get a feeling as to how much more data you might need to really nail that perfectly.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of industry data out there, legacy log data and everything that's helped us with that. But really, what's going to drive it more than anything is as we drill the wells and complete them and gather the data over time, you'll continue to see s
componenttext: There's a lot of industry data out there, legacy log data and everything that's helped us with that. But really, what's going to drive it more than anything is as we drill the wells and complete them and gather the data over time, you'll continue to see some improvement there. I mean, just like you've seen, we never stop learning. We continue to test the limits. And so I still think there's plenty of upside on them, on the Wolfcamp.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Bob Brackett with Goldstein Research.
componenttext: We'll now go to Bob Brackett with Goldstein Research.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a high-level question and a follow-up. The high-level question is it looks like you've added, say, 34% to your net locations, but -- to premium, but the average EUR went up 75%. What's driving that?
componenttext: I have a high-level question and a follow-up. The high-level question is it looks like you've added, say, 34% to your net locations, but -- to premium, but the average EUR went up 75%. What's driving that?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really, Bob, it's just the combination of better rock and better completions. And now we're filling the longer laterals to that, too. So the well results, the productivity of the well increases as very, very large an incredible. I think, once there's
componenttext: It's really, Bob, it's just the combination of better rock and better completions. And now we're filling the longer laterals to that, too. So the well results, the productivity of the well increases as very, very large an incredible. I think, once there's enough of this data out in the big databases where people can analyze it and compare EOG wells versus the industry or really any other operator, drilling horizontal oil wells now, they're going to be very, very surprised and very impressed. We do have a 1 chart in the slide deck that compares our Wolfcamp results to other operators. I believe it's Slide #9 -- 8, Slide #8, so you might want to look at that. But the wells are just fantastic wells.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the follow-up is could you talk a little bit about the process by which your location moves or gets blessed as premium? Is that done by the asset? Is it blessed by headquarters? Is it statistical or is it sort of fixed on a map?
componenttext: And then the follow-up is could you talk a little bit about the process by which your location moves or gets blessed as premium? Is that done by the asset? Is it blessed by headquarters? Is it statistical or is it sort of fixed on a map?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a process that really is done in our divisional offices. So our decentralized culture that's focused on the details right there, they're evaluating the rock, driving the cost down at the same time and executing on the wells, they know their pro
componenttext: Well, it's a process that really is done in our divisional offices. So our decentralized culture that's focused on the details right there, they're evaluating the rock, driving the cost down at the same time and executing on the wells, they know their properties the best and they are constantly working and they are so focused on improving returns and improving productivity and driving down cost. So they're really driving this whole thing and it is an amazing performance that's going on.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there's fixed on the map, those locations are known lifelongs?
componenttext: And there's fixed on the map, those locations are known lifelongs?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, yes. The well count are absolute sticks on a map. They all have a well main, so they're not like a spreadsheet.
componenttext: Absolutely, yes. The well count are absolute sticks on a map. They all have a well main, so they're not like a spreadsheet.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Mike Scialla with Stifel.
componenttext: We'll go to Mike Scialla with Stifel.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, you said in your prepared remarks that the minimum 30% IRR for premium wells translates to a healthy corporate rate of return. Is there a minimum ROE you can equate that to? Or does that necessarily translate to positive earnings?
componenttext: Bill, you said in your prepared remarks that the minimum 30% IRR for premium wells translates to a healthy corporate rate of return. Is there a minimum ROE you can equate that to? Or does that necessarily translate to positive earnings?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we picked the 30% because when you pull in our full [ph] cost capital, which would be infrastructure, land, G&G and things like that, it clearly draws a return down to maybe 15%. So we would like to have kind of a minimum full cost, all-in cost, capi
componenttext: Yes, we picked the 30% because when you pull in our full [ph] cost capital, which would be infrastructure, land, G&G and things like that, it clearly draws a return down to maybe 15%. So we would like to have kind of a minimum full cost, all-in cost, capital cost rate of return of about 15%.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bill, you mentioned in your prepared remarks, have you seen no degradation in productivity per foot with these longer lateral links, I guess, is there anything specific there without giving away the trade secret? Can you talk about, maybe bigger gains
componenttext: And Bill, you mentioned in your prepared remarks, have you seen no degradation in productivity per foot with these longer lateral links, I guess, is there anything specific there without giving away the trade secret? Can you talk about, maybe bigger gains in size or something like that that's what I did that degradation in recoveries per foot with the longer laterals? And I was wondering if you -- you mentioned the Eagle Ford in the Delaware where you're going with a longer laterals on the Eagle Ford side, is that really confined to the western portion of the play? Or does it have any  application in the East as well?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Billy Helms. So on the Eagle Ford, first of all, well, both the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin, when we drill a longer lateral. We definitely want to make sure that we're maximizing the recovery. We're not losing efficiencies as we just drill l
componenttext: This is Billy Helms. So on the Eagle Ford, first of all, well, both the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin, when we drill a longer lateral. We definitely want to make sure that we're maximizing the recovery. We're not losing efficiencies as we just drill longer laterals. So we spent a lot of time or our operational groups have spent a tremendous amount of time trying to understand how to accomplish that. And the results we've seen so far have shown they've been very successful at maintaining that productivity per foot, especially when it results in a -- we're talking about EUR per foot, mainly. Certainly, the initial production can somewhat be dilutive a little bit is due to longer laterals and flowing larger volumes with no restrictions on jobs and service things, service facilities. But the EUR per foot has been maintaining a pretty steady pace, so that's really encouraging. Now I won't get into exactly how we're doing that. We do feel that, that is an advancement we've made internally and we want to keep that a little bit proprietary at this time. But on the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin, both of those are benefiting from that and we'll continue to benefit from that.

componenttextpreview: Paul, at 40, we would adjust our capital appropriately and we would be able to generate what we believe would be the best rates of return in the industry. That's certainly a big separator for EOG. But we would adjust our spending the cash flow and stay ba
componenttext: Paul, at 40, we would adjust our capital appropriately and we would be able to generate what we believe would be the best rates of return in the industry. That's certainly a big separator for EOG. But we would adjust our spending the cash flow and stay balanced and stay disciplined and hunker down and continue to improve. We are optimistic and we have hope. We're not there yet, but if that one day, we would be able to get our capital efficiency to a point where we could actually grow oil at $40 and we're working towards that goal. We're not there quite at the moment, but we're going to continue to focus on that. But our focus, of course, first has always been on returns and capital discipline and keeping the company healthy in that regard.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I did talk about that a little bit earlier. But we did but the benchmark of 30% rate of return on the direct side, which is the well costs only. We said that at that mark so we would have room when we put in full cost that would be land and seismic t
componenttext: Yes, I did talk about that a little bit earlier. But we did but the benchmark of 30% rate of return on the direct side, which is the well costs only. We said that at that mark so we would have room when we put in full cost that would be land and seismic to an infrastructure, then our capital rate of return, not ROCE or ROE, but our capital investment rates of return would be about 15%. Now that walks down, this is a long process, but that walks down to ROE and ROCE. But ROE and ROCE are trailing metrics and it takes years to get your base production to the point where we flex the returns that you're currently drilling. So it's a long process. It takes several years to get there.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It kind of goes along with the last question there, and that's also being competitive on the world market is it requires that we really be disciplined spending and that we just continue to work our costs down. And then as through just all the primary effi
componenttext: It kind of goes along with the last question there, and that's also being competitive on the world market is it requires that we really be disciplined spending and that we just continue to work our costs down. And then as through just all the primary efficiencies I've mentioned earlier, with us having the top rigs, we have quite a number of rigs in 2016 under contract placed a couple of years ago, high rates at just $26,000 to $27,000 a rig. Now those are rolling off and we'll be able to replace those, about half of those rigs were rigs that are in the $13,000 to $15,000 per day rate. So that allows drilling cost to be down around a 20% to 25%. Our tubulars, we've depleted our inventory here early 2017. And with the arrangements we have in place,  they'll allow those cost to go down in the 20% to 25%. With our sand, as I mentioned earlier, we've reduced our production cost, optimized the transportation, just all of those sorts of things will allow us to reduce sand cost by about 15%. Same with rigs, we have many of our frac leaves under long-term contract. Half of those are going away, which allow us to bring in the lower frac rates. We continue to improve those completion efficiency with faster completions, wireline downtimes, just our staged arrangements. Water infrastructure is continuing to be enhanced and it allows us to reduce our water cost. Our wellhead inventory is somewhat depleted and that will allow us to raise those costs into the 25% range. So all of this -- and that probably accounts to 50% to 60% of our well costs allows us to further reduce well cost going into 2017. Yes, we are still pleased with the vendor help service providers. They had -- we've got the top rigs, top frac equipment. It's a fast-changing technology, so we glad not to have ownership, but just to work and partner with the service providers to have outstanding service at competitive prices. They're not always the same providers, but they are the best and the most cost-effective in our arena. And the other thing is that our rig efficiency has improved such that yes, we do not have to have a number of rigs we have back in 2013 and '15. As a matter of fact, when we look at our 10% growth in the 20% growth, we think we'll be able to provide this sort of growth running somewhere between 25 to 35 rigs. The number of frac rates are required with the efficiency we're see you are going to be in the 15 to 20 frac fleets running for us. And that's only compact average growth with increased rates. By the time we get to 2020, we're talking, yes, that's the 35 rigs on the 20% growth. So yes, the downturn has allowed EOG just to enhance our overall operations. Our divisions are performing, specially oil, continuing to lower our costs. And during the ramp up, we would expect the same because if we look back and see what has been done by EOG in the period  that we are growing volumes 30% to 40%, we will continue lowering our well costs and improving our efficiencies. Now we expect our divisions to continue to do the same especially with all the [indiscernible] we have right now for further reduction.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2016 Second Quarter Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Pl
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the EOG Resources 2016 Second Quarter Results Conference Call. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Chief Financial Officer of EOG Resources, Mr. Tim Driggers. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing second quarter 2016 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risk associated with forward-loo
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Thanks for joining us. We hope everyone has seen the press release announcing second quarter 2016 earnings and operational results. This conference call includes forward-looking statements. The risk associated with forward-looking statements have been outlined in the press release and EOG's SEC filings, and we incorporate those by reference for this call. This conference call also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. The reconciliation schedules for these non-GAAP measures to comparable GAAP measures can be found in our website at www.eogresources.com. The SEC permits oil and gas companies in their filings with the SEC to disclose not only proved reserves, but also probable reserves as well as possible reserves. Some of the reserve estimates on this conference call and webcast may include potential reserves or other estimated reserves not necessarily calculated in accordance with or contemplated by the SEC's reserve reporting guidelines. We incorporate by reference the cautionary note to U.S. investors that appears at the bottom of our press release and Investor Relations page of our website.
Participating on the call this morning are Bill Thomas, Chairman and CEO; Gary Thomas, President and Chief Operating Officer; Billy Helms, EVP, Exploration and Production; David Trice, EVP, Exploration and Production; Lance Terveen, VP, Marketing Operations; and Cedric Burgher, Senior VP, Investor and Public Relations.
An updated IR presentation was posted to our website yesterday evening, and we included guidance for the third quarter and full year 2016 in yesterday's press release. This morning, we'll discuss topics in the following order: Bill Thomas will review our shift to premium drilling and the long-term growth outlook we introduced in yesterday's press release; Billy Helms and David Trice will give notable achievements in select plays; I will then discuss EOG's financials and capital structure; and Bill will provide concluding remarks.
Here's Bill Thomas.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Good morning, everyone. EOG's goal during this downturn has been squarely focused on resetting the company to be successful at low commodity price environment. We are focused on lowering operational cost and achieving a strong return on capit
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. Good morning, everyone. EOG's goal during this downturn has been squarely focused on resetting the company to be successful at low commodity price environment. We are focused on lowering operational cost and achieving a strong return on capital invested in a $40 oil environment. Our goal is to continue to be the leader -- U.S. leader in investment returns and be competitive with the lowest-cost producers in the global oil market.
On this call this morning, we have important updates that highlight significant progress towards reaching our goals.
First, per-unit lease operating cost decreased by 27% in the first half of 2016 versus 2015, and per-unit cash operating cost in the first half are down 15% compared to full year 2015 and 30% below 2014 levels. 
Second, with outstanding capital efficiency gains, we exceeded the high end of our second quarter U.S. oil production target and we are increasing our full year U.S. oil forecast by 2% without increasing CapEx guidance. 
Third, we have increased our premium inventory by 34% and increased our premium reserve potential by a whopping 75%. 
And fourth, we closed on $425 million of noncore property sales this year. Along with maintaining our strong balance sheet, we are upgrading our portfolio by investing in high-return premium assets.
As a reminder, our premium well is defined by an after-tax direct rate of return of at least 30% at $40 oil. We believe this metric makes EOG unique in the U.S. when it comes to quality of inventory and investment returns. There are few additional points regarding this definition of premium that I want to be sure are very clear. Number one, 30% is a minimum return. This means the average return for our premium drilling inventory is clearly higher. Number two, 30% was selected as a minimum so that the fully-loaded investment, including all indirect costs, generates a healthy all-in corporate rate of return. Number three, 30% at $40 oil is the premium benchmark regardless of what the prevailing market price for oil is. Meaning, if oil goes to $50 or $60, the returns quickly move into the triple digit range. Finally, premium inventory is a return-based metric. It can be achieved by cost reductions or productivity increases or a combination of both. Because our technical and efficiency gains are sustainable, we are confident that a large majority of our remaining inventory will be converted to premium over time.
EOG shift to premium is a new chapter for the company. Premium drilling establishes a higher permanent standard for capital allocation and, therefore, will significantly increase capital productivity over time. This shift enables EOG to deliver high return, robust growth using far less capital at a far lower oil price, which leads me to another highlight from the yesterday's press release; the 2020 growth outlook we provided. Due to the sustainable gains in well productivity and costs, we can grow oil production at a 10% compound annual growth rate at $50 oil.
At $60 oil, our compound annual growth rate jumps to 20%. And most importantly, we can deliver that oil production growth while covering our capital expenditures and our dividend with cash flow, enabling us to meet our goal of maintaining a strong balance sheet. As prices improve, we expect to incrementally reduce the net debt-to-capital ratio to our historical norm of 30% or less by generating free cash flow and, to a lesser extent, through noncore property sales. While the shift to premium drilling has tremendous impact on EOG's returns, growth and capital productivity, the question remains, is this shift really permanent? In other words, can EOG continue to replace its premium inventory? And the answer is yes. The 3 ways we add premium inventory are conversion, exploration and acquisition. The first and most immediate way is through conversion. Conversion locations that were on the edge of the 30% total rate is the source of the 1,100 new premium locations we announced yesterday. Furthermore, we have much more inventory on the merger conversion. By including well productivity, our lowering costs in most cases, both, we expect much of our current nonpremium inventory in the top basins to be converted to premium over time. Improvements to the well productivity and cost savings are ongoing and never-ending. In a moment, Billy Helms and David Trice will talk more about how productivity improvements, cost reductions and longer laterals will add to premium inventory.
The second way we add premium inventory is through exploration. EOG is a leader in organic exploration growth, because in our core, we are an exploration-driven company. In this lower commodity price environment, we have not stopped looking. With EOG's decentralized structure, we have 6 experienced exploration teams in the U.S., generating new ideas, acquiring leases and developing new plays. EOG is a prospect-generating machine and our shift to premium has not slowed that effort down. In fact, it has enhanced the return hurdle by which new plays are evaluated.
The third way we expect to add premium inventory is through targeted bolt-on acquisitions. Due to the current low commodity price environment, we are actively pursuing opportunities to capture top-tier acreage. We were successful on 4 such transactions in the Delaware Basin last year and are optimistic we can execute on more through this down cycle. And I'm confident we can replace premium-level drilling end year to conversions, exploration and acquisitions. And as I said last quarter, this shift to premium drilling is a permanent and it's a game-changing event for EOG. 
Now I'll turn it over to Billy Helms to discuss Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. As highlighted in the press release yesterday, we added 390 net locations to our Eagle Ford premium inventory. That's a 25% increase to our original estimate 6 months ago and takes the total premium well count in the Eagle Ford to almost 2,0
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. As highlighted in the press release yesterday, we added 390 net locations to our Eagle Ford premium inventory. That's a 25% increase to our original estimate 6 months ago and takes the total premium well count in the Eagle Ford to almost 2,000 locations. 10,000 locations represents 10 years of premium high-return drilling. 
What's more, there are at least 2,000 more Eagle Ford locations that are on the verge of premium designation. To convert these locations, we only need to reduce current well cost by 10% or improve the EURs by 10%. Slide 11 of our investor presentation illustrates this. By making small, very attainable improvements, we can add another 10 years of premium high-return Eagle Ford inventory from our existing acreage. I'm confident we will make this conversion over time. 
One of the ways we convert locations to premium is by drilling longer laterals. Our success in the Western Eagle Ford, as illustrated on Slide 9, is a good example. The trick with longer laterals is to maintain or preferably enhance productivity per foot of lateral. Due to engineering breakthroughs and EOG's completion design, we have gone out as far as 2 miles with no degradation in productivity per foot.
While longer laterals would be one source of future premium inventory, 2 more significant sources will be EOG's focus on performance improvement through advancing our technical understanding and lowering cost. On the technical side, geological and geophysical advancements enable us to refine our precision targeting efforts. For example, we are determining where there may be multiple lower Eagle Ford targets to support drilling a W pattern. We are also working to understand where the upper Eagle Ford is perspective. While the perspective area for the upper Eagle Ford is geographically limited, there are some sweet spots that would -- may contribute premium well locations.
Finally, as we discussed last quarter, we will be completing 7 additional Austin Chalk wells and continue to delineate the play and understand its full potential.
On the cost side, we are finding creative ways to drive cost down further. We are drilling more wells per pad with more efficient rigs designed for pad drilling. The rig design allows for simultaneous operations such as conducting drilling and cementing operations on multiple wells at the same time, reducing both time and cost. 
On the completion side, we continue to optimize proppant schedules and stage lengths, reduce cost for items like sand and chemicals, while maintaining the EOG high-density completion process. Our continuing focus on every facet of our operations has allowed us to drop Eagle Ford total well cost another 11% year-to-date to $5.1 million. Also, we continue to be encouraged with our enhanced oil recovery or EOR projects. As a reminder, the process is highly economic and provides another way to create premium inventory. It not only increases the recovery, but also provides a means to flatten the field production decline.
Finally, I'll draw your attention to Slide 23. We added another line to the chart representing 2016 year-to-date cumulative production. Year-after-year, we improve our well productivity in the Eagle Ford. Much of this year's increase can be attributed to our shift to premium drilling. However, as Slide 5 illustrates, just 60% of our 2016 drilling program is premium, so we expect to see this chart show improvement for many years to come.
Now here is David Trice.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Billy. Like the Eagle Ford, the Delaware Basin also added to its premium drilling inventory. 520 net locations were added across all 3 plays, the Wolfcamp, Second Bone Spring and Leonard. The new premium total now stands at more than 1,700 locatio
componenttext:
Thanks, Billy. Like the Eagle Ford, the Delaware Basin also added to its premium drilling inventory. 520 net locations were added across all 3 plays, the Wolfcamp, Second Bone Spring and Leonard. The new premium total now stands at more than 1,700 locations. That's almost 20 years of premium high-return drilling. 
In the Delaware Basin, the main driver of premium additions was improvement in well productivity through better targeting and completions. For example, Slide 7 of the investor presentation shows EOG's 2016 Wolfcamp oil wells produced more than 200,000 barrels equivalent on average in the first 180 days. That's a 17% increase in 180-day cumulative oil production over wells in our 2015 program. More importantly, it shows a 45% uplift over a typical 750 MBoe well, which is the gross per well EUR given our last Wolfcamp update.
Finally, it's worth noting that the data in this chart is normalized to 4,500-foot laterals, meaning EOG's 4,500-foot laterals in the Delaware Basin are as good or better than 10,000-foot laterals in the Midland Basin. In addition to productivity gains, longer laterals in the Delaware Basin are another way we've added premium locations to the Wolfcamp as well as the other 2 parties. Innovations made to wellbore design in the last 6 months allow us to drill longer, but still applying high-density completions so that we do not sacrifice long-term reserves. The new design will allow us to maintain higher recovery rates on the longer laterals while lowering costs and increasing returns. 16 gross Wolfcamp oil and combo wells were brought online in the second quarter with an average 30-day rate of more than 2,400 barrels of oil equivalent per day and an average lateral length of 6,500 feet. These are industry-leading Wolfcamp results regardless of operator or basin as shown on Slide 8 of our investor presentation. EOG expects to complete 70 Wolfcamp wells in 2016.
While the effort in the last couple of years had clearly been focused on the Wolfcamp, we have been able to collect a tremendous amount of data on all of the shallower targets such as the Second Bone Spring and the Leonard Shale. Despite limited drilling this year, results in the Second Bone Spring have also been impressive. 90-day cumulative production has increased 27% over 2015 wells and 60% better than a typical 500 MBoe well. The Second Bone Spring tends to be more stratigraphically  complex, so additional data we collect from drilling Wolfcamp wells has aided in much better targeting in longer laterals and more premium wells. We expect similar or better uplift to our Leonard shale result on a go-forward basis.
In the Rockies, we've had great success in the Powder River Basin and Wyoming DJ Basin. As announced in our press release yesterday, we drilled 3 Turner wells last quarter that averaged almost 2,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day and clear well costs which include drilling, completion and unleashed facilities averaged $5.4 million for a 6,500-foot laterals down from $6.5 million in 2015. These Turner wells are incredibly economic at $40 oil. We plan to drill a total of 20 net wells in the Turner this year. When we conducted our first count of premium inventory in December of last year, the DJ Basin Codell and Wyoming was slightly below the premium threshold. 
Due to sustainable cost reductions and better targeting, we added 200 premium locations in this play. Currently, Codell wells cost $5.9 million for a 9,400-foot lateral. As noted in our press release yesterday, our latest Codell well produced approximately 1,400 barrels of oil equivalent in first 30 days. We expect cost and well improvements to continue and are working to expand gas take away options in Wyoming. The DJ Basin Codell will become a larger part of our premium drilling program in the near future.
In East Irish Sea, I'm happy to report that Conway is currently producing approximately 10,000 barrels of oil per day. During the second quarter, Conway was down due to issues on the Douglas production platform. While Conway wells were initially tested at daily rate over more than 20,000 barrels of oil, results from recent production testing indicate the optimal level production is 10,000 barrels of oil per day. For the remainder of the year, we expect to average about 4,000 to 8,000 barrels of oil per day to accommodate further tests and potential downtime.
Here's Tim Driggers.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Capitalized interest in the second quarter of 2016 was $9 million. Exploration and development expenditures were $624 million, excluding property acquisitions, which is 49% less as compared to second quarter 2015, while our total production
componenttext:
Thanks, David. Capitalized interest in the second quarter of 2016 was $9 million. Exploration and development expenditures were $624 million, excluding property acquisitions, which is 49% less as compared to second quarter 2015, while our total production volumes decreased by just 2%. In addition, expenditures for gathering systems, processing plants and other property plant and equipment were $20 million. We have maintained our full year capital expenditure guidance of $2.4 billion to $2.6 billion. 
At the end of June 2016, total debt outstanding was $7 billion and the debt to total capitalization ratio was 37%. At June 30, we had $780 million of cash on hand, giving us non-GAAP net debt of $6.2 billion for a net debt-to-total cap ratio of 34%. Year-to-date, we have sold $425 million of assets with associated production of 45 million cubic feet per day of natural gas, 3,300 barrels of oil per day and 3,700 barrels per day of NGLs. Assets sold include Midland Basin and Colorado DJ Basin properties. The effective tax rate for the second quarter is 23%, and the deferred tax ratio was 214%. 
Now I'll turn it back over to Bill.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. Now, a brief word on our macro view and how it relates to our 2016 plans. Even though oil prices have been volatile, our yield supply demand fundamentals has not changed. We believe $40 oil will not provide enough cash flow or investment retu
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. Now, a brief word on our macro view and how it relates to our 2016 plans. Even though oil prices have been volatile, our yield supply demand fundamentals has not changed. We believe $40 oil will not provide enough cash flow or investment return to overcome the combined effect of production decline and demand growth worldwide. While EOG can deliver healthy growth within cash flow at $50 oil, we continue to believe the U.S. horizontal oil industry as a whole needs a sustained $60 oil price and extended lead time to deliver a moderate level of growth. As we discussed last quarter, the sustainable reduction in capital -- the substantial reduction in capital investments by the industry since 2014 is causing oil supply to decline in many producing regions worldwide. As production continues to decline, the inventory overhang will slowly work off. The consensus view here is the market will balance during 2017.
For 2016, given the uncertainty of the current commodity environment, we are maintaining our CapEx guidance at $2.4 billion to $2.6 billion. However, as a result of cost savings, we are increasing our well count to 250 drilled wells and 350 completed wells. This is an additional 50 wells drilled and 80 completions above our original plan for the same CapEx.
In summary, I would like to leave you with the following important takeaways from this call. Number one, we continue to reduce operating costs. We believe these reductions are sustainable, and we have additional efforts underway to reduce future operational costs. Number two, our shift to premium is achieving what we believe are the strongest investment returns at $40 oil in the U.S. Number three, our shift to premium is permanent. We are confident we can grow premium quality inventory much faster than we drill it. Number four, we continue to exceed our U.S. production targets by increasing capital efficiency. We believe these efficiency gains are sustainable and give EOG a significant advantage as we enter the next recovery. And number five, we are maintaining our strong balance sheet through disciplined spending.
I'll close this call with our view of EOG's future through 2020. There are 4 goals we plan to achieve. The first goal is to be the U.S. leader in the rate of return on capital investments, the second goal is to be the low-cost U.S. producer and, therefore, competitive in the global oil market, our third goal is to be the leader in lower 48 absolute oil growth through 2020, and our fourth goal is to maintain a strong balance sheet through disciplined spending. By achieving these 4 goals, we will accomplish our ultimate goal of creating long-term shareholder value, producing growth by consistently outstanding and drilling uneconomic wells is not an EOG's vocabulary. We firmly believe that growth should be the result of strong returns and disciplined spending. EOG's unwavering commitment to our long-term shareholders is the focus on returns first. The company is uniquely positioned to produce strong returns and resume high-return growth as commodity prices improve. Thanks for listening. And now we go to Q&A.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Of course, Evan, the driver is oil price, and if oil prices improve, above the $50 level, the oil capital will have and the faster we'll ramp up our activity, we're not limited on beginning out very significantly. Then, we have ongoing operations and
componenttext: Yes. Of course, Evan, the driver is oil price, and if oil prices improve, above the $50 level, the oil capital will have and the faster we'll ramp up our activity, we're not limited on beginning out very significantly. Then, we have ongoing operations and enough rigs and equipment going now and the DUCs really help us get off to a good start. But it is, as you can tell from the chart on 14, it's not 10% every year. So 2017, we'll start of incrementally at a lower rate and then we'll build from there as we go forward. And of course, as volumes grow, cash flow grows, too, so the process kind of multiplies itself as we go forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What drives the higher growth in the back end of the decade? I mean, does that reflect the EOR base decline management? Or is that all effect on -- from premium locations?
componenttext: What drives the higher growth in the back end of the decade? I mean, does that reflect the EOR base decline management? Or is that all effect on -- from premium locations?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's -- the whole driver for us being able to grow at these kinds of rates at these low oil prices is really the switch to premium and the lowering of the well cost at the same time. The productivity of the wells is just a tremendous uptick from where we
componenttext: It's -- the whole driver for us being able to grow at these kinds of rates at these low oil prices is really the switch to premium and the lowering of the well cost at the same time. The productivity of the wells is just a tremendous uptick from where we were in '14. And so the capital efficiency, I believe, is more than doubled since that time. We did not put in the outlook, we did not put any EOR investments in there or production response. So that's really not a part of the outlook that we've given you. Of course, the EOR has great capital efficiency, and it is just as good as premium and we're working at it over time, but -- as it's appropriate.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And we'll go to Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, it's -- this is -- it's pretty exciting to see this formal change, I guess. I guess, the question I have is, you could pretty much, assuming you're right on the macro, you could pretty much seem to grow at whatever pace you wanted as always to inven
componenttext: Bill, it's -- this is -- it's pretty exciting to see this formal change, I guess. I guess, the question I have is, you could pretty much, assuming you're right on the macro, you could pretty much seem to grow at whatever pace you wanted as always to inventory. I'm guessing the 10% hurdle is not for your site record that difficult to achieve. So what are the constraints that you see to EOG's growth aspirations? I've [indiscernible] expect people with infrastructure and maybe even switched capital towards EOR or back to shareholders?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. The constraint would be -- I think the biggest one would be, we don't want to lose the capital efficiency gains that we have built in right now, and so we don't want to go so fast that we're bringing in equipment and people are spending money a
componenttext: Yes, Doug. The constraint would be -- I think the biggest one would be, we don't want to lose the capital efficiency gains that we have built in right now, and so we don't want to go so fast that we're bringing in equipment and people are spending money and drilling wells and really lose these efficiency gains that we've got right now. So if oil, say, with the $70 or $60 or $70 really quick, we could ramp up appropriately, but we wouldn't do it overnight. We couldn't do it overnight, and we have to build up the service quality, and we would certainly want to maintain our efficiency that we've already built in. That's the one thing we don't want to do. Of course, we want to focus on our balance sheet and to get that net debt-to-cap back down to that below the 30% also. So I will let Gary Thomas kind of chime in on that. He can give some color on that.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. As Bill said, the premium drilling is what helps us with growth forward, because it just requires fewer wells and would not be having to ramp up to the number of rigs that we have, for instance, in 2014. And another reason is because of the pro
componenttext: Yes, Doug. As Bill said, the premium drilling is what helps us with growth forward, because it just requires fewer wells and would not be having to ramp up to the number of rigs that we have, for instance, in 2014. And another reason is because of the productivity by rig that you could look at exhibit 20 showing that. So we've got kind of a plan in place to be able to ramp up, to maintain our efficiencies and more than likely continue to reduce our costs.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: To answer your question on when we buy back shares, that's really not in our plans at this time. We're not opportunity limited. I mean, that's an important part of the process. Geologically, we don't have an opportunity limit there. So we would ramp up ap
componenttext: To answer your question on when we buy back shares, that's really not in our plans at this time. We're not opportunity limited. I mean, that's an important part of the process. Geologically, we don't have an opportunity limit there. So we would ramp up appropriately to maintain a discipline and to reduce the debt at the same time.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, I appreciate the detailed answer. Hopefully, my quick follow-up is just on the balance sheet. Clearly, there's going to be some assets that don't -- maybe don't make it into the premium inventory. So as you now made this permanent shift, rather than
componenttext: Bill, I appreciate the detailed answer. Hopefully, my quick follow-up is just on the balance sheet. Clearly, there's going to be some assets that don't -- maybe don't make it into the premium inventory. So as you now made this permanent shift, rather than get specific, could you kind of quantify for us what impact from your base production, do you think disposals could ultimately represent because obviously that would amplify the implied growth rate going forward?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, on the oil growth rate, I don't believe it's going to impact it significantly at all. The thing that we targeted this year are mostly gas and properties for sale. And as we go forward, they would either be kind of combo-ish, our gas properties going
componenttext: Doug, on the oil growth rate, I don't believe it's going to impact it significantly at all. The thing that we targeted this year are mostly gas and properties for sale. And as we go forward, they would either be kind of combo-ish, our gas properties going forward. So on the oil growth, property sales shouldn't be a factor much at all.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is Pearce Hammond with Simmons.
componenttext: Next is Pearce Hammond with Simmons.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the helpful long-term plan. My first question is given the rise in completion activity, do you believe you have enough access to enough Texas-based finer sands? Or will you need to use more the white sands potentially requiring you to reactivat
componenttext: Thanks for the helpful long-term plan. My first question is given the rise in completion activity, do you believe you have enough access to enough Texas-based finer sands? Or will you need to use more the white sands potentially requiring you to reactivate your Wisconsin mines?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pearce, we have both available to us. We've been working on our own Texas mine and plant and expanding there as far as our capability, as well as working on our Wisconsin plant being able to reduce cost and put in place improved transportation. So we beli
componenttext: Pearce, we have both available to us. We've been working on our own Texas mine and plant and expanding there as far as our capability, as well as working on our Wisconsin plant being able to reduce cost and put in place improved transportation. So we believe that we have adequate sand, and we believe we've been able to lower our sand cost as well. And we're seeing that helping our cost here in 2016. So we've got plenty of sand available. We feel like we've got most all of our resources available to us as well. The thing that's really helped us during this downturn is we've been able to just continue increasing our efficiencies. And before, I probably mentioned that we felt that as far as our cost reductions maybe 2/3 were sustainable. With what we've seen here from 2015 going to 2016, we've lowered our well costs in all of our areas somewhere 11% to 13%, and that's just through increased efficiencies. So those will go forward with this.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And then my follow-up, Bill, as you look at the nonpremium inventory, kind of big picture thought is, is it -- does it make sense to divest more of it? Or do you need to hold on to some of it and let technology catch up to that so you can mo
componenttext: Very helpful. And then my follow-up, Bill, as you look at the nonpremium inventory, kind of big picture thought is, is it -- does it make sense to divest more of it? Or do you need to hold on to some of it and let technology catch up to that so you can move that acreage into the premium category? So just want to get your big picture thoughts on how you view with that nonpremium inventory.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pearce. I will let Billy address that. Billy Helms.
componenttext: Yes, Pearce. I will let Billy address that. Billy Helms.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pearce. So in our inventory, as we continue to demonstrate, we can add more and more to our premium inventory. There are some of the inventory that may never make it to that, so we're looking at what options are best to bring that value forward, whet
componenttext: Yes, Pearce. So in our inventory, as we continue to demonstrate, we can add more and more to our premium inventory. There are some of the inventory that may never make it to that, so we're looking at what options are best to bring that value forward, whether it's monetize that property or produce of that for a period of time or whatever the optionality is. We have a tremendous amount of flexibility. We haven't designated certain properties yet to be put on the market, but we'll just be opportunistic in that approach and evaluate each one independently. We haven't really considered any of those volumes, as Bill said, in our 4-year or 5-year plan. And so as you mentioned, there'll be mostly gas or oil and gas combo play, so that really won't affect oil production guidance, if any.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now go to Subash Chandra with Guggenheim.
componenttext: And we'll now go to Subash Chandra with Guggenheim.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the question was in creating these premium locations, do you find the best rock gets better? Or are you equally successful in converting Tier 1, Tier 2 rock to premium?
componenttext: So the question was in creating these premium locations, do you find the best rock gets better? Or are you equally successful in converting Tier 1, Tier 2 rock to premium?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, the rock quality is a very big driver on the premium. And the higher the quality of the rock, the better it responds to the technical advances we make in the completions. There's no question about that. So I think, one of the things that's not cl
componenttext: I think, the rock quality is a very big driver on the premium. And the higher the quality of the rock, the better it responds to the technical advances we make in the completions. There's no question about that. So I think, one of the things that's not clearly understood in the horizontal shale industry is that these sweet spots in these plays, especially in oil plays, are not very large. So capturing the very highest quality rock is extremely important and certainly something that EOG's excelled in and focus on over the years, and it really is the biggest driver of productivity.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up is, how many completion crews you have active in your basins? And is there sort of a rig count to completion crew ratio that we should think about?
componenttext: My follow-up is, how many completion crews you have active in your basins? And is there sort of a rig count to completion crew ratio that we should think about?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary Thomas. We have now 8 completion units running. And we've got anywhere 11 to 12 rigs and that's a pretty good ratio [indiscernible] as an average.
componenttext: This is Gary Thomas. We have now 8 completion units running. And we've got anywhere 11 to 12 rigs and that's a pretty good ratio [indiscernible] as an average.

componenttextpreview: Could you scale up the rig count without adding completion units materially?
componenttext: Could you scale up the rig count without adding completion units materially?

componenttextpreview: We could, yes, it depends on where you add the rigs. If we add it in the Eagle Ford, we would have to add fewer completion units, for instance, there. They're just so efficient after having operated there for the last 7 or 8 years.
componenttext: We could, yes, it depends on where you add the rigs. If we add it in the Eagle Ford, we would have to add fewer completion units, for instance, there. They're just so efficient after having operated there for the last 7 or 8 years.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2016
