componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question -- our first question from Scott Hanold with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Impressive job this quarter, and congratulations on the increased outlook. As you step back and look at the big opportunity you all have in the Permian that you described, can you give us a sense on generally, how you're looking at developing that in term
componenttext: Impressive job this quarter, and congratulations on the increased outlook. As you step back and look at the big opportunity you all have in the Permian that you described, can you give us a sense on generally, how you're looking at developing that in terms of what formations may be high on the top of the list over the next couple of years. And how do you see pad development going forward in that play?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott, this is Billy Helms. So yes, on the Delaware, we do expect with this increase that our activity over time will continue to increase, especially going into next year. And our activity today has been focused largely on the Wolfcamp, and I think
componenttext: Yes, Scott, this is Billy Helms. So yes, on the Delaware, we do expect with this increase that our activity over time will continue to increase, especially going into next year. And our activity today has been focused largely on the Wolfcamp, and I think that will stay. The majority of the focus will stay on the Wolfcamp. Just to reiterate, all 3 plays are considered premium today, and we're excited about the potential. We're further along in our development at the Wolfcamp, and so for that reason, we'll continue to add it. It's an excellent volume growth generator, extremely high rate of return play. And by drilling it first, it also allows us to take a look at the shallower objectives as we drill down through those. So it gives us a better idea of long-term potential and how the drilling program in those plays will develop. In the future -- the second part of your question there about pad drilling. We are continuing to develop pad drilling as we develop the field now, and that will continue as we add the shallower zones as well. The good thing about that is we put in the infrastructure once for all those wells to share in the future. So incrementally, the overall rate of return for those programs in the future will continue to increase as we share that infrastructure. That's built out for the initial completion.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's good. And then my follow-up. This quarter, you guys are now producing -- it's over 50%, which was a pretty good heavy lifting here over the last few years to get. And when you look at your long-range outlook, can you give us a sense of how s
componenttext: Great, that's good. And then my follow-up. This quarter, you guys are now producing -- it's over 50%, which was a pretty good heavy lifting here over the last few years to get. And when you look at your long-range outlook, can you give us a sense of how some of the resource pieces contribute to that? So specifically, what is the Permian producing today? What's the Eagle Ford producing today? And in your long-range outlook, where do those plays go?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, we haven't broken out by play. And so I think the way you want to think about the company is that we have a very strong diversified portfolio. And from year-to-year -- actually, from maybe even quarter-to-quarter, we shift our capital to wherever w
componenttext: Scott, we haven't broken out by play. And so I think the way you want to think about the company is that we have a very strong diversified portfolio. And from year-to-year -- actually, from maybe even quarter-to-quarter, we shift our capital to wherever we see the highest rate of return. So things change over time. As Billy said, obviously, the Delaware is getting bigger and better for us, so we have to get more capital next year than we got this year. The Eagle Ford also. We'll get a lot of capital in the Rockies play, particularly the Powder River Basin, we'll get a lot of capital. But I think you need to be thinking of EOG as very balance, very large and a very diversified portfolio.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Subash Chandra with Guggenheim.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Subash Chandra with Guggenheim.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is, when I think about the number of locations, the Wolfcamp, is it 2 intervals that you're thinking about in each of the oil and Combo plays? And what's the status of the lower Wolfcamp, if you've had any results there?
componenttext: First question is, when I think about the number of locations, the Wolfcamp, is it 2 intervals that you're thinking about in each of the oil and Combo plays? And what's the status of the lower Wolfcamp, if you've had any results there?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Subash. This is Billy Helms again. So on the Wolfcamp, we generally think about, yes, 2 -- mainly 2 intervals -- 2 zones, the upper and middle is what we've assessed with resource potential, too. But within each one, there are multiple target interva
componenttext: Yes, Subash. This is Billy Helms again. So on the Wolfcamp, we generally think about, yes, 2 -- mainly 2 intervals -- 2 zones, the upper and middle is what we've assessed with resource potential, too. But within each one, there are multiple target intervals. So you can think about it as having multiple targets within each play. And we have assessed the potential mainly in areas where we tested each one, and we based that on our confirmed test -- confirmed results of each one. So that's how we kind of rolled up the resource potential there. So I'm sorry, what was the second part of your question?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The lower Wolfcamp.
componenttext: The lower Wolfcamp.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the lower Wolfcamp. I'm sorry. So yes, the lower Wolfcamp, we have had some tests. I'd say the majority of our tests so far have been in the upper part of the zone, but we also had some tests in what we call the middle Wolfcamp, and those results are
componenttext: Yes, the lower Wolfcamp. I'm sorry. So yes, the lower Wolfcamp, we have had some tests. I'd say the majority of our tests so far have been in the upper part of the zone, but we also had some tests in what we call the middle Wolfcamp, and those results are encouraging as well.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if I hear it correctly, it's a very highly risked measure in your locations that you published to date, right? Because if I just did resource map across multiple intervals, I can get many, many more locations than what you've published?
componenttext: Okay. So if I hear it correctly, it's a very highly risked measure in your locations that you published to date, right? Because if I just did resource map across multiple intervals, I can get many, many more locations than what you've published?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the way to think about that is, our results are based on our confirmed test in each one of the intervals. And then we allocate that to sticks-on-a-map kind of approach, where we -- it's not just taking the total number of acres and dividing i
componenttext: Yes. I think the way to think about that is, our results are based on our confirmed test in each one of the intervals. And then we allocate that to sticks-on-a-map kind of approach, where we -- it's not just taking the total number of acres and dividing it by well spacing. It's actually geologically looking at where those perspective intervals are -- exist. We've mapped them out pretty extensively and then placed well locations on those spots to assess the potential. So -- but you're right. It only goes to the zones we've tested, and we do feel like there's additional target intervals to test going forward.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a tremendous update, but I wonder if I could ask you about the 22 wells you did on Delaware this quarter. There's still the shorter laterals. But the well rates appear to still be -- maybe I'm getting this wrong, but it looks like they're still substan
componenttext: So a tremendous update, but I wonder if I could ask you about the 22 wells you did on Delaware this quarter. There's still the shorter laterals. But the well rates appear to still be -- maybe I'm getting this wrong, but it looks like they're still substantially better than even your longer lateral implied type curves. So can you help me understand what the implications are of the run rate that you're having on those recent completions?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say -- Doug, this Billy Helms. Yes, we're very excited about the potential that we're seeing in these zones more recently. And we -- the longer laterals are giving us a lot more efficiency, a lot more reserves per well, higher production rates. A
componenttext: Yes, I'd say -- Doug, this Billy Helms. Yes, we're very excited about the potential that we're seeing in these zones more recently. And we -- the longer laterals are giving us a lot more efficiency, a lot more reserves per well, higher production rates. And our EURs assessment for the play, though, is taking what we've tested across the play. And some of those tests are a little older, so we're trying to incorporate all the tests we have, and all of the wells are not benefiting from the latest results. So our results continue to improve, and we assess that as time goes forward. And I think the tremendous thing that we're seeing is just the benefits from our targeting and how that's really enhancing the productivity. And that really comes from our detailed look and continued work on assessing the geological potential of the play. And so that's why we're confident that as we continue to improve that technique and gain more understanding that we're going to see additional intervals that will add to the resource over time. So we fully expect that the resource and the play will continue to increase.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Billy, let me just put a point of clarification to make sure you know what I'm asking. So the new type curve on the Wolfcamp oil is 1.3 million. It looks like the wells you completed in the third quarter are even better than that. Am I getting that wr
componenttext: But Billy, let me just put a point of clarification to make sure you know what I'm asking. So the new type curve on the Wolfcamp oil is 1.3 million. It looks like the wells you completed in the third quarter are even better than that. Am I getting that wrong? Or is -- in other words, is there still upside to your assessment?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's exactly right. Yes, the wells we completed in the third quarter are improving. And actually, year-to-date, the results are still stronger than what our resource update is. So again, I think that's a testament to the technology and the things we
componenttext: No, that's exactly right. Yes, the wells we completed in the third quarter are improving. And actually, year-to-date, the results are still stronger than what our resource update is. So again, I think that's a testament to the technology and the things we're continuing to expand on and learn. So yes, I think there's additional upside potential there.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could add a little bit more color there, Doug. This is Bill Thomas. The rock quality drives the productivity of all these plays. And so we're getting better and better at identifying the better quality rock at each one of these plays, and then we're
componenttext: If I could add a little bit more color there, Doug. This is Bill Thomas. The rock quality drives the productivity of all these plays. And so we're getting better and better at identifying the better quality rock at each one of these plays, and then we're getting considerably better at locating the lateral with the precision targeting and keeping that lateral in that good rock for a long period, a long part of the lateral. So that's a process we're learning. We probably learn more about rock quality and targeting and execution on that part of the process in the last year or so than we've ever learned. So there's a lot of upside. As Billy said and talked about, we think there's a lot of upside on what to go in that process.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up, though, hopefully is a little quicker. It's kind of a related question. If you can achieve 15% to 25% at $50 to $60 oil, if these wells continue to get better, would you choose to raise the growth rate again or do more with less? I'm thi
componenttext: And my follow-up, though, hopefully is a little quicker. It's kind of a related question. If you can achieve 15% to 25% at $50 to $60 oil, if these wells continue to get better, would you choose to raise the growth rate again or do more with less? I'm thinking about constraints surrounding infrastructure and things of that nature. And I'll leave it there.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there is a limit on how fast we want to go, Doug, in each one of these plays, because you don't want to go faster than the learning curve and certainly, you do have to stay ahead of the infrastructure process. So -- and we don't want to lessen the c
componenttext: Well, there is a limit on how fast we want to go, Doug, in each one of these plays, because you don't want to go faster than the learning curve and certainly, you do have to stay ahead of the infrastructure process. So -- and we don't want to lessen the capital efficiency. We like to continue to increase the capital efficiencies that go along. So we're going to be very disciplined in our spending approach. And the rates of return, just to say a bit about it, the rates of return that we're getting on the premium is that the minimum return, that means the lowest return well in the 6,000-well inventory, generates a 30% rate of return at $40 oil and $2.50 flat gas prices. So the returns on the average well is much, much higher than 30%. So these are exceptionally strong wells.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, my first question is, you guys have added 2 billion barrels of Permian resource and indicated that's likely to rise over time and it's the best spending in your 40 years, so you're clearly not resource constraint. So how do you think about potential
componenttext: Bill, my first question is, you guys have added 2 billion barrels of Permian resource and indicated that's likely to rise over time and it's the best spending in your 40 years, so you're clearly not resource constraint. So how do you think about potential asset sales given acreage prices and given it appears like lots of the MPs are reaching a similar conclusion at a similar time? Is there a first-mover advantage? What are your thoughts there?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evan, as we continue to generate more potential and we continue to high grade that, it does give us a lot more opportunities for just high grading our asset portfolio through property sales. So we're going to continue that process, evaluating each asset,
componenttext: Evan, as we continue to generate more potential and we continue to high grade that, it does give us a lot more opportunities for just high grading our asset portfolio through property sales. So we're going to continue that process, evaluating each asset, seeing how it mixes and fits into the future of the company. And the noncore assets are the ones that don't reach -- I don't think will reach the premium category. They'll certainly be candidates for asset sales in the future. And that will help keep our balance sheet strong. And we want to operate -- from a spending standpoint, we want to operate the cash flow, but the property sale proceeds will continue to help us keep our balance sheet strong. And by increasing the quality of things we drill over time, obviously, increasing the returns, but we're also lowering the funding cost, which will filter back down through the base. You've heard that a company had lowered the DD&A rate. So it's a process of just getting better in all areas through time.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my second question, it's a follow-up to Doug's. I mean, you introduced the higher oil growth guidance here, 15% to 25%. I mean, the entire industry from small cap to Chevron is projecting an impressive rise in growth targets in -- largely in taxes and
componenttext: And my second question, it's a follow-up to Doug's. I mean, you introduced the higher oil growth guidance here, 15% to 25%. I mean, the entire industry from small cap to Chevron is projecting an impressive rise in growth targets in -- largely in taxes and oil prices. So I mean, how do you -- what do you think the limitations of growth are for EOG? Or where they are or the levels? And how are you -- what will differentiate EOG in the execution? And how are you preparing to deliver that and execute better than the industry?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the real advantage we have, Evan, is the rates of return that we're generating off. Each one of these wells is, we believe, is significantly higher than the industry. And so that will filter down through the financials, and in due time, it w
componenttext: Well, I think the real advantage we have, Evan, is the rates of return that we're generating off. Each one of these wells is, we believe, is significantly higher than the industry. And so that will filter down through the financials, and in due time, it will show up in ROCE. So our first goal, as I mentioned, is to be the U.S. leader in terms of ROCE. And that's a position that we've historically held, and I think it's a big distinguishing factor in the company.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is there any level as you think about maximum growth rate achievable just within the organization outside of ROCE?
componenttext: And is there any level as you think about maximum growth rate achievable just within the organization outside of ROCE?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't want to speculate on that. We want to stay efficient, and we want to continue to get better. So as I talked about before, we want to stay disciplined and under control. And so the goal is to get better, not just to get bigger. So we're going
componenttext: Well, I don't want to speculate on that. We want to stay efficient, and we want to continue to get better. So as I talked about before, we want to stay disciplined and under control. And so the goal is to get better, not just to get bigger. So we're going tackle that from that standpoint.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to ask a question about the estimate -- resource estimate of the Yates transaction. I think you guys put some information on your slides, specifically Slide 9. You have the resource per well for those Yates -- for the Yates acquisition around 920
componenttext: I'd like to ask a question about the estimate -- resource estimate of the Yates transaction. I think you guys put some information on your slides, specifically Slide 9. You have the resource per well for those Yates -- for the Yates acquisition around 920, higher than what you had incumbent in your portfolio. Can you talk about what the factors -- what factors that higher per well resource reflects? And maybe, is that a piece of a bigger picture that, in general, the rock quality is higher as you move up into New Mexico, whether you have a deep or higher pressure of the lateral lengths that is driving that?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles. This is Billy Helms. So when we assess most of the potential on the Yates acreage, it was generally on the basis of 1-mile laterals. And since then, we've come back in and assess the potential across all the plays. And as you've noticed, the
componenttext: Yes, Charles. This is Billy Helms. So when we assess most of the potential on the Yates acreage, it was generally on the basis of 1-mile laterals. And since then, we've come back in and assess the potential across all the plays. And as you've noticed, the lateral length on most of the -- across the whole portfolio has increased to about 7,000 feet per well in the oil window and even greater than that in the combo window. And so I think the -- a lot of the initial estimates you saw there on Slide 9 were based on our assessment when we made the transaction for Yates. And those were based on essentially 1 mile per well. So that's the majority of the difference. But as -- but I might just add, as we move into this, the one thing that Yates does allow us to do is to block it up with our existing acreage. So we fully expect to be able to drill these longer laterals across all the portfolio.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, Bill, if I could ask a question about the 15% to 25% CAGR that you put out. You touched on this, I believe, on the last conference call about how that trajectory might shift or evolve over the 2017 to 2020 framework. Do you see that CAGR
componenttext: Got it. And then, Bill, if I could ask a question about the 15% to 25% CAGR that you put out. You touched on this, I believe, on the last conference call about how that trajectory might shift or evolve over the 2017 to 2020 framework. Do you see that CAGR, whether we're talking about the $50 low end or the $60 high end, do you see that being back-end weighted or that growth accelerating through that 3-year time frame? Or is it more likely to be front-end weighted?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, if you look at the slide in the front part of the slide deck, it shows the curve. It shows that in 2017, the growth rate is smaller and it grows over time. So in 2017, it's less than 15% at $50. And into 2020, it's probably more than 15% at $50.
componenttext: Charles, if you look at the slide in the front part of the slide deck, it shows the curve. It shows that in 2017, the growth rate is smaller and it grows over time. So in 2017, it's less than 15% at $50. And into 2020, it's probably more than 15% at $50. So it's more back-end weighted.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Pearce Hammond with Simmons -- Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Pearce Hammond with Simmons -- Piper Jaffray.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, Bill, is on rigs and what the rig count could look like based upon this long-term production, oil production growth plan. Kind of where are you right now on rig count? And I know you haven't given '17 guidance, but looking at this long-
componenttext: My first question, Bill, is on rigs and what the rig count could look like based upon this long-term production, oil production growth plan. Kind of where are you right now on rig count? And I know you haven't given '17 guidance, but looking at this long-term oil production growth plan, where do you see rigs traversing to? Any color you can provide on that would be helpful.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pearce, this is Gary Thomas. Right now, we have 15 rigs operating domestic. We got 1 international, that being in Trinidad. And we, as you say, we haven't disclosed what we had planned for 2017. However, just with the rig efficiency that we've seen over t
componenttext: Pearce, this is Gary Thomas. Right now, we have 15 rigs operating domestic. We got 1 international, that being in Trinidad. And we, as you say, we haven't disclosed what we had planned for 2017. However, just with the rig efficiency that we've seen over this last 2 years and with the type of rigs we have in place, we will not be required to ramp up the number of rigs very much for most any plan that we have put in place. Just have a tremendous amount of flexibility. The one thing that we had, 2016, most of our rigs were under long-term contract, high rates. As we've mentioned, yes, we'll have only about half that number for 2017. But we put in place rates that are about 40% lower for essentially the same number of rigs.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And in those 15 rigs, how are those broken out right now?
componenttext: Great. And in those 15 rigs, how are those broken out right now?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, we got 5 in Midland. That's really what we've averaged this year, and that is Delaware Basin. We have 6 now in San Antonio. We have 4 in Rocky Mountains because we have 1 rig that was required on the Yates position in the Powder River Basin, an
componenttext: Right now, we got 5 in Midland. That's really what we've averaged this year, and that is Delaware Basin. We have 6 now in San Antonio. We have 4 in Rocky Mountains because we have 1 rig that was required on the Yates position in the Powder River Basin, and we'll be letting it go. But as we've mentioned earlier, we're going to be picking up an additional rig for the Delaware Basin at year-end and also for San Antonio for the Eagle Ford.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my follow-up pertains to sand loadings. And I'm just curious in the Delaware Basin specifically, where are you on sand loadings right now? And have you reached the point of diminishing returns on sand loadings? Or are we not there yet?
componenttext: Great. And then my follow-up pertains to sand loadings. And I'm just curious in the Delaware Basin specifically, where are you on sand loadings right now? And have you reached the point of diminishing returns on sand loadings? Or are we not there yet?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary Thomas. We are still experimenting there in the Delaware Basin. I might just take you back to the Eagle Ford, where we've operated for so many years. We found a point of diminishing returns. And as a matter of fact, here, sand loading for 201
componenttext: This is Gary Thomas. We are still experimenting there in the Delaware Basin. I might just take you back to the Eagle Ford, where we've operated for so many years. We found a point of diminishing returns. And as a matter of fact, here, sand loading for 2016 on the average is slightly less than what it was in 2015. So we've got a pretty good handle as to what we anticipate as an optimum sand loading rate there for the Delaware Basin.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you share what that is on a pounds per foot basis?
componenttext: Can you share what that is on a pounds per foot basis?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- Pearce, this is Billy Helms. [indiscernible] It will vary on each area and by zone, too. So we've tested as much as maybe 3,000 pounds per foot, which is probably not going to be applicable across all of the plays in every area. It's probably g
componenttext: I think -- Pearce, this is Billy Helms. [indiscernible] It will vary on each area and by zone, too. So we've tested as much as maybe 3,000 pounds per foot, which is probably not going to be applicable across all of the plays in every area. It's probably going to average somewhere between 2,000 and 2,800, probably in that range, depending on the zone and where it is. But it will be a broad range depending on the play and where it is within the play. And that's why we're in the process of trying to dial in, as Gary has mentioned.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First couple of questions on the Eagle Ford. Can you add some more color on the staggered spacing test put 200-foot spacing into context in terms of how widespread that may be applicable and the total locations per unit that would represent? And then how
componenttext: First couple of questions on the Eagle Ford. Can you add some more color on the staggered spacing test put 200-foot spacing into context in terms of how widespread that may be applicable and the total locations per unit that would represent? And then how do you view the well economics and EURs, given that you've been applying some enhanced targeting and completions over more -- for more than a year?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian, this is David Trice. On the stack stagger targeting and spacing, we've been working on that for well over a year, and we're seeing good results on that. As we noted there in the core [ph] wells, I mean, we're not seeing any degradation on the
componenttext: Yes, Brian, this is David Trice. On the stack stagger targeting and spacing, we've been working on that for well over a year, and we're seeing good results on that. As we noted there in the core [ph] wells, I mean, we're not seeing any degradation on the areas that we're doing that. So it's not applicable over the entire position. In some places, we do have 2 good targets in the lower Eagle Ford, so it -- so we're certainly doing that there. But I think over time,  we'll continue to see that improve as we dial the targets in a little bit better and we work on the completions. But again, it's not applicable to all areas because some areas are -- we have really just 1 target. So really, throughout the play, we're looking at anywhere from 200-foot spacing to 300 or 350, depending on the area.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then shifting over to the Powder River Basin, which it seems like you're employing a similar strategy here as with post-Yates as you are in the Permian. Can you talk to the potential cost savings per BOE from deploying longer laterals in the P
componenttext: Got it. And then shifting over to the Powder River Basin, which it seems like you're employing a similar strategy here as with post-Yates as you are in the Permian. Can you talk to the potential cost savings per BOE from deploying longer laterals in the PRB? And then post-Yates, what type of activity do you think we could see? And how prospective do you view opportunities beyond the Turner Sand?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is David again. In the Powder River, we're still really in early innings there. We've been testing various zones, and we're -- we've been focused mainly on the Turner lately. But we do see a lot of upside as far as extending these laterals. Like
componenttext: Yes, this is David again. In the Powder River, we're still really in early innings there. We've been testing various zones, and we're -- we've been focused mainly on the Turner lately. But we do see a lot of upside as far as extending these laterals. Like we mentioned earlier that we're seeing a big uplift on the economics in the Powder River as we do in other plays. So we do think going forward, it's going to be a bigger part of the program.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Is this an area that, you mentioned exploratory, the potential for further exploration and then this may not count as exploration since you already have some premium locations built? But how does the Powder fall in, in terms of incremental opportu
componenttext: Got it. Is this an area that, you mentioned exploratory, the potential for further exploration and then this may not count as exploration since you already have some premium locations built? But how does the Powder fall in, in terms of incremental opportunities for EOG beyond the big 3?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, I think, it's an area where we have stacked pay. We've got 4,000 to 5,000 feet of potential here. It's similar to the Delaware Basin. But like I mentioned, we are early. We are still testing a lot of targets, and we do have substantial acreag
componenttext: Well, again, I think, it's an area where we have stacked pay. We've got 4,000 to 5,000 feet of potential here. It's similar to the Delaware Basin. But like I mentioned, we are early. We are still testing a lot of targets, and we do have substantial acreage position there. We've got 200,000 net acres really in the core of the play. But really across the basin, we've got kind of more of an exploration area. We've got more like 400,000 acres. So again, I do think there's potential for additional activity here in the Powder.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a longer-term strategic question for you guys. How do you think about the potential to generate free cash flow prior to the collapse in crude? We've seen you reach a point where like cash returned to shareholders became a slightly more meaningful co
componenttext: Maybe a longer-term strategic question for you guys. How do you think about the potential to generate free cash flow prior to the collapse in crude? We've seen you reach a point where like cash returned to shareholders became a slightly more meaningful component of shareholder return as reflected by some pretty substantial increases to the dividend. When you look out over the next few years, do you envision dividend growth becoming more meaningful again? Or is the outlook for growth changed enough that we should expect all incremental cash flow to go into drilling for the foreseeable future?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, the dividend certainly is very important to us. And as the business environment improves and prices improve, we'll start considering increasing the dividend again. And then certainly, generating free cash flow is a goal that we want to begin to do.
componenttext: Ryan, the dividend certainly is very important to us. And as the business environment improves and prices improve, we'll start considering increasing the dividend again. And then certainly, generating free cash flow is a goal that we want to begin to do. And we generated just a slight amount in the third quarter. And so that's a goal that we want to continue to focus on as we go forward. So free cash flow and dividend growth will be a part of the game plan as the business environment improves.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe, one, just as we think about infrastructure, I know you talked about it a little bit. Any constraints in the Permian in your -- from an infrastructure side? And in terms of kind of a rough outlook for what we should expect you to spen
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe, one, just as we think about infrastructure, I know you talked about it a little bit. Any constraints in the Permian in your -- from an infrastructure side? And in terms of kind of a rough outlook for what we should expect you to spend on infrastructure spend, it's like -- is 15% of the capital budget a reasonable amount? Or anything in the ballpark, how much -- what your needs are going to be as you ramp over the next 3 or 4 years?

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, this is Gary Thomas. Just to address, yes, the infrastructure spending for next year, it'll be very similar to what we've had the last several years. We want to stay up. We're a little bit ahead, and it'll be in that 18% to 20% of our capital. We'll
componenttext: Ryan, this is Gary Thomas. Just to address, yes, the infrastructure spending for next year, it'll be very similar to what we've had the last several years. We want to stay up. We're a little bit ahead, and it'll be in that 18% to 20% of our capital. We'll let Lance address, yes, our position, infrastructure there for Delaware.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Thanks, Gary. Ryan, the team has done a great job on gas takeaway. And when you think about the extensive gas gathering system that we put into service, we're going to have multiple market connections in the area. So we plan on exiting this year with
componenttext: Yes, Thanks, Gary. Ryan, the team has done a great job on gas takeaway. And when you think about the extensive gas gathering system that we put into service, we're going to have multiple market connections in the area. So we plan on exiting this year with over $300 million a day of firm plant capacity. So when we think about that, coupled with our NGL transportation or fractionation capacity too, we really don't see any constraints from the gas standpoint at all. And then also maybe just to add on oil, too. We're actually finalizing agreements for a new oil terminal that's going to be, hopefully, coming into service in late 2017. So with that, we'll have all the market diversification, whether that's the Gold Coast, the Cushing, and also just continuing to align ourselves with our strategic refining partners. So we couldn't be more excited about the developments and staying out in front of the curve.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that does conclude our Q&A session. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Thomas for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And that does conclude our Q&A session. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Thomas for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In closing, I want to say thank you to all the tremendous EOG employees who are making the record-setting accomplishments we've done this year a reality. Everyone listening, do not think EOG is maxed out on room to improve. And we see miles of improvement
componenttext: In closing, I want to say thank you to all the tremendous EOG employees who are making the record-setting accomplishments we've done this year a reality. Everyone listening, do not think EOG is maxed out on room to improve. And we see miles of improvement opportunities ahead of us, and we look forward to 2017 and beyond. So thank you for listening, and thank you for your support.

headline: EOG Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2016
